22.17: Then tell us, what seems good to thee? is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar, or not?
22.18: And Jesus knowing their wickedness, said, Why tempt ye me, O ye hypocrites?
22.19: Show me the tribute money: and they brought Him a denarion.
22.20: And He says to them, Whose is this image and superscription?
22.22: And hearing they are astonished, and leaving Him, they went away.
22.23: On that day the Sadducees came to Him, saying, there is no resurrection: and asked Him,
22.24: saying, Teacher, Moses said, If any man may die, not having children, his brother shall marry his wife, and raise up seed to his brother.
22.25: But there were among us seven brothers: the first marrying died, and having no seed left his wife to his brother.
22.26: Likewise also, the second, and third, even unto seven.
22.27: And last of all the woman also died.
22.28: Therefore in the resurrection, of which one of the seven shall she be the wife? for they all had her.
22.29: and Jesus responding said to them, You err, not knowing the Scriptures, nor the power of God.
22.30: For in the resurrection they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but they are as angels of God in heaven:
22.31: concerning the resurrection of the dead, have you not read that which was spoken to you by God, saying,
22.32: I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.
22.33: And the multitudes hearing, were delighted with His teaching.
22.34: And the Pharisees, hearing that He silenced the Sadducees, gathered themselves together.
22.35: And one of them, a theologian, tempting Him, asked Him also, saying,
22.36: Teacher, what is the great commandment in the law?
22.37: And He said to him; Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.
22.38: This is the first and great commandment.
22.39: And the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.
22.40: On these two commandments hang all the law, and the prophets.
22.41: And the Pharisees being assembled, Jesus asked them,
22.42: saying, What seems to you concerning the Christ? whose son is He? They say to Him, Of David.
22.43: He says to them, How then does David in the Spirit call Him Lord, saying,
22.44: The Lord said to my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, until I may make thine enemies the footstool of thy feet?
22.45: Then if David calls Him Lord, how is He his son?
22.46: And no one was able to respond a word to Him, neither did any one from that day dare to ask Him anything more.

23.1: Then Jesus spoke to the multitudes and His disciples,
23.2: saying, The scribes and Pharisees sat upon the seat of Moses;
23.3: therefore do and keep all things so many as they may speak to you, but do not according to their works; for they say, and do not.
23.4: But they bind heavy burdens, and place them on the shoulders of the people; and they themselves are not willing to touch them with their finger.
23.6: and they love the first couch at the suppers, and the first seats in the synagogues,
23.7: and salutations in the forums, and to be called by the people, "Doctor."
23.10: Be not called teachers: because One is your teacher, Christ.
23.11: And the great of you shall be your deacon.
23.12: But whosoever shall exalt himself, shall be abased; and whosoever shall humble himself shall be exalted.
23.15: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because you compass the sea and the dry land to make one proselyte, and when it may be done, you make him twofold more the son of hell than yourselves.
23.16: Woe unto you, blind guides, who are saying, Whosoever may swear by the temple it is nothing; but whosoever may swear by the gold of the temple, he is debtor.
23.17: Ye fools and blind: for which is the greater, the gold, or the temple sanctifying the gold?
23.18: And, Whosoever may swear by the altar, it is nothing; but whosoever may swear by the gift upon it, is debtor.
23.19: Ye blind: for which is the greater, the gift, or the altar which sanctifies the gift?
23.20: Therefore the one swearing by the altar, swears by it, and by all things which are on it.
23.21: And the one swearing by the temple, swears by it, and by Him who inhabited it.
23.22: And the one swearing by heaven, swears by the throne of God, and by Him that sitteth upon it.
23.23: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because you tithe mint and anise and cummin, and pass by the weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy, and faith: it behooves to do these and not to neglect those.
23.24: Ye blind guides, who strain out the gnat, and swallow down the camel.
23.25: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because you purify the exterior of the cup and the plate, and within they are full of extortion and impurity.
23.26: Ye blind Pharisee, first purify the inside of the cup, in order that its outside may be clean.
23.27: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because you are like whitened sepulchers, which are beautiful indeed externally, but within they are full of the hones of the dead people, and every impurity.
23.28: So you also appear unto the people indeed righteous, but within you are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.
23.29: Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because you build the tombs of the prophets, and ornament the sepulchers of the righteous,
23.30: and you say, If we were in the days of our fathers we would not have been their fellow-partakers in the blood of the prophets.
23.31: So you witness to yourselves, that you are the sons of those who murdered the prophets.
23.32: And you fill up the measure of your fathers.
23.33: Ye serpents, generations of vipers, how can you escape from the judgment of hell?
23.34: Therefore I send unto you prophets, and wise men, and scribes: you will kill and crucify some of them; and will scourge some of them in your synagogues, and will persecute them from city to city;
23.35: in order that all the righteous blood shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel, unto the blood of Zachariah the son of the blessed, whom they slew between the temple and the altar, may come upon you.
23.36: Truly I say unto you, all these things shall come upon this generation.
23.37: O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them that have been sent unto thee! how frequently did I wish to gather together thy children, in the manner in which a hen gathers her brood under her wings, but ye were not willing!
23.38: Behold, your house is left unto you desolate.

24.1: Jesus having gone out departed from the temple, and His disciples came to Him to show Him the buildings of the temple.
24.3: And He sitting upon the Mount of Olives; the disciples came to Him privately, saying, Tell us, when these things shall be? and what shall be the sign of thy coming and the end of the age?
24.4: And Jesus responding said to them, See, lest any one may deceive you.
24.5: For many will come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and they will deceive many.
24.6: And you will be about to hear of wars and rumors of wars: see that you are not disturbed: for it behooveth all these things to be, but the end is not yet.
24.7: For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be famines and earthquakes in divers places.
24.8: And all these things are the beginning of travails.
24.9: Then they will deliver you into tribulation, and will kill you, and you will be hated by all nations on account of my name,
24.10: and then many will be offended; and they will betray one another, and hate one another.
24.11: And many false prophets will arise and deceive many.
24.12: And because iniquity doth abound, the divine love of many will grow cold.
24.13: But the one persevering to the end, the same shall be saved.
24.14: And this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world, for a testimony to all the nations; and then the end shall come.
24.15: Then when you may see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place (let him that readeth know),
24.16: then let those who are in Judea fly to the mountains:
24.17: and let him who is on the housetop not come down to take things out of his house:
24.18: and let not the one in the field turn back to take his garment.
24.19: But alas unto those who are in gestation and nursing in those days.
24.20: But pray that your flight may not be in the winter, nor on the Sabbath.
24.21: For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world even until now nor ever may be.
24.22: And if those days were not shortened, no life would be saved: but for the sake of the elect those days will be shortened.
24.23: Then if any one may say to you, Lo, here is Christ, or, there: believe him not:
24.24: for false Christs and false prophets will rise up, and give great signs and wonders; so as to deceive even the elect, if possible.
24.27: For as the lightning comes from the east, and shines even unto the west; so also shall the coming of the Son of man be.
24.28: For where the carcass is, there the eagles will be gathered together.
24.29: And immediately, after the desolation of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give her light, and the stars will fall from the heavens, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken.
24.30: And then the sign of the Son of man will appear in the heaven: and all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and will see the Son of man coming in the clouds of heaven with power and much glory.
24.31: And He will send forth His angels with a great trumpet, and they will gather His elect out of the four winds, from the extremities of the heavens, unto the extremities of the same.
24.32: But learn the parable from the fig-tree: when her branch may now be tender, and she may grow out leaves, know that the summer is nigh.
24.33: So you also, when you may see all these things know that it is at the doors.
24.34: Truly I say unto you, This race may not pass away until all these things may be fulfilled.
24.35: Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words can not pass away.
24.37: But as were the days of Noah, so indeed shall be the coming of the Son of man.
24.38: For as in those days before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day on which Noah entered into the ark,
24.39: and they did not know until the flood came, and took them all away; so shall be the coming of the Son of man.
24.40: Then two men shall be in the field; one is taken, and one is left.
24.41: Two women will be grinding at the mill; one is taken, and one is left.
24.42: Watch therefore: because you do not know on what day your Lord cometh.
24.43: But know this, that if the landlord knew at what watch the thief cometh, he would have watched, and would not have permitted his house to be broken into.
24.44: Therefore be ye also ready: because the Son of man cometh in an hour at which you do not think.
24.45: Then who is the faithful and wise servant, whom the lord placed over his household to give them their food in season?
24.46: Happy is that servant whom, his lord having come, will find so doing.
24.47: Truly I say unto you, that he will appoint him over all his possessions.
24.48: But if the wicked servant may say in his heart,
24.49: My lord delayeth; and may begin to smite his fellow-servants, and eat and drink with the drunken;
24.50: the lord of that servant will come in a day in which he does not expect, and an hour in which he does not know,
24.51: and he will cut him off, and will appoint his part with hypocrites: and there shall be weeping and gnashing of the teeth.

25.1: Then shall the kingdom of the heavens be likened unto ten virgins, who taking their lamps, went out to meet the bridegroom.
25.2: And five of them were foolish, and five were wise.
25.3: For the foolish, taking their lamps, took no oil with themselves:
25.4: and the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.
25.5: But the bridegroom tarrying, they all nodded and slept.
25.7: Then all those virgins arose and trimmed their lamps.
25.8: And the foolish said to the wise, Give us of your oil; for our lamps are going out.
25.9: And the wise responded, saying, No, lest there may not be a sufficiency for us and you: go ye rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves.
25.11: And afterwards the other virgins come, saying; Lord, lord, open unto us.
25.13: Watch therefore, because you know neither the day nor the hour.
25.15: to one he gave five talents, to another two, to another one; to each one according to his own ability; and departed.
25.16: The one having received the five talents going immediately, operated with the same, and made other five talents.
25.17: Likewise the one having received two gained two others.
25.18: And he having received one, having gone away, digged up the earth, and buried the money belonging to his lord.
25.20: And the one having received the five talents coming to him brought other five talents, saying, Lord, thou didst deliver unto me five talents: behold, I have gained other five talents.
25.21: His lord said to him, Well done, thou good and faithful servant: thou wast faithful over few things, and I will make thee ruler over many things: come thou into the joy of thy lord.
25.22: And the one having received two talents, coming to him, said, Lord, thou didst deliver unto me two talents: behold, I have gained other two talents.
25.23: And his lord said to him, Well done, good and faithful servant; thou wast faithful over few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: come thou into the joy of thy lord.
25.24: And the one having received one talent also coming, said, Lord, I knew thee that thou art a hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown, and gathering where thou hast not strewn:
25.25: and being afraid, having gone away, I hid thy talent in the earth: behold, thou hast thine own.
25.27: Therefore it behooved thee to put my money in the bank, and having come, I would receive my own with the product.
25.28: Therefore take the talent from him, and give it to the one having ten talents.
25.29: For to every one having it shall be given, and he shall superabound: but from the one not having shall be taken away even that which he has.
25.30: And cast ye the unprofitable servant into the darkness which is without: and there shall be weeping and gnashing of the teeth.
25.31: But when the Son of min may come in His glory, and all His angels with Him, then will He sit upon the throne of His glory:
25.32: and all nations shall be gathered before Him: and He will separate them from one another, as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats:
25.33: and He will place the sheep on His right, and the goats on His left.
25.35: For I was hungry, and you gave me to eat: I was thirsty, and you gave me drink: I was a stranger, and you took me in;
25.36: was naked, and ye clothed me: was sick, and ye visited me: was in prison, and ye came unto me.
25.37: Then the righteous will respond to Him, saying; Lord, when saw we thee then hungry, and fed thee? or thirsty, and gave thee drink?
25.38: And when saw we thee then a stranger, and took thee in? or naked, and clothed thee?
25.39: But when saw we thee sick, or in prison, and came unto thee?
25.40: And the King responding will say unto them, Truly I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did these things to one of the least of these my brethren, you did them unto me.
25.42: For I was hungry, and you gave me nothing to eat: I was thirsty, and you gave me nothing to drink:
25.43: I was a stranger and you took me not in; was naked, and you clothed me not; was sick, and in prison, and you visited me not.
25.44: Then will they also respond, saying, Lord, when saw we thee hungry, or thirsty, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and ministered not unto thee?
25.45: Then will He respond to them, saying, Truly I say unto you, Inasmuch as you did not these things to one of the least of these, you did them not unto me.
25.46: And these shall go away into eternal punishment: and the righteous into eternal life.

26.1: And it came to pass, when Jesus finished these discourses, He said to His disciples,
26.2: You know that after two days is the passover, and the Son of man is delivered to be crucified.
26.3: Then the chief priests, and scribes, and elders of the people, were assembled in the hall of the high priest, called Caiaphas.
26.4: And they immediately passed the verdict that they would take Jesus by stratagem, and kill Him.
26.5: But they said, Not at the feast, lest there be an uproar among the people.
26.6: And Jesus being in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
26.7: a woman having an alabaster box of myrrh, very valuable, came to Him and poured it on His head, while sitting at the table.
26.8: And His disciples, seeing, were indignant, saying, For what was this waste?
26.9: For this was able to be sold for much, and given to the poor.
26.10: And Jesus knowing, said to them, Why do you give the woman trouble? because she hath wrought a beautiful work in me.
26.11: For you have the poor with you always; but you have not me always.
26.12: For she pouring this myrrh on my body, did it in order to my burial.
26.13: Truly I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel may be preached in all the world, that which she did shall indeed be spoken of for a memorial of her.
26.14: Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, going to the chief priests,
26.15: said, What do you wish to give me, and I will deliver Him to you? And they offered him thirty pieces of silver.
26.16: And from that time he was seeking opportunity that he might betray Him.
26.17: On the first day of the unleavened bread, the disciples came to Jesus, saying to Him; Where do you wish that we may prepare for you to eat the passover?
26.18: And He said; Go into the city to a certain one, and say to him; The Teacher says; My time is nigh; I make the passover with you along with my disciples.
26.19: And the disciples did as Jesus commanded them, and prepared the passover.
26.20: And it being evening, He sat down at the table with the twelve.
26.21: And they eating, He said; Truly, I say unto you, that one of you will betray me.
26.22: And they being exceedingly sorrowful, began each one of them to say to Him, Lord, whether am I the one?
26.23: And responding He said, The one dipping his hand in the dish with me, the same shall betray me.
26.24: Indeed the Son of man goeth, as has been written concerning Him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! It was good for him if that man had never been born.
26.25: But Judas, the one betraying Him, responding said, Master, whether am I the one? He says to him, Thou hast said it.
26.26: And they eating, Jesus taking the bread, and blessing it, broke, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.
26.28: for this is my blood which belongs to the new covenant, which is shed for many unto the remission of sin.
26.29: And I say unto you, that I shall no more drink of the fruit of the vine, until that day when I may drink it new with you in the kingdom of my Father.
26.30: Having sung a hymn, they went out into the Mount of Olives.
26.31: Then Jesus says to them, You will all be offended in me this night: for it has been written, I will smite the Shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered.
26.32: And after I am risen, I will go before you into Galilee.
26.34: Jesus said to him, Truly I say unto thee, That this night, before the cock shall crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
26.36: Then Jesus comes with them into a place called Gethsemane, and He says to His disciples, Sit here, until I having gone may pray there.
26.37: And taking Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, He began to grieve and to be dejected.
26.38: Then He says to them, My soul is exceedingly sorrowful, even unto death: abide here, and pray with me.
26.39: And having gone forward a little, He fell on His face, praying, and saying, My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me: moreover not as I will, but as thou wilt.
26.40: And He comes to the disciples, and finds them sleeping, and says to Peter, Were you not able to watch with me one hour?
26.41: Watch and pray, that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
26.42: And again the second time, having gone away, He prayed, saying, My Father, if it is possible that this cup pass from me, if I shall not drink it, let thy will be done.
26.43: And having come He finds them again sleeping, for their eyes were heavy.
26.44: And leaving them, having gone away, He prayed again the third time, speaking the same word.
26.46: arise, let us go: behold, the one having betrayed me is nigh.
26.47: And He still speaking, behold, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
26.48: And the one having betrayed Him gave them a sign, saying, The one whom I shall kiss, is He: hold Him fast.
26.49: And immediately coming forward to Jesus, he said, Hail, Master; and kissed Him copiously.
26.51: And behold, one of those along with Jesus, reaching out his hand, drew his sword, and smiting the servant of the high priest, cut off his ear.
26.52: Then Jesus says to him, Turn away thy sword into its place; for all taking the sword shall perish by the sword.
26.53: Whether do you think that I am not able now to call upon my Father, and He will send me more than twelve legions of angels?
26.54: How then would the Scriptures be fulfilled, because it is necessary thus to be done?
26.55: And at that hour Jesus said to the multitudes, You have come out as against a robber with swords and clubs to take me: daily did I sit with you, teaching in the temple, and you did not arrest me:
26.56: but all this took place that the Scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then the disciples all leaving Him, fled away.
26.57: Taking Jesus they led Him to Caiaphas the high priest, where the chief priests and elders were assembled together.
26.58: And Peter followed Him a long way off, into the court of the high priest, and having come in, was sitting with the officers, to see the end.
26.59: And the high priests and all the sanhedrim were seeking false testimony against Jesus, in order that they might kill Him.
26.60: And they found none. And many false witnesses having come forward, they found none.
26.61: And afterwards two false witnesses having come forward, said, He said, I am able to destroy the temple of God, and build it in three days.
26.63: And Jesus was silent; and the high priest responding said to Him, I adjure thee by the living God, that thou tell us if thou art the Christ, the Son of God.
26.65: Then the high priest tore his robes, saying, He blasphemed: why have we yet need of witnesses? behold, now you heard His blasphemy:
26.66: what seems to you? They responding said, He is worthy of death.
26.67: They spat in His face, and buffeted Him: and they slapped Him,
26.68: saying, Prophesy unto us, who is the one smiting thee?
26.69: And Peter was sitting without in the court. And a certain maidservant came to him, saying, Truly, thou wast with Jesus the Galilean.
26.70: And he denied before all, I know not what you say.
26.71: And another maidservant saw him, having come to the gate, and says to them there, This man was with Jesus the Nazarene.
26.72: And again he denied with an oath, I know not the man.
26.73: And after a little the bystanders coming to Peter, said, Truly, thou art also one of them, for indeed thy speech betrays thee.
26.74: Then he began to anathematize and to swear, I know not the man. And immediately the cock crew.

27.1: And it being morning, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to put Him to death.
27.2: And having bound Him, took Him away, and delivered Him to Pontius Pilate, the governor.
27.3: Then Judas, the one having betrayed Him, seeing that He was condemned, being seized with remorse, returned the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
27.4: saying, I sinned betraying the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? See thou to it.
27.5: And throwing down the money in the temple, he departed; and having gone away hung himself.
27.6: And the chief priests, taking the pieces of silver, said, It is not lawful to put them in the treasury, because it is the price of blood.
27.7: And taking counsel, they purchased with them the field of the potter, for a burying place for strangers.
27.8: Therefore that field has been called, The field of blood, to this day.
27.9: Then the word having been spoken by Jeremiah the prophet, was fulfilled, saying, And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of Him that was valued, whom they of the sons of Israel did value;
27.10: and they gave them for the field of the potter, as the Lord appointed me.
27.12: And while He is accused by the chief priests and elders, He responded nothing.
27.14: And He responded to him not one word, so that the governor marveled exceedingly.
27.15: And the governor during the feast was accustomed to release to the multitude one prisoner, whom they wished.
27.16: But they had at that time a noted prisoner called Barabbas.
27.17: Then they being assembled, Pilate said to them, Whom do you wish that I may release unto you? Barabbas? or Jesus who is called Christ?
27.18: For he knew that they delivered Him on account of envy.
27.19: And he sitting on his tribunal, his wife sent to him, saying, Let there be nothing to thee and that just man: for this day I suffered many things in a dream on account of Him.
27.20: And the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitudes that they should ask Barabbas, and destroy Jesus.
27.24: And Pilate seeing that he profits nothing, but rather an uproar supervenes, having taken water, washed his hands in the presence of the multitude, saying, For I am free from the blood of this just one: you shall see to it.
27.25: And all the people responding said, His blood be upon us, and upon our children.
27.26: Then he released unto them Barabbas. And having scourged Jesus, delivered Him up that He should be crucified.
27.27: Then the soldiers of the governor taking Jesus into the judgment hall, gathered to Him the whole band.
27.28: And having divested Him, put on Him a scarlet robe:
27.29: and plaiting a crown of thorns put it on His head, and a reed in His right hand; and bowing the knee to Him, continued to mock Him, saying, Hail, King of the Jews!
27.30: And spitting on Him, they took the reed and struck Him on the head repeatedly.
27.31: And when they mocked Him, divesting Him of the robe, they put on Him His own raiment, and led Him away to crucify Him.
27.32: And going out they found a Cyrenean man, Simon by name: they compelled him that he should bear His cross.
27.33: Having come to the place called Golgotha, which is called the place of a skull.
27.34: And they gave Him vinegar mingled with gall to drink: and tasting, He was not willing to drink it.
27.35: And crucifying Him, they divided His garments, casting the lot,
27.36: and sitting down, they continued to watch Him there.
27.37: And they placed over His head, His accusation written, THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
27.38: Then two thieves are crucified along with Him, the one on the right and one on the left.
27.39: And going by they continued to blaspheme Him, wagging their heads,
27.40: and saying, Thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in three days, save thyself: if thou art the Son of God, come down from the cross.
27.41: Likewise also the chief priests mocking, with the scribes and elders, continued to say,
27.42: He saved others; He is not able to save Himself: if He is the King of Israel, let Him now come down from the cross, and we will believe on Him.
27.43: He trusted in God; let Him now deliver Him, if He wishes Him; for He said, I am the Son of God.
27.44: And the thieves being crucified along with Him were also reproaching Him in the same manner.
27.45: And from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.
27.47: And certain ones of those standing there hearing, said, He is calling Elijah.
27.48: And one of them running and taking a sponge, and filling it with vinegar, and extending it on a reed, gave Him drink.
27.49: And others were saying, Let Him alone; let us see if Elijah comes about to save Him.
27.50: And Jesus again crying with a loud voice, gave up His spirit.
27.51: And behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from top to bottom, and the earth did quake; and the rocks were rent;
27.52: and the tombs were opened; and many bodies of the sleeping saints arose;
27.53: and having come out of the tombs after His resurrection came into the holy city and appeared unto many.
27.54: And the centurion and those watching Jesus with him, seeing the earthquake, and the things which took place, feared exceedingly, saying, Surely this was the Son of God.
27.55: And many women were there looking on from a distance, who followed Jesus from Galilee to minister unto Him,
27.56: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary, the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
27.57: And it being evening, a rich man came from Arimathea, whose name was Joseph, who himself also was a disciple to Jesus.
27.58: He having come to Pilate, begged the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded that the body should be given:
27.59: and Joseph having received the body, wrapped it in clean linen,
27.60: and placed it in a new sepulcher, which he hewed in the rock: and having rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulcher, departed.
27.61: And Mary Magdalene was there, and the other Mary, sitting in front of the tomb.
27.62: And on the following day, which is after the Preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees came together to Pilate, saying,
27.64: Command therefore that the tomb be made safe until the third day, lest His disciples having come, may steal Him away, and say to the people, He is risen from the dead: and the last error shall be worse than the first.
27.65: Pilate said to them, You have a watch: go, make it safe as you know.
27.66: And having gone, they secured the tomb, sealing the stone, with the guard.

28.1: And late on the Sabbath-day, on the dawn toward the first of the Sabbaths, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the sepulcher.
28.2: And behold, there was a great earthquake; for an angel descending from heaven, having come rolled away the stone from the door, and sat upon it.
28.3: And his countenance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow.
28.4: And from fear of him the keepers did quake, and they became like dead men.
28.6: He is not here; for He is risen, as He said. Come, see the place where the Lord lay.
28.7: And going quickly, tell His disciples, that He is risen from the dead; and behold, He goes before you into Galilee; and there you shall see Him; lo, I have told you.
28.8: And having come out quickly from the sepulcher with fear and great joy, they were running to tell His disciples.
28.9: And behold, Jesus met them, saying, Hail. And they having come forward, took hold of His feet, and worshiped Him.
28.11: And they going, behold, certain ones of the watch having come into the city, proclaimed to the chief priests all things which had taken place.
28.12: And being assembled along with the elders, and taking counsel, they gave much money to the soldiers,
28.13: saying, You tell, that His disciples, having come by night, stole Him away while we slept.
28.14: And if this may be heard by the governor, we will persuade him and make you secure.
28.15: And they having received the money, did as they were instructed: and this report is current among the Jews until this day.
28.16: And the eleven disciples went away into Galilee into the mountain where Jesus commanded them:
28.17: and seeing Him, they worshiped Him: but some doubted.
28.19: Going, disciple all nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost:
28.20: teaching them to observe all things which I commanded you. And lo, I am with you all the days, unto the end of the age.

1.1: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
1.2: As has been written in the prophets; Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, who will prepare thy way before thee;
1.3: the voice of one roaring in the wilderness; Prepare ye the way of the Lord; make His paths straight.
1.4: John the Baptist came preaching in the wilderness the baptism of repentance unto the remission of sins.
1.5: And all the Judean country and the Jerusalemites were going out unto him, and were being baptized by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins.
1.6: And John was clothed with camel's hair and a leathern girdle about his loins, and eating locusts and wild honey;
1.8: and He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost.
1.9: And it came to pass in those days, Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee, and was baptized by John in the Jordan.
1.10: And coming up straightway from the water, He saw the heavens open and the Spirit like a dove descending on Him.
1.11: And there was a voice from the heavens: Thou art my beloved Son, in whom I delight.
1.12: And immediately the Spirit casts Him out into the wilderness.
1.13: And he was in the wilderness forty days being tempted by Satan, and was with the wild beasts; and the angels continued to minister unto Him.
1.14: After that John was cast into prison, Jesus came into Galilee preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God,
1.15: and saying, That the time is fulfilled: the kingdom of God is at hand: repent, and believe the gospel.
1.16: And walking by the sea of Galilee, He saw Simon and Andrew his brother casting their net in the sea: for they were fishers.
1.18: And immediately, having left their nets, they followed Him.
1.19: And going forth thence a little, He saw James, the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, themselves also in a ship mending their nets,
1.20: and immediately He called them. And having left their father Zebedee in the ship with the hired hands, they departed after Him.
1.21: And they come into Capernaum; and immediately on the Sabbath, He was teaching in the synagogue.
1.22: And they were astonished at His teaching; for Ile was teaching them as one having authority, and not as the scribes.
1.23: And there was a man in their synagogue with an unclean spirit; and he cried out,
1.24: saying, Let me alone; what is there to us and thee, thou Jesus, the Nazarene? You have come to destroy us; I know thee who thou art, the Holy One of God.
1.26: And the unclean spirit, convulsing him and crying with a great voice, came out from him.
1.27: And they were all astonished, so that they were inquiring one to another, saying, What is this? what new teaching is this? Because according to authority He commands the unclean spirits, and they obey Him;
1.28: and His fame went out immediately into all the surrounding country of Galilee.
1.29: And immediately, having come out from the synagogue, they came into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
1.30: And the mother-in-law of Simon was lying down burning with fever; and immediately they speak to Him concerning her:
1.31: And having come to her, taking her by the hand, He raised her up; and immediately the fever left her, and she continued to minister unto them.
1.32: And it being evening, when the sun went down, they were carrying to Him all the sick and demonized;
1.33: and the whole city was gathered to the door.
1.34: And He healed many who were afflicted with various diseases, and He cast out many demons; and did not suffer the demons to speak, because they knew Him.
1.35: And in the morning, exceedingly early, while it was yet night, having arisen up He came out, and went away into a desert place, and was praying there.
1.36: And Simon and those who were with him followed Him.
1.38: And He says to them, Let us go into the surrounding villages and cities, that I may preach there; for unto this I have come out.
1.39: And He was preaching in their synagogues in all Galilee, and casting out the demons.
1.40: And a leper comes to Him, entreating Him, and bowing the knee to Him, and saying to Him, That if thou mayest be willing, thou art able to cleanse me.
1.42: And He speaking, immediately the leprosy departed from him, and he was cleansed.
1.43: And charging him, He immediately sent him away,
1.44: and says to him, See that you may speak nothing to any one: but go, show thyself unto the priest, and offer for thy cleansing those things which Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.
1.45: And he having gone out, began to proclaim many things, and to publish abroad the word, so that He was no longer able openly to come into the city, but was out in desert places: and they continued to come to Him from all directions.

2.1: And again He having come into Capernaum during those days; and it was heard that He was in the house.
2.2: And immediately many were assembled together, so that there was no room, even at the door; and He was speaking the word to them.
2.3: And they come to Him, carrying a paralytic, borne by four.
2.4: And not being able to come near Him on account of the crowd, they opened the roof where He was: and having lifted it up, they let down the bed on which the paralytic was lying.
2.5: And Jesus seeing their faith says to the paralytic, Child, thy sins are forgiven thee.
2.6: And certain ones of the scribes were sitting there, and reasoning in their hearts,
2.7: Why does He speak blasphemies? Who is able to forgive sins, except the one God?
2.8: And Jesus immediately knowing in His spirit that they are thus reasoning among themselves, said to them, Why do you thus reason in your hearts?
2.9: Which is easier, to say to the paralytic, Thy sins are forgiven; or to say, Arise, and take thy bed, and walk about?
2.10: But in order that you may know that the Son of man has power on earth to forgive sins
2.11: (He says to the paralytic), I say unto thee, Arise, take thy bed, and go into thy house.
2.12: And he arose immediately, and having taken the bed, went out before them all. So that all were astonished, and glorified God, saying, Never have we seen it after this sort.
2.13: And He came out again by the sea; and the whole multitude came to Him, and He was teaching them.
2.15: And it came to pass, while He was sitting at the table in his house, and many publicans and sinners were sitting along with Jesus and his disciples: for they were many, and they followed Him.
2.16: And the scribes and Pharisees, seeing Him eating with the publicans and sinners, were saying to His disciples, Why does He eat and drink with publicans and sinners?
2.17: Jesus hearing, says to them, They that are whole have no need of a physician, but they that are sick. I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
2.18: The disciples of John and the Pharisees were fasting. And they come and say to Him; Wherefore do the disciples of John and the Pharisees fast, and thy disciples do not fast?
2.19: And Jesus said to them, Whether are the sons of the bride-chamber able to fast while the bridegroom is with them? So long a time as they have with them the bridegroom they are not able to fast.
2.20: But the days will come, when the bridegroom must be taken from them, and then they will fast in that day.
2.21: No one putteth a piece of new cloth on an old garment: lest the new take its fullness from the old, and the rent is made worse.
2.22: No one puts new wine in old bottles: lest the new wine shall break the bottles, and the wine is poured out, and the bottles shall perish: but the new wine is put in new bottles.
2.23: And it came to pass, that He was traveling through the corn-fields on the Sabbath-day; and His disciples began to make the journey plucking the ears.
2.24: And the Pharisees continued to say to Him, Behold what they are doing on the Sabbath, which is not lawful.
2.25: And He said to them, Have ye not read what David did, when he had need, and was hungry, and those with him?
2.26: How he entered into the house of God, in the days of Abiathar, the high priest, and did eat the shewbread, which is not lawful to eat except for the priest, and he gave it to those being with him?
2.27: And He said to them, The Sabbath was made for the sake of man, and not man for the sake of the Sabbath.
2.28: So the Son of man is also Lord of the Sabbath.

3.1: He came again into the synagogue, a man was there having a withered hand.
3.2: And they were watching Him, if He will heal him on the Sabbath, that they might accuse Him.
3.3: And He says to the man having a withered hand; Rise up in the midst.
3.4: And He says to them; Is it lawful to do good or to do evil on the Sabbath; to save life, or to kill? And they were silent.
3.5: And looking round on them with indignation, being grieved over the hardness of their hearts, He says to the man; Reach forth thy hand. And he reached it forth and it was restored.
3.6: And the Pharisees, having gone out immediately along with the Herodians, took counsel against Him in order that they might kill Him.
3.7: And Jesus departed with His disciples to the sea: and a great multitude followed Him from Galilee, and from Judea,
3.8: and from Jerusalem, and from Idumea, and from beyond the Jordan, and those about Tyre and Sidon, a great multitude, hearing so many things that He was doing, came to Him.
3.9: And He said to His disciples, that a little boat should wait on Him in order that they may not tread on Him.
3.10: For He healed many; so that they were falling before Him so that they might touch Him, so many as had diseases.
3.11: And unclean spirits, when they saw Him, fell down before Him, and were crying out, saying, Thou art the Son of God.
3.12: And He charged them much that they should not make Him known.
3.13: And He goes up into the mountain, and calls whom He wished: and they went away to Him.
3.14: And He made twelve (apostles) that they may be with Him and that He may send them out to preach,
3.15: and to have power to heal diseases, and to cast out the demons.
3.16: And He placed the name Peter on Simon;
3.17: and James the son of Zebedee, and John the brother of James; and on them He placed the names Boanerges, which is, Sons of thunder:
3.18: and Andrew and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alpheus, and Thaddeus, and Simon the Zealot, and Judas Iscariot,
3.20: And He comes into a house; and the multitude come together again so they are not able to eat bread.
3.21: And those along with Him hearing came out to arrest Him: for they continued to say, He is beside Himself.
3.22: And the scribes having come down from Jerusalem were saving, He has Beelzebul and He is casting out the demons through the prince of the demons.
3.23: And calling them to Him, He continued to speak to them in parables, How is Satan able to cast out Satan?
3.24: And if a kingdom may be divided against itself, that kingdom is not able to stand,
3.25: and if a house may be divided against itself, that house will not be able to stand;
3.26: and if Satan stand up against himself, and is divided, he is not able to stand, but has an end.
3.27: No one is able, having entered into the house of a strong man, to spoil his goods, unless he may first bind the strong man, and then he will spoil his house.
3.28: Truly I say unto you, that all sins shall be forgiven unto the sons of men, and blasphemies whatsoever they may blaspheme:
3.29: but whosoever may blaspheme against the Holy Ghost hath never forgiveness, but is subject of eternal condemnation.
3.30: Because they were saying, He has an unclean spirit.
3.31: And His mother and His brothers come; and standing without, sent to Him, calling Him.
3.32: And the crowd was sitting round Him; and they say to Him, Behold thy mother and thy brothers without are seeking thee.
3.33: And He responding to them, says, Who is my mother and my brothers?
3.34: And looking round on His disciples sitting about Him in a circle, He says, Behold my mother and my brothers!
3.35: For whosoever may do the will of God, the same is my brother, and my sister, and my mother.

4.1: And again He began to teach by the sea: and a great multitude is gathered unto Him, so that He having gone into a ship, sat on the sea; and the whole multitude was at the sea on the land.
4.2: And He was teaching them many things in parables, and in His teaching He said to them,
4.3: Hear: Behold, a sower went out to sow:
4.4: and it came to pass while he was sowing, some fell by the wayside, and the fowls came and devoured it.
4.5: And other fell upon stones, where it had not much earth; and immediately it sprang up, because it had no depth of earth:
4.6: and when the sun arose, it was scorched; and because it had no root, it withered away.
4.7: And other fell among thorns, and the thorns sprang up, and choked it, and it gave no fruit.
4.8: And other fell in good ground, and springing up and growing, gave fruit, and produced, one thirty, and one sixty, and one a hundred.
4.9: And He said, Let the one having ears to hear, hear.
4.10: And when they were alone, and those around Him along with the twelve asked Him the parable.
4.11: And He said to them, To you it has been given the mystery of the kingdom of God: but to them who are without, all things are in parables:
4.12: in order that seeing they may see, and not know; and hearing they may hear, and not understand; lest they may turn, and their sins may he forgiven unto them.
4.15: And those who are by the way-side, where the word is sown; and when they hear it, immediately Satan comes, and takes away the word which was sown in their hearts.
4.16: And those who are sowed upon the rocks are likewise, those who, when they may hear the word, immediately with joy receive it.
4.17: And they have no root in themselves, but are temporary; then tribulation or persecution arising on account of the word, they are immediately offended:
4.18: and others are those who are sown among the thorns; they are those hearing the word,
4.19: and the cares of the age, and the deceitfulness of riches, and desires concerning other things coming into them, choke out the word, and it becomes unfruitful.
4.20: And these are they who are sown on good ground; whosoever hear the word, and receive it, and bring forth fruit, some thirty, some sixty, and some a hundred.
4.22: For there is nothing hidden which may not be made manifest; neither is there any thing concealed, but that it may come into the light.
4.23: If any one has ears to hear, let him hear.
4.24: And He said to them. See what you hear: with what measure you measure it shall be measured unto you: and it shall be added unto you who hear.
4.25: For whosoever has, it shall be given unto him: and he who has not, it shall be taken from him even that which he has.
4.26: And He said, Thus is the kingdom of God, as a man may cast seed on the ground;
4.27: and he may sleep, and rise night and day, and the seed germinates and grows, as he does not know.
4.28: The earth spontaneously brings forth fruit; first the blade, then the ear, then the full corn in the ear.
4.29: And when the fruit may develop, immediately he thrusts in the sickle, because the harvest is at hand.
4.30: And He said, To what may we liken the kingdom of God? or in what parable may we present it?
4.31: Tis like a grain of mustard seed, which when it may be sown upon the earth, is the smallest of all seeds which are upon the earth,
4.32: and when it may be sowed, it springs up, and becomes the greatest of herbs, and produces great branches; so that the birds of the heavens are able to lodge under its shadow.
4.33: And in many such parables He continued to speak the word to them, as they were able to hear.
4.34: And without a parable He did not speak to them: and He privately expounded all things to His disciples.
4.35: And He says to them, on that day, it being evening, Let us go away to the other side.
4.36: And leaving the multitude, they receive Him, as He was in the ship; and other ships were also with Him.
4.37: And there was a great storm of wind: and the waves were dashing into the ship, so that it was already filled.
4.38: And He was in the stern, sleeping on a pillow: and they awaken Him, and say to Him; Teacher, is there no care to thee that we perish?
4.39: And being awakened, He said to the sea, Be calm, be quiet. And the wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
4.40: And He said to them, Why are you so cowardly? how have you not faith?
4.41: And they feared with a great fear, and continued to say to one another, Who then is this, because the wind and the sea obey Him?

5.1: And they came beyond the sea, into the country of the Gadarenes,
5.2: And a man from the tombs, with an unclean spirit met Him, having come out of the ship;
5.3: who had his dwelling among the tombs: neither was any one able to bind him with chains;
5.4: because frequently he had been bound with fetters and chains, and the chains were slipped off by him, and the fetters torn to pieces.
5.5: No one was able to tame him: and all the time, night and day, he was among the tombs in the mountains, crying, and cutting himself with stones.
5.6: And seeing Jesus a great way off, he ran to Him, and worshiped Him;
5.7: and crying with a loud voice, he says, What is there to me and to thee, O Jesus, thou Son of the Most High God? I adjure thee in the name of God, that you may not torment me.
5.10: And he continued to intreat Him much, that He would not send them out of the country.
5.11: And there was a great herd of swine feeding in the mountain.
5.12: And they intreated Him, saying, Send us into the swine, in order that we may go into them.
5.13: And Jesus immediately permitted them. And the unclean spirits having gone out, came into the swine: and the herd rushed down a precipice into the sea, and there were about two thousand: and they were strangled in the sea.
5.14: And those herding them fled, and reported in the city, and in the country. And they came out to see what it was that came to pass.
5.15: And they come to Jesus, and see the demonized man sitting down, both clothed and in his right mind, the one called Legion; and they were afraid.
5.16: And those seeing, related to them how it happened to the demonized man and concerning the swine.
5.17: And they began to intreat Him to depart from their coasts.
5.18: And He having come to the ship, the demonized man intreated Him that he should be with Him.
5.19: And He did not permit him, but says to him, Go to thine own house to thy people, and proclaim to them how many things the Lord has done for thee, and had mercy on thee.
5.20: And he went away, and began to preach in Decapolis, how many things Jesus did to him. And all were astonished.
5.21: And Jesus crossing over in the ship again to the other side, a great multitude was gathered unto Him; and He was by the sea.
5.22: And one of the chief rulers of the synagogue, by name jairus, comes; and seeing Him falls at His feet,
5.23: and intreats Him much saying, My little daughter is at the point of death: that coming He may lay hands on her, in order that she may be saved and live.
5.24: And He departed with him; and a great multitude followed Him, even treading on Him.
5.25: And a certain woman, being in an issue of blood twelve years,
5.26: and having suffered much from many physicians, and expended all things which were with her, and being profited as to nothing, but rather having come to the worse,
5.27: hearing concerning Jesus, having come in the crowd behind, touched His garment.
5.28: For she was saying, If I may touch His garment, I shall be saved.
5.29: And immediately the issue of her blood was dried up: and she knew in her body that she is healed of her plague.
5.30: And immediately Jesus, knowing in Himself that the powerhas gone out from Him, turning in the crowd, said, Who touched my garments?
5.31: And His disciples continued to say to Him, You see the crowd treading upon you, and you say, Who touched me?
5.32: And He looked round to see her who did it.
5.33: And the woman fearing and trembling, knowing what has taken place unto herself, came and fell down before Him, and told Him the whole truth.
5.35: And He still speaking, they come from the house of the chief ruler of the synagogue, saying, Thy daughter is dead: why do you still trouble the Teacher?
5.37: and He did not permit any one to accompany Him, except Peter, and James, and John the brother of James.
5.38: And He comes into the house of the chief ruler of the synagogue; And He sees a tumult, weeping and wailing much;
5.39: and having come in, He says to them, Why are you excited and weeping? The child is not dead, but sleepeth.
5.40: And they hooted at Him. And putting them all out, He takes the father and mother of the child and those with Him, and goes in where the child was.
5.41: And taking the child by the hand, says to her, Talitha cumi; which is interpreted, Damsel, I say unto thee, Arise.
5.42: And immediately the damsel stood up, and walked about; for she was twelve years old. And they were immediately delighted with great delight.
5.43: And He charged them much that no one should know it; and He said that something should be given to her to eat.

6.1: And He came out thence and comes into His own country; and His disciples follow Him:
6.2: and it being the Sabbath day, He began to preach in the synagogue: and many hearing were astonished, saying, Whence are these things to this one? and, What wisdom is given unto Him? Such miracles are wrought by His hands.
6.3: Is not this the carpenter, the son of Mary? the brother of James, and Joses, and Simon, and Judas? Are not His sisters here with us? And they were offended in Him.
6.5: And He was not able to do any miracle there, except laying hands on a few sick people, He healed them.
6.6: And He was astonished on account of their unbelief. And He went about the villages in a circuit teaching.
6.7: And He calls the twelve to Him, and began to send them out two by two; and He gave them authority over unclean spirits.
6.8: And He commanded them that they should take nothing for the way except staff only; no valise, no bread, no money in the girdle;
6.9: but having put on your sandals: and put not on two coats.
6.10: And He said to them, Into whatsoever house you may enter, there abide until you may go out from thence.
6.11: And whatsoever place may not receive you nor hear you, going forth thence, shake off the dust which is beneath your feet for a testimony unto them.
6.12: And having gone out they preached that they must repent;
6.13: and they cast out many demons; and anointed many sick with oil, and healed them.
6.14: And king Herod heard; for His name became known: and said, John the Baptist is risen from the dead, and therefore mighty works are wrought in Him.
6.15: And others continued to say, That He is Elijah; and others continued to say that He is a prophet, indeed one of the prophets.
6.16: But Herod hearing said, That, He is John, whom I beheaded; He is risen from the dead.
6.17: For Herod himself having sent, arrested John, and bound him in prison on account of Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip: because he married her.
6.18: For John said to Herod, It is not lawful for thee to have the wife of thy brother.
6.19: And Herodias hated him, and wished to kill him; and was not able;
6.20: for Herod was afraid of John, knowing him to be a just and holy man, and he continued to hold him in prison: and hearing him, he continued to do many things, and he was hearing him gladly.
6.21: And it being a high day, when Herod on his birthday made a feast to his mighty men, and chiliarchs, and the first men of Galilee;
6.23: And he promised her, I will give you whatsoever you may ask, even unto the half of my kingdom.
6.24: And having gone out, she said to her mother, What shall I ask And she said, The head of John the Baptist.
6.25: And she having come in to the king, immediately with haste asked him, saying; I wish, that you may give to me immediately, the head of John the Baptist in a charger.
6.26: And the king being grieved exceedingly; on account of his oaths, and those sitting with him, was not willing to reject her.
6.27: And the king immediately sending forth a soldier of his guard, commanded that his head should be brought.
6.28: And having departed, he beheaded him in prison: and brought his head in a charger, and gave it to the damsel, and the damsel gave it to her mother.
6.29: And his disciples having heard, came and took his body, and put it in a sepulcher.
6.30: The apostles return to Jesus, and related unto Him all things, even so many as they did, and so many as they taught.
6.32: And they came away into a desert place privately in a ship.
6.33: And the multitudes saw them going, and many recognized them, and they ran together thither on foot from many cities, and came before them and came together to Him.
6.34: And Jesus having come out saw a great multitude, and was moved with compassion in their behalf, because they were as sheep having no shepherd: and He began to teach them many things.
6.35: And already the hour being late, His disciples coming to Him, say, That it is a desert place, and the hour is already late:
6.36: send them away, that having gone into the surrounding country and the villages, they may purchase for themselves bread: for they have not what they may eat.
6.37: And responding He said to them, You give to them to eat. And they say to Him, Having gone away must we purchase the loaves of two hundred denaria, and give them to eat?
6.39: And He commanded them all to sit down in companies on the green grass.
6.40: And they sat down in ranks, about one hundred, and about fifty.
6.41: And taking the five loaves and the two fishes, looking up to heaven, He blessed them; and broke the loaves, and gave them to His disciples, that they should dispense to them; and He divided the two fishes among all.
6.42: And they all ate, and were filled;
6.43: and they took up the fragments, twelve baskets full, and from the fishes.
6.44: And those eating the bread were five thousand men.
6.45: And immediately He constrained His disciples to embark into the ship, and go before Him to the other side to Bethsaida, until He shall send away the multitude.
6.46: And having dismissed them, He went away into the mountain to pray.
6.47: And it being evening, the ship was in the middle of the sea; and He was alone upon the land.
6.48: And He seeing them toiling in rowing; for the wind was contrary to them, and about the fourth watch of the night He comes to them, walking on the sea; and He wished to pass by them.
6.49: But they, seeing Him walking on the sea, thought it was a specter, and cried out.
6.50: For they all saw Him, and were alarmed. And immediately He spoke with them, and says to them, Be of good cheer; I am He; be not afraid.
6.51: And He went up to them into the ship; and the wind ceased. And they were exceedingly much astonished among themselves, and continued to marvel.
6.52: For they did not understand concerning the loaves, for their heart was hardened.
6.53: And having crossed over, they came to the land of Gennesaret; and they disembarked.
6.54: And they having come out from the ship, immediately recognizing Him,
6.55: they were running round all that country, and they began to carry the sick on beds, when they heard that He is there.
6.56: And when He departed into the villages, or cities, or countries, they placed the sick in the forums, and call upon Him, and continued to intreat Him that they should touch the hem of His garment: and so many as touched Him were saved.

7.1: And the Pharisees and certain ones of the scribes, having come from Jerusalem, gather to Him.
7.2: And seeing certain ones of His disciples eating bread with defiled, that is, unwashed hands.
7.3: For the Pharisees and all the Jews, unless they diligently wash their hands, do not eat, holding the tradition of the elders.
7.4: And from the forum, unless they may baptize themselves, they do not eat: and many other things which they have received to hold, the baptism of cups, and pots, and brazen vessels, and couches.
7.5: Then the Pharisees and scribes asked Him, Wherefore do not thy disciples walk according to the tradition of the elders: but they eat bread with unwashed hands?
7.6: And responding He said to them, Beautifully did Isaiah prophesy concerning you hypocrites, as has been written, This people honor me with lips, but their heart is far from me.
7.7: In vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.
7.8: For having left the commandment of God, you are holding the tradition of men.
7.9: And He said to them, Truly, you make void the commandment of God, that you may hold your own tradition.
7.11: But you say, If a man may say to father or mother, Corban, that is a gift, whatsoever you may be profited by me;
7.12: and you no longer permit him to do anything for his father or mother;
7.13: making void the word of God by your tradition, which you have given: and you do many such similar things.
7.14: And calling the crowd to Him again, He said to them, Hear all ye, and understand.
7.15: There is nothing without a man coming into him, which is competent to defile him: but those things coming out from him, these are the things which defile the man.
7.16: If any one has ears to hear, let him hear.
7.17: And when He came from the multitude into the house, His disciples asked Him the parable.
7.19: Because it does not go into his heart, but into his stomach, and is cast out into the excrement, purifying all edibles.
7.20: And He said, Everything proceeding out from the man, that defiles the man.
7.21: For within, out of the heart of men, proceed evil reasonings, adulteries, fornications, murders,
7.22: thefts, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, impurity, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, folly.
7.23: All these evils proceed out from within, and defile the man.
7.24: And rising up, He departed thence into the regions of Tyre and Sidon. And having entered into a house, and He wished no one to know it: and He was not able to be hidden.
7.25: For a woman hearing concerning Him, whose daughter had an unclean spirit, having come worshiped at His feet.
7.26: For the woman was a Greek, a Syrophenician by race; and asked Him that He may cast the demon out of her daughter.
7.28: And she responded and says to Him, Yea, Lord: for even the little dogs eat the crumbs of the children under the table.
7.30: And having come into her house, she found the demon gone out, and the daughter lying on the bed.
7.31: And having again come out from Tyre and Sidon, He came to the Sea of Galilee, amid the coasts of Decapolis.
7.32: And they bring Him a deaf man, speaking with difficulty; and intreat Him that He may lay His hand on him.
7.33: And taking him from the crowd privately, He put His fingers in his ears, and having spat, He touched his tongue;
7.35: And immediately his ears were opened, and the bond of his tongue loosed, and he continued to speak distinctly.
7.36: And He charged them that they should tell no one: and the more He charged them, the more abundantly they proclaimed it.
7.37: And were astonished exceedingly, saying, He has done all things well: He makes the deaf to hear, and the dumb to speak.

8.1: In those days, the multitude being large, and having nothing which they may eat, Jesus calling His disciples, says to them,
8.2: I sympathize with the multitude because three days already abide unto me, and they have nothing which they may eat.
8.3: If I shall send them away to their homes fasting, they will faint on the road; indeed some of them have come from afar.
8.4: And His disciples responded, Whence shall any one be able to feed these with bread in the desert?
8.5: And He asked them, How much bread have you? And they said, Seven loaves.
8.6: He commanded the multitude to sit down on the ground; and taking the seven loaves, giving thanks, He broke, and gave them to His disciples, that they may dispense them; and they presented them to the multitude.
8.7: And they had a few fishes: and blessing them, He delivered them.
8.8: And they ate, and were filled: and they took up the residue of the fragments, seven baskets.
8.9: And those eating were about four thousand. And He sent them away.
8.10: And immediately having gone into the ship with His disciples, He came to the parts of Dalmanutha.
8.11: And the Pharisees came out, and began to question Him, seeking from Him a sign from heaven, tempting Him.
8.12: And groaning in spirit, He says, What sign does this generation seek after? truly I say unto you, No sign shall be given unto this generation.
8.13: And having left them, coming in again He departed to the other side.
8.14: And they forgot to take bread; and had but one loaf with them in the ship.
8.15: And He commanded them, saying, See, beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, and of the leaven of Herod.
8.16: And they were reasoning to one another, saying, It is because we have not bread.
8.17: And Jesus knowing says to them, Why do you reason because you have not bread? do you not yet know, nor understand? have you your heart still hardened?
8.18: Having eyes, do you not see? having ears, do you not hear? and do you not remember?
8.19: When I broke the five loaves to the five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you take up? They say to Him, Twelve.
8.20: And when the seven loaves to the four thousand, how many baskets full of fragments did you take up? And they said, Seven.
8.22: And they come into Bethsaida: and they bring Him a blind man, and they intreat Him that He may touch him.
8.24: And looking up he said, I see the men walking about like trees.
8.25: Then again He put His hands on his eyes, and he looked up; and was restored, and saw all things distinctly.
8.27: And Jesus and His disciples went away into the villages of Caesarea Philippi; and on the way He asked His disciples, saying to them, Whom do the people say that I am?
8.28: And they answered Him saying, John the Baptist: and others, Elijah; and others, One of the prophets.
8.30: And He charged them that they should speak to no one concerning Him.
8.31: And He began to teach them, that it behooves the Son of man to suffer many things, and to be rejected by the elders, and the chief priests and the scribes, and to be killed, and after three days to rise.
8.32: And He was boldly speaking the word. And Peter taking Him to him began to rebuke Him.
8.33: And He turning and seeing His disciples rebuked Peter, and says, Get behind me, adversary: because thou art not thinking the things of God, but those of men.
8.34: And calling the multitude to Him with His disciples, He said to them, Whosoever wishes to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
8.35: For whosoever may wish to save his soul shall lose it; and whosoever shall lose his soul for my sake and that of the gospel shall save it.
8.36: For what shall it profit a man to gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?
8.37: For what would a man give in exchange for his soul?
8.38: For whosoever may be ashamed of me and my words in this adulterous and wicked generation, the Son of man shall also be ashamed of him, when He may come in the glory of His Father with the holy angels.

9.1: And He said to them, Truly I say unto you, that there are certain ones of those standing here, who may not taste of death, until they may see the kingdom of God, having come with power.
9.2: After six days Jesus takes Peter, and John, and James, and carries them up into an exceedingly high mountain privately alone; and was transfigured before them:
9.3: and His raiment became resplendent, exceedingly white like snow; as no fuller on earth is able to whiten.
9.4: And Elijah was seen by them with Moses: and they were talking with Jesus.
9.5: And Peter responding says to Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here: and let us make three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elijah:
9.6: for he did not know what he might say; for they were afraid.
9.7: And there was a cloud overshadowing them: and a voice came out of the cloud, saying, This is my beloved Son: hear ye Him.
9.8: And immediately looking around, they saw no one, but Jesus only with them.
9.9: And they coming down from the mountain, He charged them, that they should relate to no one the things which they saw, until the Son of man may rise from the dead.
9.10: And they held the word to themselves, inquiring, what it is to rise from the dead.
9.11: And they asked Him, saying, that the scribes say, that it behooves Elijah first to come.
9.13: But I say unto you, that Elijah indeed has come, and they did unto him so many things as they wished, as has been written in reference to him.
9.14: And having come to the disciples, He saw a great multitude around them and the scribes disputing with them!
9.15: And immediately the whole multitude, seeing Him, became excited, and running to Him, seized Him; and He asked the scribes,
9.16: Why are you disputing with them?
9.17: And one responding from the multitude, said, Teacher, I have brought my son to thee, having a dumb spirit.
9.18: And when he may take him, he lacerates him: and he froths, and gnashes his teeth, and pines away. And I said to thy disciples, that they should cast him out; and they were not able.
9.19: And He responding to them, says, O faithless generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I bear with you? Bring him hither to me.
9.20: And they brought him to Him; and seeing Him, immediately the spirit convulsed him; and falling on the ground, he continued to wallow, foaming.
9.22: and frequently he cast him into the fire and into the waters, in order that he may destroy him: but if you are able to do anything, assist us, being moved with compassion towards us.
9.23: And Jesus said to him, It is this, if you are able (to believe); all things are possible to him that believeth.
9.24: And immediately the father of the child crying out with tears, continued to say, I believe; assist thou my unbelief.
9.25: And Jesus seeing that the multitude are running together, rebuked the unclean spirit, saying to him, Dumb and deaf spirit, I command thee, come out from him, and enter no more into him.
9.26: And crying out, and convulsing he came out. And he became like a corpse; so that many said, that, he is dead.
9.27: And Jesus, taking him by the hand, lifted him up; and he stood up.
9.28: And His disciples asked I Iim privately, having come into the house, Why were we not able to cast him out?
9.29: And He said unto them, This kind is able to come out by nothing, but by prayer.
9.30: And they coming out thence, traveled through Galilee; and He was not willing that any one should know it.
9.31: For He was teaching His disciples, and saying to them, The Son of man is betrayed into the hands of men, and they will kill Him; and having been killed, He will rise again the third day.
9.32: And they did not understand the word, and they were afraid to ask Him.
9.33: And He came into Capernaum. And He being in the house asked them, What were you disputing about to one another in the way?
9.34: And they were silent: for they were disputing to one another in the way, who was the greater.
9.35: And sitting down, He called the twelve; and says to them, If any one wishes to be first, he shall be last of all, and servant of all.
9.36: And taking a little child, He placed it in their midst; and taking it up in His arms, He said to them,
9.37: Whosoever may receive one of such little children in my name, receives me: and whosoever may receive me, receives not me, but Him that sent me.
9.38: And John responded to Him saying, Teacher, we saw one casting out demons in Thy name, who does not follow us; and we forbade him, because he does not follow us.
9.40: For whosoever is not against us, is on our side.
9.41: For whosoever may give you a cup of water in my name, because you are Christ's, truly I say unto you, can not lose his reward.
9.42: Whosoever may offend one of these little ones who believe in me, rather is it good for him, if a millstone is hung about his neck, and he may be cast into the sea.
9.43: And if thy hand may offend thee, cut it off: it is good for thee to go into life maimed, rather than having two hands to go away into hell, into the fire that can not be quenched.
9.45: If thy foot offend thee, cut it off: it is good for thee to go into life lame, rather than have two feet to be cast into hell.
9.47: If thine eye may offend thee, cast it from thee: it is good for thee entering into the kingdom of God having one eye, rather than having two eyes to be cast into hell;
9.48: where their worm does not die, and the fire is not quenched.
9.49: For every one shall be salted with fire.
9.50: Salt is good: but if the salt may become savorless, with what will you salt it? Have salt in yourselves, and live in peace with one another.

10.1: Rising up thence He comes into the coasts of Judea, through the region beyond the Jordan; and the multitudes again come to Him, and, as was His custom, He again taught them.
10.2: And the Pharisees having come forward asked Him, If it is lawful for a man to send away his wife? tempting Him.
10.3: And He responding said to them, What did Moses command you?
10.4: And they said, Moses permitted to write a book of divorcement, and to send her away.
10.5: Jesus said to them, On account of the hardness of your heart he wrote this commandment to you.
10.7: On this account a man shall leave his father and his mother,
10.8: and they two shall be one flesh; so they are no longer two, but one flesh.
10.9: And what God joined together, let no man separate.
10.10: And His disciples again around Him in the house asked Him. And He says to them,
10.11: Whosoever may send away his wife, and marry another, commits adultery unto her.
10.12: And if she having sent away her husband, may marry another, she commits adultery.
10.13: And they continued to bring little children to Him, that He should touch them: but the disciples rebuked those bringing them.
10.14: But Jesus seeing was displeased, and said to them, Suffer the little children to come unto me; and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God.
10.15: Truly, I say unto you, Whosoever may not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, can not enter into it.
10.16: And taking them up in His arms, putting His hands on them, He continued to bless them copiously.
10.17: And He traveling along the road, one having run to Him and worshiping Him, asked Him, Good Teacher, what shall I do in order that I may inherit eternal life?
10.18: And Jesus said to him, Why do you call me good? No one is good but One, God.
10.19: You know the commandments, thou must not commit adultery, thou must not murder, thou must not steal, thou must not bear false witness, thou must not defraud, honor thy father and mother.
10.20: And he said to Him, Teacher, I have kept all these from my youth.
10.21: Jesus looking on him loved him, and said to him, One thing is wanting to thee: go, sell whatsoever thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come, follow me.
10.22: And he being grieved at the word, went away sorrowing: for he had great possessions.
10.23: And Jesus looking around, says to His disciples; How hardly shall those having riches enter into the kingdom of God!
10.25: It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to go into the kingdom of God.
10.26: And they were astonished exceedingly, saying to one another, And who is able to be saved?
10.27: And Jesus looking upon them says, With men it is impossible, but not with God: for all things are possible with God.
10.28: Peter began to say to Him, Behold, we have left all things, and followed thee.
10.29: Jesus said, Truly I say unto you, there is no one who has left house, or brothers, or sisters, or father, or mother, or children, or lands, on account of me and the gospel,
10.30: except he may receive a hundredfold now in this time, and brothers, and sisters, and mothers, and children, and lands, with persecutions; and in the coming age eternal life.
10.31: But many who are first shall be last; and the last first.
10.32: And they were in the way, going up to Jerusalem; and Jesus was going before them: and they were amazed; and following they were afraid. And taking the twelve to Himself, again He began to tell them the things which were about to happen to Him;
10.34: and they will mock Him, and will scourge Him, and will spit upon Him, and will kill Him; and He will rise the third day.
10.35: James and John, the sons of Zebedee, come to Him, saying, Teacher, we wish that you may do unto us whatsoever we may ask.
10.36: And He said to them, What do you wish for me to do for you?
10.37: And they said to Him, Grant unto us, that we may sit, one on thy right, and one on thy left, in thy glory.
10.38: And Jesus said to them, You know not what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup which I drink? and to be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized?
10.39: And they said to Him, We are able. And Jesus said to them, You shall indeed drink the cup which I drink, and be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized:
10.40: but to sit on my right, and on my left, is not mine to give, but is for those for whom it has been prepared.
10.41: And the ten hearing, began to be indignant concerning James and John.
10.42: And Jesus calling them to Him, says to them: You know that those seeming competent to rule the Gentiles domineer over them; and their great ones exercise authority over them.
10.43: But it is not so among you: but whosoever may wish to be great among you, shall be your servant:
10.44: and whosoever of you may wish to be first, shall be the slave of all:
10.45: for the Son of man came not to be served, but to serve, and to give His soul a ransom for many.
10.46: And they come into Jericho: and He and His disciples and a great multitude going out from Jericho, blind Bartimeus, the son of Timeus, was sitting by the wayside, begging.
10.47: And hearing that it is Jesus the Nazarene, began to cry out, and say, Jesus, son of David, have mercy on me.
10.48: And many continued to rebuke him that he should keep silent: but he continued to cry out much more, O son of David, have mercy on me.
10.50: And he, casting away his cloak, rising, came to Jesus.
10.51: And Jesus responding said to him, What do you wish that I shall do to you? And the blind man said to Him, Great Master, that I may look up.
10.52: And Jesus said to him, Go; thy faith hath saved thee: and immediately he looked up, and followed Jesus in the way.

11.1: And when they draw nigh to Jerusalem and to Bethany, to the Mount of Olives, He sends away two of His disciples,
11.2: and says to them, Go into the village over against you: and immediately entering into it, you will find a colt tied, on which no one of men has ever sat; loosing him, lead him away.
11.3: And if any one may say to you, Why do you this? say to him, that the Lord hath need of him; and immediately he sends him hither.
11.4: Then they departed, and found the colt tied at the door without at the crossing of the road; and they are loosing him.
11.5: And certain ones of those standing there said to them, What are you doing, loosing the colt?
11.6: And they said to them as Jesus commanded: and they permitted them.
11.7: And they lead the colt to Jesus, and cast their garments on him; and He sat on him.
