11.8: And many strewed their garments in the road; and others were cutting down the branches of the trees, (and strewing them in the road),
11.9: And those going before, and those following after, continued to cry out, Hosanna: blessed is He that cometh in the name of the Lord:
11.10: blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David: Hosanna in the highest!
11.11: And He came into Jerusalem, into the temple; and looking round upon all things, the hour being already late, He went out into Bethany along with the twelve.
11.12: And on the morrow, they going out from Bethany, He was hungry.
11.13: And seeing a fig-tree at a distance, having leaves, He came, if perchance He shall find something on it: and having come to it, He found nothing except leaves; for it was not the time of the figs.
11.14: And responding He said to it, Let no one ever eat fruit from thee. And His disciples heard Him.
11.15: And they come into Jerusalem: and He having come into the temple, began to cast out the buyers and sellers in the temple, and He overturned the tables of the money-exchangers, and the seats of those selling doves;
11.16: and He did not suffer that any one should carry a vessel through the temple.
11.17: And He was teaching, saying to them, Is it not written, That my house shall be called a house of prayer for all the Gentiles? But you have made it a den of thieves.
11.18: And the scribes and high priests heard Him, seeking how they might destroy Him: for they feared Him, because all the multitude were delighted with His teaching.
11.19: And when it was evening, He departed out of the city.
11.20: And going along in the morning, they saw the fig-tree utterly withered from the roots.
11.21: And Peter remembering says to Him, Master, behold, the fig-tree which thou didst execrate is withered away.
11.22: And Jesus responding says to them, Have God's faith.
11.23: Truly I say unto you, That whosoever may say to this mountain, Be thou taken up and cast into the sea; and may not doubt in his heart, but believe that what he says does take place; it shall be unto him.
11.24: Therefore I say unto you, All things whatsoever you pray for and ask, believe that you just now received them, and they shall be unto you.
11.25: And when you stand praying, forgive, if you have aught against any one; in order that your Father who is in the heavens may forgive you your trespasses.
11.27: They come again into Jerusalem. And He walking round in the temple, the high priests, and scribes, and elders come to Him;
11.29: And Jesus said to them, I will ask you one word, and you respond to me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things:
11.30: Was the baptism of John from heaven, or from men? answer me.
11.33: And responding they say to Jesus, We do not know. And Jesus says to them, Neither do I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.

12.2: And he sent a servant to the husbandmen in the season, that he might receive from the husbandmen of the fruit of the vineyard:
12.3: and they taking him, beat him, and sent him away empty.
12.4: And again he sent to them another servant; and stoning him they wounded him in the head, and sent him away dishonored.
12.5: And again he sent another; and they slew him, and many others beating some, killing others.
12.6: Then having still one son, his own beloved, he sent him also to them last, saying; That they will reverence my son.
12.8: And taking him they slew him, and cast him out of the vineyard.
12.9: What then shall the lord of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the husbandmen, and give the vineyard to others.
12.10: Have you not read the Scripture; The stone which the builders rejected, the same has come to be the head of the corner:
12.11: this was with the Lord, and is wonderful in our eyes?
12.12: And they were seeking to arrest Him; and they feared the multitude; for they knew that He spoke the parable against them. And leaving Him they went away.
12.13: And they send to Him certain ones of the Pharisees and Herodians, that they may catch Him with speech.
12.14: And they having come, say to Him, Teacher, we know that thou art true, and there is not a care to thee for any one: for thou dost not look into the face of men, but thou dost teach the way of God in truth: is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar, or not? must we give, or must we not give?
12.15: And knowing their hypocrisy, He said to them, Why tempt ye me? Bring to me the denarion, that I may see it.
12.17: And Jesus responding said to them, Render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's, and unto God the things which are God's. And they were astonished at Him.
12.18: And the Sadducees come to Him, who say there is no resurrection; and asked Him, saying;
12.19: Teacher, Moses wrote to us, That if the brother of any man may die, and leave a wife and have no children, that his brother must take his wife and raise up seed to his brother.
12.20: There were seven brothers, and the first took a wife, and dying left no seed.
12.21: And the second received her and died, and he left no seed; and the third likewise.
12.22: And the seven received her and left no seed. Last of all the woman also died.
12.23: Then in the resurrection, when they may rise, of which one of them shall she be the wife? for the seven had her a wife.
12.25: For when they may rise from the dead, they neither marry nor are given in marriage; but they are as angels in the heavens.
12.26: But concerning the dead, that they are raised, have you not read in the book of Moses at the Bush, how God spoke to him saying; I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?
12.27: He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. You do err much.
12.28: And a certain one of the scribes, hearing them propounding questions, knowing that He answered them beautifully, asked Him, What is the first commandment of all?
12.29: And Jesus responded to him, The first commandment of all; Hear, O Israel; The Lord our God, is one Lord:
12.30: and thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength. This is the first commandment.
12.31: And the second is like unto it; Thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself. There is no other commandment greater than these.
12.32: And the scribes said to Him, Truly, Teacher; thou hast spoken in truth that He is One; and there is no other besides Him.
12.33: And love Him with all the heart, and with all the mind, and with all the strength, and to love thy neighbor as thyself is more than all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.
12.34: And Jesus seeing that he answered intelligently, said to him, Thou art not far from the kingdom of God. And no one dared to ask Him any more,
12.35: And Jesus responding spoke, teaching in the temple, How do the scribes say that Christ is the son of David?
12.36: For David himself said in the Holy Spirit, the Lord said unto my Lord; Sit thou on my right hand, until I may make thine enemies the footstool of thy feet!
12.37: Then David himself calls Him Lord; and whence is He his son? And the great multitude were hearing Him delightfully.
12.39: and the first seats in the synagogues, and the first couches at the suppers.
12.40: They are those devouring the houses of widows, and making long prayers through pretext; they shall receive the greater judgment.
12.41: And He sitting in front of the treasury, was seeing how the multitudes are casting their money into the treasury. And many rich people were casting in much.
12.42: And one poor widow was casting in two mites, which is a farthing.
12.43: And calling His disciples to Him, He says to them, Truly I say unto you, That this poor widow has cast in more than all those casting into the treasury.
12.44: For all they of that which abounds unto them cast in; but she of her scarcity cast in all things so many as she had, all her living.

13.1: And He departing out from the temple, one of His disciples says to Him, Teacher, behold, how great stones and how great buildings!
13.3: And He sitting upon the Mount of Olives in front of the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew asked Him privately,
13.4: Tell us, when these things shall be? and what shall be the sign when all these things may be about to have an end?
13.5: And Jesus began to say to them, See, lest any one may deceive you.
13.6: For many will come in my name, saying, I am He; and will deceive many. I
13.7: And when you may hear of wars and rumors of wars, be not disturbed: for it behooves it to be so; but the end is not yet.
13.8: For nation will rise up against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be earth-quakes in divers places; and there shall be famines.
13.10: And it behooves the gospel first to be preached to all the nations.
13.11: And when they may lead you forth, delivering you up, do not be solicitous what you may speak, nor meditate: but whatsoever may be given to you in that hour, speak this: for you are not those speaking, but the Holy Spirit.
13.13: And you shall be hated by all on account of my name: but the one persevering to the end, the same shall be saved.
13.14: And when you may see the abomination of desolation standing where it ought not (let him that readeth know), then let those in Judea fly to the mountains:
13.15: and let not the one on the housetop come down, nor enter in, to take anything out of his house:
13.16: and let not the one who is in the field turn back to take his garment.
13.17: But alas unto those who are in gestation and nursing in those days.
13.18: But pray that your flight may not be in the winter.
13.19: For these days will be tribulation, such as has never been from the beginning of creation which God created, until now, and never may be.
13.20: And unless the Lord shortened those days, no flesh would be saved: but for the sake of the elect, whom He chose, He shortened the days.
13.22: For false Christs and false prophets will arise, and give signs and wonders, to deceive even the elect, if possible.
13.23: But you see: behold, I have foretold you all things.
13.25: and the stars of heaven will be falling, and the powers which are in the heavens shall be shaken.
13.26: And then they shall see the Son of man coming in the clouds with great power and glory.
13.27: And then He will send forth His angels, and will gather His elect from the four winds, from the extremity of the earth unto the extremity of heaven.
13.28: But learn the parable from the fig-tree: when her branches may be now tender, and she may grow out leaves, know that the summer is nigh.
13.29: So you also, when you may see these things take place, know that it is already at the doors.
13.30: Truly I say unto you, this race may not pass away, until all these things may be fulfilled.
13.31: Heaven and earth shall pass away: but my words shall not pass away.
13.33: Beware, watch; for you know not when the time is.
13.34: As a man, going away, leaving his own house, and giving authority to his servants, and to each one his work, and commanded the porter that he should watch.
13.35: Watch therefore: for you know not when the Lord of the house cometh, late, or at midnight, or at the crowing of the cock, or in the morning;
13.36: lest having come suddenly he may find you sleeping.
13.37: And the things I say to you, I say to all, Watch.

14.1: And it was the passover and feast of unleavened bread after two days. And the high priests and scribes were seeking how they might kill Him, having taken Him by stratagem.
14.2: For they said, Not at the feast, lest there shall be an uproar of the people.
14.3: And He being in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, He sitting at the table, a woman came having an alabaster box of myrrh of spikenard estimated very valuable; and breaking the alabastar box, she poured it on His head.
14.4: And there were certain ones indulging in indignation among themselves (and saying), For what was this loss of the myrrh?
14.5: For this myrrh was able to be sold for more than three hundred denaria, and given to the poor. And they murmured against her.
14.6: And Jesus said, Let her alone; why do you give her trouble? she hath wrought a beautiful work in me.
14.7: For you have the poor always with you, and when you wish, you are able to do them good: but you have not me always.
14.8: She did what she could: she came aforehand to anoint my body for the burial.
14.9: Truly I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel may be preached in all the world, that which she did shall indeed be spoken of for a memorial of her.
14.10: And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went away to the chief priests, that he might betray Him to them.
14.11: And they, hearing, rejoiced, and promised to give him money. And he was seeking how he might betray Him opportunely.
14.12: And on the first day of the unleavened bread, when they were accustomed to slay the passover, His disciples say to Him; Where do you wish, that we, having gone away may prepare that you may eat the passover?
14.13: And He sends away two of His disciples, and says to them; Go into the city and a man will meet you carrying a pitcher of water; follow him,
14.14: whithersoever he may go in, say to the landlord that the Teacher says, Where is my guest chamber where I may eat the passover with my disciples?
14.15: And he will show you a large upper room furnished, ready; there prepare for us.
14.16: And His disciples went out, and came into the city, and found as He said to them, and prepared the passover.
14.17: And it being evening, He comes with the twelve.
14.18: And they sitting and eating, Jesus said, Truly, I say unto you, that, One of you who eateth with me shall betray me.
14.19: And they began to be grieved, and to say to Him one by one, Whether am I the one? And another, Whether am I the one?
14.20: And He said to them, One of the twelve who is dipping with me in the dish.
14.21: Truly the Son of man goes, as has been written concerning Him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! It was good for him if that man had never been born.
14.22: And they eating, Jesus having taken the bread, blessing it, broke, and gave it to them, and said, Take it: this is my body.
14.23: And taking the cup, blessing it, He gave it to them, and all drank of it.
14.24: And He said to them, This is my blood, which belongs to the new covenant, which is poured out for many.
14.25: Truly I say unto you, That I shall no more drink of the fruit of the vine, until that day when I may drink it new in the kingdom of God.
14.26: And they having sung a hymn, went out into the Mount of Olives.
14.28: But after I am risen, I will go before you into Galilee.
14.30: And Jesus says to him, Truly I say unto thee, That thou to-day, even this night, before the cock shall crow twice, shalt deny me thrice.
14.32: And they come into the place whose name is Gethsemane. And He says to His disciples, Sit here, until I may pray.
14.33: And He takes Peter, and John, and James with Him, and began to grieve and to be dejected.
14.34: And He says to them, My soul is exceedingly sorrowful unto death: abide here, and watch.
14.35: And having gone forward a little, He fell on the ground; and continued to pray, that if possible, the hour may pass from Him.
14.38: Watch and pray, that you may not enter into temptation: for the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
14.39: And again having gone away, He prayed, speaking the same word.
14.40: And turning, He found them again sleeping, for their eyes were heavy; and they did not know what they might respond to Him.
14.42: arise, let us go: behold, the one having betrayed me draws nigh.
14.43: And immediately, He still speaking, Judas Iscariot comes, being one of the twelve, and with him a great multitude with swords and clubs, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders.
14.44: And the one having betrayed Him gave them a sign, saying, The one whom I shall kiss, is He: seize Him and lead Him away securely.
14.45: And having come, immediately advancing forward, he said to Him, Master, and kissed Him copiously.
14.46: And they laid their hands on Him and arrested Him.
14.47: And a certain one of those standing by drew his sword, and smote the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.
14.48: Jesus responding said to them, You have come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs to take me:
14.49: I was daily with you in the temple teaching, and you did not arrest me: but in order that the Scriptures may be fulfilled.
14.50: And all leaving Him, fled away.
14.51: And one certain young man followed Him, invested with a linen cloth on his unclothed body: and they take hold of him.
14.52: And he leaving the linen cloth, fled from them in a state of nudity.
14.53: And they led Jesus to the high priest: and all the chief priests and elders and scribes came together to Him.
14.54: And Peter followed Him a long way off, even into the court of the high priest; and was sitting with the officers, and warming at the fire.
14.55: And the chief priests and all the sanhedrim were seeking testimony against Him to put Him to death; and they found none.
14.56: For many were testifying falsely against Him, and their testimonies were not equal.
14.57: And certain ones rising up, were testifying falsely against Him, saying,
14.58: We heard Him saying, I will destroy this temple made with hands, and will build another in three days, made without hands.
14.59: And thus their testimony was not equal.
14.63: The high priest tearing his garments, says, Why have we yet need of witnesses?
14.64: You heard the blasphemy: what seems to you? And all answered, He is worthy of death.
14.65: And certain ones began to spit on Him, and to cover His face, and to buffet Him, and say to Him, Prophesy: and the officers received Him with blows.
14.66: And Peter being in the court, one of the maidservants of the high priest comes down;
14.67: and seeing Peter warming, looking upon him, says, Thou wast with Jesus the Nazarene.
14.68: And he denied, saying, I know not, neither do I understand what you say. And he went out into the portico; and the cock crew.
14.69: And the maidservant seeing him again, began to say to the bystanders, He is one of them.
14.70: And again he denied: and after a little again the bystanders were saying to Peter, Truly, thou art one of them; for indeed thou art a Galilean.
14.71: But he began to anathematize, and to swear, I know not this man of whom you speak.

15.1: And immediately early in the morning the high priests having made counsel with the elders and scribes, and all the sanhedrim, having bound Jesus, led Him away, and delivered Him to Pilate.
15.3: And the chief priests were accusing Him of many things.
15.5: And Jesus responded nothing at all; so that Pilate marveled.
15.6: But during the feast he was accustomed to release unto them one prisoner, whom they asked,
15.7: And there was one called Barabbas, having been bound along with the insurrectionists, who had committed murder during the insurrection.
15.8: And the multitude crying out began to ask, as he was always accustomed to do unto them.
15.10: For he knew that the chief priests had delivered Him on account of envy.
15.11: And the chief priests persuaded the multitude that he should rather release unto them Barabbas.
15.12: And Pilate responding again said to them, Then what do you wish that I shall do unto Him whom you call the King of the Jews.
15.15: And Pilate, wishing to do the multitude a favor, released unto them Barabbas. And having scourged Jesus, he delivered Him up that He should be crucified.
15.16: And the soldiers led Him into the court, which is the judgment hall; and call around Him the whole band.
15.17: And they put on Him a purple robe, and having plaited a thorny crown, put it on Him.
15.18: And they began to mock Him, Hail, King of the Jews!
15.19: And they continued to strike His head with a reed, and spit on Him, and putting down their knees worshiped Him.
15.20: And when they mocked Him, they divested Him of the purple robe, and put on Him His own raiment: and lead Him away in order that they may crucify Him.
15.21: And they compel a certain Simon, a Cyrenean, coming from the country, the father of Alexander and Rufus, that he must take His cross.
15.22: And they lead Him to Golgotha, a place which is interpreted, The place of a skull.
15.23: And they gave Him myrrhed wine to drink: and He did not take it.
15.24: And they crucify Him, and divide His garments, casting the lot upon them, what each one may take.
15.25: And it was the third hour, and they crucified Him.
15.26: And the superscription of His accusation was written over Him, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
15.27: And they crucify two thieves along with Him; the one on His right, and one on His left.
15.29: And passing by they continued to blaspheme Him, wagging their heads, and saying, Aha, thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in three days,
15.30: save thyself, and come down from the cross.
15.31: Likewise also the chief priests mocking to one another with the scribes, continued to say, He saved others; He is not able to save Himself.
15.32: Let Christ, the King of Israel, now come down from the cross, in order that we may see and believe. And those being crucified along with Him were reproaching Him.
15.33: And it being the sixth hour, there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.
15.35: And certain ones of those standing by said, Behold, He is calling Elijah.
15.36: And one running and filling a sponge with vinegar, and reaching it forth on a reed, gave Him drink, saying, Let Him alone, let us see if Elijah comes to take Him down.
15.37: And Jesus, sending forth a loud voice, expired.
15.38: And the veil of the temple was rent in twain from top even to the bottom.
15.39: And the centurion standing by in front of Him, seeing that He thus expired, said; Surely this man was the Son of God.
15.40: And there were women looking on from a distance: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the less and Joses, and Salome;
15.41: who when He was in Galilee, were accustomed both to follow Him, and minister unto Him. And many other women who came up to Jerusalem along with Him.
15.42: And it already being evening, since it was the Preparation, which is the day before the Sabbath,
15.43: Joseph, who is from Arimathea, an honorable councilor, who also himself was waiting for the kingdom of God; having taken courage came to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus.
15.44: And Pilate was astonished if He had died already. And having called the centurion, asked him if He was already dead.
15.45: And having learned from the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph.
15.46: And having purchased linen, and taking Him down, he wrapped Him in the linen, and placed Him in a sepulcher which had been hewn out of the rock; and he rolled a stone to the door of the sepulcher.
15.47: And Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses were looking where He is placed.

16.1: And the Sabbath passing away, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome, prepared aromatics, in order that having come they may anoint Him.
16.2: And exceedingly early in the morning, the first of the Sabbaths, they come to the sepulcher, the sun approaching the horizon.
16.3: And they were saying to themselves, Who shall for us roll away the stone from the sepulcher?
16.4: And looking up, they see that the stone has already been rolled away: for it was exceedingly great.
16.5: And having come to the sepulcher, they saw a young man sitting on the right, clothed in a white robe. And they were affrighted.
16.7: But go, tell His disciples and Peter, that He goes before you into Galilee: you shall see Him there, as He told you.
16.8: And having come out from the sepulcher, they fled; and trembling and ecstasy possessed them, and they said nothing to any one; for they were afraid.

1.1: Inasmuch as many took it in hand to present a history concerning these things which have been fulfilled among us,
1.2: as those being eyewitnesses and ministers of the Word have delivered unto us;
1.3: it seemed good to me also, having followed carefully all things from the beginning, to write unto thee consecutively, O most noble Theophilus,
1.4: in order that thou mayest know the certainty of the words concerning which thou hast been instructed.
1.5: There was in the days of Herod, the king of Judea, a certain priest, by name Zacharias, of the course of Ahijah, and his wife of the daughters of Aaron, and her name Elizabeth.
1.6: And they were both righteous before God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord, blameless.
1.7: And there was no child to them, as Elizabeth was barren, and both were advanced in their days.
1.8: And it came to pass, while he was officiating in the order of his course before God,
1.9: (according to the custom of the priesthood he was chosen by lot to offer incense), having gone into the temple of the Lord;
1.10: and all the multitude of the people were praying without at the hour of incense;
1.11: the angel of the Lord appeared unto him standing on the right hand of the altar of incense:
1.12: and Zacharias was troubled seeing him, and fear fell on him.
1.14: And there shall be joy and rejoicing, and many shall rejoice at his birth.
1.15: For he shall be great before the Lord; and he shall not drink wine and strong drink; and he shall be filled with the Holy Ghost even from the womb of his mother.
1.16: And he will turn many of the sons of Israel to the Lord, their God.
1.17: And he will go before Him in the spirit and Power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient unto the understanding of the righteous, to prepare a people made ready for the Lord.
1.18: And Zacharias said to the angel: According to what shall I know this? for I am old and my wife advanced in her days.
1.19: And the angel responding said to him; I am Gabriel standing in the presence of God, and am sent to speak to you and to preach to you these things.
1.20: And behold thou shalt be dumb and unable to speak, unto the day upon which these things may take place; because thou didst not believe my words, which shall be fulfilled in their time.
1.21: And the people were waiting for Zacharias, and were wondering because he tarries in the temple.
1.22: And having come out he was unable to speak to them; and they recognized that he had seen a vision in the temple; and he was beckoning to them and remained dumb.
1.23: And it came to pass when the days of his ministry were fulfilled, he went away to his own house.
1.24: And after these days Elizabeth, his wife, conceived, and hid herself five months, saying,
1.25: That the Lord so hath done unto me, in the days in which He condescended to take away my reproach among men.
1.26: And in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a city of Galilee, to which was the name
1.27: Nazareth, to a virgin betrothed to a man, to whom was the name Joseph of the house of David; and the name of the virgin was Mary.
1.28: And the angel having come to her said; Hail, thou blessed one; the Lord is with thee; blessed art thou among women.
1.29: And she seeing was troubled over his word, and was reasoning what kind this salutation might be.
1.31: And behold, thou shalt conceive and hear a son, and thou shalt call His name Jesus.
1.32: He shall be great and shall be called the Son of the Highest; and the Lord God shall give unto Him the throne of His father David:
1.33: and He shall reign over the house of Jacob forever, and of His Kingdom there shall be no end.
1.34: And Mary said to the angel; How shall this be, since I know not man?
1.35: And the angel responding said to her; The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee; therefore, indeed, that holy thing that is begotten shall be called the Son of God.
1.36: And behold Elizabeth thy kinswoman, indeed, herself having conceived a son in her old age; and this is the sixth month, to her who is called barren.
1.37: Because no word shall be impossible with God.
1.38: And Mary said; Behold the handmaiden of the Lord; may it be done unto me according to thy word. And the angel went away from her.
1.39: And Mary, rising, departed into the mountainous land, with haste, into a city of Judah.
1.40: And she came into the house of Zacharias and saluted Elizabeth.
1.41: And it came to pass when Elizabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the infant in her womb leaped; and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit; and she spoke with a loud voice and said;
1.43: And whence is this to me that the mother of my Lord may come unto me?
1.44: For behold when the voice of your salutation came into my ears, the infant in my womb leaped with joy.
1.45: And blessed is she that believeth, because there shall be a perfection to those things having been spoken to her by the Lord.
1.46: And Mary said; My soul doth magnify the Lord,
1.47: and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour,
1.48: because He looked upon the low state of his handmaiden.
1.49: For behold from now all generations call me blessed; because the Mighty One did great things unto me, and His name is holy;
1.50: and His mercy unto generation of generations to them that fear Him.
1.51: He wrought power by his own arm; he dispersed the proud in the thought of their heart.
1.52: He cast down the mighty from thrones and exalted the humble.
1.53: He filled the poor with good things, and sent away the rich empty.
1.54: He delivered his son Israel, to remember mercy,
1.55: as he spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and his seed forever.
1.56: And Mary remained with her about three months, and returned to her own house.
1.57: And the time of her parturition was fulfilled unto Elizabeth and she brought forth a son.
1.58: And the neighbors and her relatives heard, that the Lord was magnifying His mercy with her, and they continued to rejoice with her.
1.59: And it came to pass on the eighth day, they came to circumcise the little child; and they were calling him Zacharias, after the name of his father.
1.60: And his mother responding said; No, but he shall be called John.
1.61: And they said to her; That there is no one among thy kindred who is called by this name.
1.62: And they were beckoning to his father, what he might wish to call him.
1.63: And having asked for a writing tablet, he wrote saying; His name is John.
1.64: And all marveled. And his mouth immediately opened and his tongue loosed, and he continued to speak, praising God.
1.65: And fear came upon all of those dwelling around; and all these words were spoken abroad in all the mountainous regions of Judea.
1.66: And all those hearing placed them in their heart, saying; What then shall this little child be? And the hand of the Lord was with him.
1.67: And Zacharias his father was filled with the Holy Ghost, and prophesied saying;
1.68: Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, because He looked upon us and wrought redemption to His people, and raised up unto us a horn of salvation
1.69: in the house of David His son.
1.70: As he spoke through the mouth of His holy prophets from the beginning;
1.71: salvation from our enemies, and from the hand of all those who hate us,
1.72: to execute mercy with our fathers, and remember His holy covenant,
1.73: the oath which He swore to Abraham our father:
1.74: to grant unto us, having been delivered out of the hand of our enemies, to serve Him without fear,
1.75: in holiness and righteousness before Him all the days of our life.
1.76: And thou, little child, shall be called a prophet of the Highest; for thou shalt go before the face of the Lord to prepare His ways,
1.77: to give knowledge of salvation to His people in remission of their sins,
1.78: through the bowels of mercy of our God, in which the dayspring from on high looked upon us,
1.79: to appear unto those sitting in darkness and in the shadow of death, to direct our feet in the way of peace.
1.80: And the little child continued to grow and waxed strong in spirit; and was in the deserts until the day of his showing unto Israel.

2.1: It came to pass in those days, a decree went out from Augustus Caesar, to enroll all the world.
2.2: This was the first enrollment, Cyrenius being governor of Syria.
2.3: And all were going forth to enroll, each one into his own city.
2.4: And Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city Nazareth, into Judea, into the city of David which is called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and family of David,
2.5: to enroll himself along with Mary, the wife having been betrothed to him, being in an advanced state of pregnancy.
2.6: And it came to pass while they were there the days of her parturition were fulfilled.
2.7: And she brought forth her firstborn son, and she wrapped Him in swaddling clothes and laid Him in a manger, because there was no place for them in the inn.
2.8: And the shepherds were in that country, tenting out and keeping guard over their flock by night.
2.9: And behold an angel of the Lord stood over them and the glory of the Lord shone around them; and they feared with great fear.
2.11: because this day a Savior is born unto you, who is Christ the Lord, in the city of David.
2.12: And this shall be the sign unto you; you shall find an infant lying in a manger, wrapped in swaddling clothes.
2.13: And immediately a multitude of the heavenly host was with the angel, praising God and saying;
2.14: Glory to God in the highest, and peace on earth; good will among men.
2.15: And it came to pass, when the angels departed from them into heaven, indeed, the shepherds said to one another; Now let us go unto Bethlehem and see this word which has taken place, which the Lord made known to us.
2.16: They went making haste, and found both Mary and Joseph, and the infant lying in the manger.
2.17: And seeing, they made known concerning the word which was spoken to them about this little child.
2.18: And all hearing wondered concerning the things which were spoken to them by the shepherds.
2.19: And Mary kept all these words laying them up in her heart.
2.20: And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God, for all things which they heard and saw, as it was spoken to them.
2.21: And when the eight days of circumcising Him were fulfilled, and His name was called Jesus, having been called by the angel before He was conceived in the womb.
2.22: And when the days of their purification were fulfilled, according to the law of Moses, they carried him up into Jerusalem, to present him to the Lord,
2.25: And behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon; and the same man was righteous and godly, awaiting the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was on him;
2.26: and it was revealed unto him by the Holy Spirit, that he should not see death before he may see the Christ of the Lord.
2.27: And he came in the Spirit into the temple; and while the parents are bringing in the little child Jesus, that they may do according to the provisions of law concerning Him,
2.28: he received Him into his arms and blessed God and said;
2.29: Now, O Lord, thou art letting thy servant depart, in peace according to thy word;
2.30: because mine eyes saw thy salvation,
2.31: which thou didst prepare before the face of all peoples;
2.32: a light unto the revelation of the Gentiles, and the glory of thy people Israel.
2.33: And His father and His mother were marveling at the words spoken concerning Him.
2.34: And Simeon blessed them and said to Mary, His mother; Behold, he is appointed unto the fall and rising of many in Israel, and unto a sign which is spoken against;
2.35: and a sword shall go through thy soul, in order that the reasonings of many hearts may be revealed.
2.36: And Anna was a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel of the tribe of Asher, herself being advanced in many days, having lived with her husband seven years from her virginity;
2.37: and she a widow of about fourscore years, who did not depart from the temple, worshiping night and day with fastings and prayers.
2.38: And she, at the same hour, standing up continued to praise the Lord, and speak concerning Him to all those awaiting the redemption in Jerusalem.
2.39: And when they finished all things according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee into their own city Nazareth.
2.40: And the child continued to grow and waxed strong in spirit, being full of wisdom; and the grace of God was on Him.
2.41: And His parents were going, according to custom, into Jerusalem at the feast of the passover.
2.42: And when He was twelve years old, they going up to Jerusalem according to the custom of the feast,
2.43: and having completed the days, while they were returning the boy Jesus remained in Jerusalem. And His parents knew it not.
2.44: And thinking that He is in the crowd, they came a day's journey, and were seeking Him among His relatives and acquaintances.
2.45: And not having found Him; they returned to Jerusalem seeking Him.
2.46: And it came to pass, after three days they found Him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the teachers, both hearing them and asking them questions.
2.47: And all hearing Him were astonished at His wisdom and answers.
2.48: And seeing Him they were astonished, and His mother said to Him; Child, why did you thus do unto us? Behold, thy father and I were seeking thee, sorrowful.
2.50: And they did not understand the word which He spoke unto them.
2.51: And He went down with them and came to Nazareth; and was subject unto them. And His mother continued to keep all these words in her heart.
2.52: And Jesus continued to grow in wisdom and stature and favor with God and men.

3.1: And in the fifteenth year in the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judea, and Herod being tetrarch of Galilee, and Philip his brother, tetrarch of Ituria and the Trachonitis country, and Lusanius tetrarch of Abilene, during the high-priesthood of Annas
3.2: and Caiaphas, the word of God came to John the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.
3.3: And he came into all the region round about the Jordan preaching the baptism of repentance unto the remissions of sins,
3.4: as has been written in the book of Isaiah the prophet, saying; The voice of one roaring in the wilderness; Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make straight His paths.
3.5: Every valley shall be filled up and every mountain and hill shall be cut down; and the crooked places shall be straight and the rough ways smooth.
3.6: And all flesh shall see the salvation of God.
3.7: Then he said unto the multitudes coming out to be baptized by him; O generations of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
3.8: Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance, and do not begin to say among yourselves; We have Abraham our father.
3.9: But truly the ax is laid to the root of the trees; Therefore every tree not producing good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
3.10: And the multitudes asked him, saying; What then shall we do?
3.11: And responding he says to them, Let the one having two coats, give to him having none, and let the one having food do likewise.
3.12: And the publicans came also to be baptized, and said to him; Teacher, what shall we do!
3.15: And the people waiting and all reasoning in their hearts concerning John, lest he might be the Christ.
3.16: John responded to all, saying; I indeed baptize you with water; but there cometh One more powerful than I, the latchet of His sandals I am not worthy to loose; He will baptize you with the Holy Ghost and fire.
3.17: Whose fan is in His hand, and He will thoroughly purify His threshing-floor, and gather the wheat into His garner, and will burn up the chaff with unquenchable fire.
3.18: Then indeed exhorting them as to many other things he continued to preach the gospel to the people.
3.19: And Herod the tetrarch, being convicted by him concerning Herodias, the wife of his brother Philip, and concerning the wickedness which Herod did,
3.20: added also this to all, and shut up John in prison.
3.21: And it came to pass while all the people were being baptized, and Jesus having been baptized, and praying, the heaven was opened,
3.22: and the Holy Spirit in bodily appearance like a dove descended on Him; and there was a voice from heaven, saying; Thou art my beloved Son, I am delighted in Thee.
3.23: And Jesus was beginning to be about thirty years old, being as was supposed, the son of Joseph, the son of Eli,
3.34: Jacob, Isaac, Abraham, Thara, Nachor, Serouch, Ragau,
3.37: of Methusalah, Enoch, Jared, of Mahalaleel, Cainan,
3.38: of Enos, Seth, Adam, the Son of God.

4.1: And Jesus, full of the Holy Ghost, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, tempted by the devil forty days.
4.2: And He ate nothing during those days; and they having been completed, He afterward hungered.
4.3: And the devil said to Him, If thou art the Son of God, speak to this stone, in order that it may become bread.
4.4: And Jesus responded to him, saying; It has been written, That man shall not live upon bread alone, but upon every word of God.
4.5: And the devil leading Him up, he showed Him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
4.6: And the devil said to Him, I will give all the authority and glories of these to thee: because it has been given unto me: and I give it to whom I may wish;
4.7: then if thou mayest worship before me all shall belong to thee.
4.8: And Jesus responding said to him; It has been written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God and Him only shalt thou serve.
4.9: And he led Him into Jerusalem, and placed Him on a pinnacle of the temple, and said to Him, If thou art the Son of God cast thyself down from thence;
4.10: for it has been written, That He will give His angels charge concerning thee, in order to guard thee,
4.11: and they will bear thee upon their hands, lest at any time thou mayest dash thy foot against a stone.
4.12: And Jesus responding said to him; That it has been said, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.
4.13: And the devil having perfected every temptation, departed from Him for a season.
4.14: And Jesus returned in the power of the spirit into Galilee. And the fame concerning Him went throughout the whole country.
4.15: And He was teaching in their synagogues, being glorified by all.
4.16: And He came into Nazareth, where He was brought up: and according to the custom to Him, He came into the synagogue on the Sabbath-day, and stood up to read.
4.17: And the Book of Isaiah the prophet was given to Him; and having opened the book, He found the place where it was written,
4.18: The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because He anointed me to preach the gospel to the poor: hath sent me to heal the brokenhearted, to proclaim deliverance to the captives, and sight to the blind, and to set at liberty them that are bruised,
4.19: to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord.
4.20: And having closed the book, and giving it back to the officer, He sat down: and the eyes of all in the synagogue were fastened on Him.
4.21: And He began to say to them; This day has this Scripture been fulfilled in your ears.
4.22: And they all continued to witness to Him, and wonder at the words of grace proceeding out from His mouth: and say, Is not this the son of Joseph?
4.23: And He said to them, You truly speak to me this parable, Physician, heal thyself: so many things as we heard having been done in Capernaum, do also here in thy own country.
4.24: And He said, Truly I say unto you, that no prophet is acceptable in his own country.
4.25: And in truth I say unto you, There were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah. When the heaven was shut up three years and six months, how the famine was great over all the land;
4.26: and Elijah was sent to none of them, except to a widow woman in Sarepta of Sidon.
4.27: And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha; and none of them were cleansed except Naaman the Syrian.
4.28: And all in the synagogue, hearing these things, were filled with wrath.
4.29: And rising up, they cast Him out of the city, and were leading Him to the brink of the mountain on which their city was built, to hurl Him down;
4.30: and He having passed through the midst of them went away.
4.31: And He came down into Capernaum, a city of Galilee, And He was teaching them on the Sabbath.
4.32: And they were astonished at His teaching; because His word was with authority.
4.33: And in the synagogue there was a man having a spirit of an unclean demon, and he cried with a great voice,
4.34: saying, Let me alone; what is there to us and to thee, O Jesus the Nazarene? Hast thou come to destroy us? I know thee who thou art, the Holy One of God.
4.36: And fear came upon them all, and they were talking together to one another, saying, What word is this? because with authority and power He commands the unclean spirits, and they come out.
4.37: And the report concerning Him was going out into every place in the surrounding country,
4.38: Having arisen up from the synagogue, He came into the house of Simon. And the mother-in-law of Simon was afflicted with a great fever; and they asked Him concerning her.
4.39: And He, standing over her, rebuked the fever; and dismissed it; and immediately, having stood up, she continued to minister unto them.
4.40: And the sun having gone down, all so many as had people afflicted with various diseases continued to lead them to Him; and He having put His hands on each one of them, healed them.
4.41: And the demons continued to go out from many, crying, and saying, Thou art the Christ, the Son of God. And rebuking them, He did not suffer them to speak, because they knew that He was the Christ.
4.42: And it being day, having come out, He departed into a desert place: and the multitudes continued to seek Him; and they came unto Him, and they constrained Him not to depart from them.
4.43: And He said to them, That, it behooveth me to preach the gospel of the kingdom of God to many other cities: because unto this I have been sent.
4.44: And He was preaching in the synagogues of Galilee.

5.1: And it came to pass, while the multitude is pressing on Him to hear the word of God, and He was standing by the lake of Gennesaret;
5.2: and He saw two ships standing by the lake: the fishermen, having gone from them, were washing their nets.
5.3: And having come into one of the ships, which belonged to Simon, He asked him to lead out a little from the land, and sitting down He was teaching the multitudes from the ship.
5.4: When He ceased speaking He said to Simon, Lead out into the deep, and spread your nets for a draught.
5.5: And Simon responding said to Him, Master, having toiled all night, we caught nothing: but at thy word I will spread the net.
5.6: And having done this, they caught a great multitude of fishes; and their net was breaking;
5.7: and they beckoned to their comrades in another ship, having come to assist them, And they came, and filled both ships, so as to sink them.
5.8: And Simon Peter, seeing, fell down at the knees of Jesus, saying; Depart from me, Lord, because I am a sinful man,
5.9: For fear took hold of him, and all of those with him, at the draught of fishes which they received.
5.11: And drawing up their ships to the land, having left all things, they followed Him.
5.12: And it came to pass, while He was in one of the cities, and behold, there is a man full of leprosy: and seeing Jesus, having fallen on his face, he prayed to Him, saying, Lord, if you may will it, you are able to cleanse me.
5.13: And reaching out His hand, He touched him, saying, I will; be thou cleansed. And immediately the leprosy departed from him.
5.15: And the word concerning Him was going abroad: and many multitudes continued to come, and be healed of their diseases by Him.
5.16: And He was out in the deserts, and praying.
5.17: And He was in one of the cities, and was teaching; and there were many Pharisees and theologians, who had come from every village of Galilee and Judea and Jerusalem: and the power of the Lord was present to heal them.
5.18: And behold, men carrying a man on a couch, who was paralyzed; and were seeking to bring him in, and place him before Him.
5.19: And not having found by what way they may bring him in on account of the crowd, going upon the house, they let him down through the tiles along with the bed in their midst in the presence of Jesus.
5.21: And the scribes and Pharisees began to reason, Who is this one who speaketh blasphemies? Who is able to forgive sins, except God only?
5.22: And having responded He said to them, Why do you reason in your hearts?
5.23: Which is the easier, to say, Thy sins are forgiven unto thee; or, to say. Arise and walk about?
5.24: But in order that you may know that the Son of man has power on earth to forgive sins, (He said to the paralyzed), I say unto thee, Arise, and having taken thy bed, go into thy house.
5.25: And immediately having arisen before them, taking the bed on which he was lying down, he went away to his own house, glorifying God.
5.26: And rapture seized them all, and they continued to glorify God; and they were filled with fear, saying, that, We have seen the paradoxical this day.
5.28: And having left all things, rising up, he followed Him.
5.29: And Levi made a great feast for Him in his own house: and there was a great multitude of publicans and others who were sitting along with Him.
5.30: And their scribes and the Pharisees were murmuring to His disciples, saying, Wherefore do you eat and drink with publicans and, sinners?
5.31: And Jesus responding said to them, They that are whole have not need of a physician, but they that are sick;
5.32: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
5.33: And they said to Him, Wherefore do the disciples of John fast, and make supplications; likewise also those of the Pharisees; but thy disciples eat and drink?
5.34: And He said to them, Whether are you able to make the sons of the bridechamber to fast, while the bridegroom is with them?
5.35: But the days will come when the bridegroom must indeed be taken away from them, then will they fast in those days.
5.36: He also spoke a parable to them; Let no one put a piece of new cloth on an old garment; lest the new shall tear it, and the piece from the new will not fit the old.
5.37: And no one puts new wine into old bottles; lest the new wine shall break the bottles, and it shall be poured out, and the bottles shall perish:
5.38: but the new wine is to be put into new bottles, and both will be preserved.
5.39: No one drinking the old immediately wishes the new; for he says, The old is better.

6.1: And it came to pass on the second Sabbath, He was going through the cornfields; and His disciples were plucking the ears, and eating, shelling them out with their hands.
6.2: And certain ones of the Pharisees said to them, Why are you doing that which is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?
6.3: Jesus responded and said to them, Have ye not read what David did, when he was hungry, and those being with him?
6.4: How he entered into the house of God, and how he took the shewbread, and ate it, and gave it to those with him; which is not lawful to eat, except the priests only?
6.5: And He said to them, The Son of man is Lord of the Sabbath also.
6.6: And it came to pass on another Sabbath, that He came into the synagogue and taught, and a man was there, whose right hand was withered.
6.7: And the scribes and Pharisees were watching Him, if He will heal him on the Sabbath, in order that they may find accusation against Him.
6.8: But He knew their thoughts, and said to the man having the withered hand, Rise up, and stand in the midst; and he having arisen stood.
6.9: And Jesus said to them, I will ask you; What is lawful on the Sabbath; to do good, or to do evil? to save life, or to destroy?
6.10: And looking around upon them all, He said to him, Reach forth thy hand. And he did so: and his hand was restored.
6.11: And they were filled with rage; and they were talking one to another what they might do to Jesus.
6.12: And it came to pass in those days, that He went out into the mountain to pray; and was there through the night in the prayer of God.
6.13: And when it was day, He called His disciples to Him: and having chosen twelve from them, whom He also named apostles;
6.14: Simon, whom He also named Peter, and Andrew his brother, James and John. Philip and Bartholomew,
6.15: Matthew and Thomas, James the son of Alpheus, and Simon called the Zealot;
6.16: and Judas the brother of James, and Judas Iscariot, who also became His betrayer.
6.17: And having come down with them, He stood upon a level place, and a great multitude of His disciples, and a great crowd of people from all Judea and Jerusalem, and Tyre and Sidon by the sea, who came to hear Him, and to be healed of their diseases;
6.18: and those troubled by unclean spirits; and they were getting healed.
6.19: And the whole multitude sought to touch Him: because power was going out from Him, and was healing all.
6.21: Blessed are ye who hunger now: because ye shall be filled. Blessed are ye who weep now: because ye shall laugh.
6.22: Blessed are ye, when the people may hate you, and when they may separate you, and cast out your name as evil, for the sake of the Son of man.
6.23: Rejoice in that day, and leap for joy: for behold your reward in heaven is great: for according to these things were their fathers accustomed to do to the prophets.
6.25: Woe unto you who are full! because you shall hunger. Woe unto you who are now laughing because you shall weep and mourn.
6.26: Woe unto you when all the people may speak well of you! because according to the same things their fathers were accustomed to do to the false prophets.
6.28: bless those who curse you, and pray for those who despitefully use you.
6.29: To the one smiting thee on the cheek turn the other also; and from the one taking away thy cloak do not withhold even the coat.
6.30: Give to every one asking thee, and turn not away from the one taking thy possessions,
6.31: And as you wish that the people may do unto you, do ye unto them even likewise.
6.32: If you love those who love you, what grace is there to you? for even sinners love those who love them.
6.33: And if you may do good to those doing good to you, what grace is there to you? for sinners also do the same.
6.34: And if you may lend to those from whom you may hope to receive, what grace is there to you? for sinners lend to sinners, that they may receive back the equivalent.
6.35: Moreover love your enemies, and do good, and lend, hoping nothing in return; and your reward shall be great, and you shall be the sons of the Highest: because He is good to the ungrateful and wicked.
6.36: Therefore be ye merciful, as your Father is indeed merciful.
6.38: Forgive, and you shall be forgiven: give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, heaped up, and shaken down, and running over, they will give into your bosom. For with the same measure, which you measure, it will be measured unto you.
6.40: The disciple is not above his teacher; but every one having been made perfect shall be as his teacher.
6.41: But why do you see the mote which is in the eye of your brother, and do not recognize the beam which is in your own eye?
6.44: For every tree is known by its own fruit: for they do not gather figs from thorns, nor do they gather the grape-bunch from the bramble.
6.45: The good man out of the good treasure of his heart brings forth the good; and the wicked man out of the wicked treasure of his heart brings forth that which is wicked: for out of the abundance of his heart his mouth speaks.
6.46: But why do you call me Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say?
6.47: Every one coming to me, and hearing my words, and doing the same, I will show you to whom he is like.
6.48: He is like unto a man building a house, who dug and went down deep, and laid the foundation upon the rock: and there being a flood, the river broke against that house, and it was not able to shake it; for it was founded on the rock.
6.49: But the one hearing and not doing, is like unto a man building his house upon the ground without a foundation; against which the river broke, and it fell immediately, and great was the fall of that house.

7.1: When He completed all His words in the ears of the people, He came into Capernaum.
7.2: And the servant of a certain centurion, being sick, was about to die, who was precious to him.
7.3: And hearing about Jesus, he sent elders of the Jews to Him, asking Him that having come He may save his servant.
7.4: And they, having come to Jesus, continued to entreat Him earnestly, saying, That he to whom He will do this is worthy:
7.5: for he loves our race, and himself built for us a synagogue.
7.6: And Jesus went along with them. And already He being not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to Him, saying to Him, Lord, be not troubled: for I am not worthy that you may come in under my roof:
7.7: Therefore I did not count myself worthy to come to thee; but speak the word, and my servant shall be healed.
7.9: And Jesus, having heard these words, was astonished at him, and turning to the multitude following said, I say unto you, I did not find so great faith in Israel.
7.10: And those having been sent, returning to the house, found the servant well.
7.11: And it came to pass consecutively, He departed into a city called Nain; and His many disciples and a great multitude went along with Him.
7.12: And when He drew nigh unto the gate of the city, behold, a dead man, an only born son to his mother, and she a widow, was indeed being carried out: and a great multitude of the city was along with her.
7.14: And having come forward He touched the bier: and the pall-bearers stood still: and He said, Young man, I say unto thee, Arise.
7.15: And the dead man sat up, and began to talk, and Ile gave him to his mother.
7.17: And that word about Him went out in all Judea, and all the country round about.
7.18: And His disciples proclaimed to John concerning all these things.
7.21: And at that hour He healed many of their diseases and ailments and evil spirits; and He conferred on many blind people the power to see.
7.22: And Jesus responding said to them, Having gone, proclaim to John those things which you saw and heard; that the blind are seeing, the lame are walking about, the lepers are being cleansed, the deaf are hearing, the dead are being raised up, the poor are having the gospel preached unto them;
7.23: and happy is he whosoever may not be offended in me.
7.24: And the messengers of John having gone away, He began to speak to the multitudes concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderness to see? a reed shaken by the wind?
7.25: But what went you out into the wilderness to see? a man clothed in soft raiment? Behold those who are in gaudy apparel and luxury, are in royal palaces.
7.26: But what went you out to see? a prophet? Yea, and I say unto you even more than a prophet.
7.27: This is he concerning whom it has been written, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, who will prepare thy way before thee.
7.28: I say unto you, among those having been born of women no prophet is greater than John the Baptist; nevertheless the least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.
7.29: And all the people hearing and the publicans justified God, being baptized with the baptism of John.
7.30: But the Pharisees and theologians rejected the counsel of God, against themselves, not having been baptized by him.
7.31: Then to whom shall I liken the men of this generation, and to whom are they like?
7.32: They are like unto little children sitting in the market-place, and calling to one another, and saying, We piped unto you, and you did not dance; we mourned unto you, and you did not weep.
7.33: For John the Baptist has come neither eating bread nor drinking wine; and you say, He has a demon.
7.34: The Son of man has come eating and drinking, and you say, Behold, a gluttonous wine-drinking man, a friend of publicans and sinners.
7.35: Truly wisdom is justified by her children.
7.36: And a certain one of the Pharisees, asked Him, that He would eat with him, and having come into the house of the Pharisee, He sat down to the table.
7.37: Behold, a woman who was a sinner, in the city, also having learned that He is dining in the house of the Pharisee, breaking an alabaster box of myrrh,
7.38: and standing behind by His feet, weeping, began to moisten His feel with tears, and she wiped them with the hairs of her head, and she continued to copiously kiss His feet, and to anoint them with the myrrh.
7.39: And the Pharisee, having invited Him, seeing, spoke within himself, saying, If He were a prophet, He would know who and what kind the woman is, who touches Him, because she is a sinner.
7.40: And Jesus responding said to him, Simon, I have something to say to thee. And he says, Speak, Teacher.
7.42: And they not being able to pay, he forgave them both. Then which one of them will love him the more?
7.43: Simon responding said, I perceive, that he, to whom he forgave the more. And He said to him, You answered correctly.
7.45: Thou gavest me no kiss: she, from the time I came in, did not cease copiously kissing my feet.
7.46: Thou didst not anoint my head with oil: but she anointed my feet with myrrh.
7.47: Therefore I say unto thee, her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much: but he to whom little is forgiven, loveth little.
7.48: And He said to her; Thy sins are forgiven.
7.49: And those sitting along with Him began to say among themselves, Who is this who even forgives sins?
7.50: And He said to the woman, Thy faith hath saved them; go in peace.

8.1: And it came to pass consecutively, that He was going through city and village, proclaiming and preaching the gospel of God, and the twelve along with Him.
8.2: And certain women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities, Mary called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had gone out,
8.3: and Joanna the wife of Chuzas the steward of Herod, and Susanna, and many other women, who were accustomed to minister unto Him from those things belonging to them.
8.4: A great multitude being with Him, and coming to Him throughout every city, He spoke in a parable:
8.6: And other fell on the rock; and springing up, withered away, because it had no moisture.
8.7: And other fell in the midst of thorns, and the thorns growing together, choked it out.
8.8: And other fell into good ground, and springing up, produced fruit, a hundredfold. Speaking these things, He cried out, Let the one having ears to hear, hear.
8.9: And His disciples asked Him saying, What might this parable be?
8.10: And He said; To you it has been given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God: but to the rest in parables; in order that seeing they may not see, and hearing they may not understand.
8.11: And this is the parable: The seed is the word of God.
8.12: And there are those who hear by the wayside; then the devil comes, and takes away the word from their heart, lest they believing may be saved.
8.13: And those on the stones are they who, when they may hear, receive the word with joy; and they have no root in them, who believe for a time, and in time of temptation they fall away.
8.14: And that which falleth among thorns, there are those who hear, and going forward, by the cares and riches and pleasures are choked out, and bring forth no fruit to perfection.
8.15: And that which is in the good ground, are those whosoever hearing the word in a beautiful and good heart, retain it, and bring forth fruit with patience.
8.16: But no one having lighted a candle covers it with a vessel, or puts it under a bed; but he places it on a candlestick, in order that those coming in may see the light.
8.17: For there is nothing hidden which shall not be made manifest; neither is there any thing concealed, which may not be made known and come into the light.
8.18: Therefore see how you hear: for whosoever may have, it shall be given unto him; and whosoever may not have, it shall be taken from him, even that which he seems to have.
8.19: And His mother and His brothers came to Him, and were not able to reach Him on account of the crowd.
8.20: And it was told Him, Thy mother and thy brothers stand without, wishing to see thee.
8.21: And He responding said to them, My mother and my brothers are the ones hearing the word of God, and doing it.
8.22: And it came to pass on one of the days, He and His disciples went into a ship. And He said to them, Let us go to the other side of the lake. And they were embarked.
8.23: And they sailing, He was asleep: and a storm of wind came down into the lake; and they were being filled, and imperiled.
8.24: And they having come to Him, awakened Him, saying, Master, Master, we perish. And He having arisen, rebuked the wind and the wave of the water: and they ceased, and there was a calm.
8.25: And He said to them, Where is your faith? And they being afraid were astonished, saying to one another, Who then is this, because He commands the winds and the water, and they obey Him?
8.26: And they sailed into the country of the Gergesenes, which is over against Galilee.
8.27: And a certain man from the city, who a long time had demons, and did not wear clothing, and did not remain in the house, but in the tombs; met Him having come to the land.
8.28: And seeing Jesus, and crying out, he worshiped Him, and said with a loud voice; What is there to me and to thee, O Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I pray thee torment me not.
8.29: For He commanded the unclean spirit to come out from the man; for since a long time he had possessed him, and he was frequently bound, secured with chains and fetters, and smashing his bonds, was driven by the demons into the desert.
8.30: And Jesus asked him saying, What is thy name? And he said Legion; because many demons entered into him.
8.31: And he continued to intreat Him that He should not command them to depart into the abyss.
8.32: And there was a herd of many swine feeding in the mountain: and they continued to intreat Him that He should permit them to go into them. And He permitted them.
8.33: And the demons having come out from the man, came into the swine: and the herd rushed down a precipice into the sea, and were strangled.
8.34: And the herders seeing that which took place, fled, and proclaimed it in the city and in the country.
8.35: And they came out to see that which had happened; and came to Jesus, and found the man, out of whom the demons had gone, clothed and in his right mind, at the feet of Jesus: and they were afraid.
8.36: And those seeing reported to them how the demonized man was saved.
8.37: And all the multitudes of the surrounding country of the Gergesenes, asked Him to depart from them; because they were seized with great fear. And He having come Into the ship, returned.
8.38: And the man out of whom the demons had gone prayed to be with Him. And Jesus sent him away, saying,
8.39: Return to thy own house, and relate, how many things God has done unto thee. And he departed throughout the whole city, preaching how many things Jesus did unto him.
8.40: And it came to pass when Jesus returned, the multitude received Him; for they were all looking for Him.
8.41: Behold, a man to whom was the name Jairus, and he was a ruler of the synagogue: and falling at the feet of Jesus, he continued to intreat Him to come into his house;
8.42: for there was an only daughter to him, of twelve years, and she was dying. And while He was going the multitudes were thronging Him.
8.43: And a woman being in an issue of blood twelve years, who having expended all her living with physicians, was not able to be healed by any of them,
8.44: and having come to Him behind, she touched the hem of His garment: and immediately the issue of blood ceased.
8.45: And Jesus said, Who is the one having touched me? And all denying, Peter and the disciples with Him said, The multitudes crowd thee and press upon thee, and dost thou say, Who is the one having touched me?
8.46: And Jesus said, Some one touched me: for I know the power went out from me.
8.47: And the woman seeing that she was not concealed, came trembling, and falling down before Him, proclaimed on account of what cause she touched Him, in the presence of all the people, and how she was healed immediately.
8.49: And He yet speaking, a certain one comes from the house of the chief ruler of the synagogue, saying to him, Thy daughter is dead; trouble not the Teacher:
8.51: And having come to the house, He did not suffer any to enter except Peter, John, and James, and the father and mother of the child.
8.52: And they were all weeping, and wailing over her: and He said, Weep not; she is not dead, but sleepeth.
8.53: And they hooted at Him, knowing that she was dead.
8.55: And her spirit returned, and she stood up immediately. And He commanded that something should be given to her to eat.
8.56: And her parents were delighted: and He commanded them to tell no one that which had taken place.

9.1: And calling the twelve, He gave to them power and authority over all demons, and to heal diseases.
9.2: And He sent them to preach the kingdom of God and to heal the sick.
9.3: And He said to them, Take nothing for the journey, neither staff, nor valise, nor bread, nor silver; nor to have two coats.
9.4: And into whatsoever house you may eaten there abide, and go out from thence.
9.5: And so many as may not receive you, going out from that city, knock off the dust of your feet for a testimony against them.
9.6: And going out, they continued to go through the villages, everywhere preaching the gospel, and healing.
9.7: And Herod the tetrarch heard all things which were wrought by Him; and was at a loss, because it was said by some, that John is risen from the dead;
9.8: and by some that Elijah has appeared; and by others that one of the old prophets is arisen.
9.9: And Herod said, I beheaded John: but who is this, concerning whom I hear these things? And he was seeking to see Him.
9.10: And the apostles having returned, expounded unto Him how many things they did. And taking them He departed privately into a desert place, belonging to the city called Bethsaida.
9.11: And the multitudes having found out, followed Him And receiving them, He spoke to them concerning the kingdom of God, and healed those having need of healing.
9.12: And the day began to decline; and the twelve coming to Him, said, Send away the multitude, in order that having gone into the surrounding villages and countries, they may lodge, and find food: because we are here in a desert place.
9.13: And He said to them, You give them to eat. And they said, There is not to us more than five loaves and two fishes; if not having gone we must purchase victuals for all this people.
9.14: For the men were about five thousand. And He said to His disciples, Have them sit down in companies, about fifty.
9.15: And they did thus, and made all sit down.
9.16: And taking the five loaves and two fishes, looking up to heaven, He blessed them; and He broke, and gave to the disciples to dispense to the multitude.
9.17: And they all ate and were filled: and that which remained to them of the fragments, were taken up, twelve baskets.
9.18: It came to pass, while He was praying alone, His disciples came to Him. And He asked them, saying, Whom do the multitudes say that I am?
9.19: They responding said, John the Baptist; and others, Elijah; and others, that one of the old prophets is risen.
9.21: And having charged them, He commanded them to tell it to no one.
9.22: Saying, That it behooved the Son of man to suffer many things, and to be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes and to be killed, and to rise the third day.
9.23: And He spoke to all, If any one wishes to come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.
9.24: For whosoever may wish to save his soul shall lose it; and whosoever may lose his soul for my sake, he shall save it.
9.25: For what is a man profited, gaining the whole world, and losing or forfeiting himself?
9.26: For whosoever may be ashamed of me and my words, the Son of man will be ashamed of him, when He may come in His glory, and that of the Father, and that of the holy angels.
9.27: And truly I say unto you, There are some of those standing here, who may not taste of death, until they may see the kingdom of God.
9.28: And it came to pass after these discourses, about eight days, and taking Peter and John and James, He went up into the mountain to pray.
9.29: And it came to pass while He was praying, the appearance of His countenance was changed, and His raiment shining white.
9.30: And behold two men were talking with Him, who were Moses and Elijah:
9.31: who being seen in glory, was speaking of His departure which He was about to perfect in Jerusalem.
9.32: And Peter and those who were along with Him, were burdened with sleep. And having watched through the night, they saw His glory and the two men who were standing with him.
9.33: It came to pass when they departed from Him, Peter said to Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here: and let us make three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elijah: not knowing what he says.
9.34: And he speaking these things there was a cloud, and it overshadowed them; and they were afraid while they were entering into the cloud.
9.35: And there was a voice from the cloud, saying, This is my beloved Son: hear ye Him. And while the voice is heard, Jesus is found alone.
9.36: And they were silent, and they told no one during those days any of those things which they had seen
9.37: And it came to pass, on the following day, they having come down from the mountain, a multitude met Him.
9.38: And behold, a man from the multitude cried out, saying, Teacher, I pray thee look upon my son, because he is to me an only child:
9.39: and behold, the spirit seizes him, and he suddenly cries out; and he convulses him with foam, and scarcely departs from him, contorting him.
9.40: And I besought thy disciples, that they should cast him out; and they were not able.
9.41: And Jesus responding said, O ye faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you, and bear with you? Bring your son hither.
9.42: And he yet coming, the demon dashed him down and convulsed him. And Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit and healed the child, and gave him to his father.
9.43: And all were astonished at the majesty of God. And all being astonished at all things which Jesus did, He said to His disciples,
9.44: You place these words in your ears: for the Son of man is about to be betrayed into the hands of men.
9.45: And they did not understand this word, and it was hidden from them, in order that they should not understand it: and they were afraid to ask Him concerning this word.
9.46: And a dispute came in among them, as to which one of them might be the greater.
9.47: And Jesus seeing the dispute of their heart, taking a little child, He placed it by Himself,
9.48: and said to them, Whosoever may receive this little child in my name receives me; and whosoever may receive me receives him that sent me. For he who is least among you all, the same shall be great.
9.49: And John responding said, Master, we saw one casting out the demons in thy name; and we forbade him, because he does not follow with us.
9.51: And it came to pass while the days of His taking up were being fulfilled, and He turned His face to go to Jerusalem,
9.52: and He sent messengers before His face. And they going forward, entered into a city of the Samaritans, in order to prepare for Him;
9.53: and they did not receive Him, because His face was going toward Jerusalem.
9.54: And the disciples James and John, seeing, said, Lord, do you wish that we may command fire to descend from heaven and consume them?
9.56: And they went into another village.
9.57: And they going on the way, a certain one said to Him, Lord, I will follow thee wheresoever thou mayest go.
9.60: And Jesus said to him, Let the dead bury their dead; but thou having gone away proclaim the kingdom of God.
9.61: And another said to Him, Lord, I will follow thee; but first permit me to bid adieu to those at my own home.
9.62: And Jesus said to him, No one putting his hand to the plow, and looking back, is worthy of the kingdom of God.

10.1: After these things the Lord chose seventy others also, and sent them out two by two before His face, into every place and city, where He was about to come.
10.2: And He said to them, The harvest is indeed great, but the laborers are few: therefore pray you the Lord of the harvest, that He may send forth laborers into His harvest.
10.3: Go: behold, I send you forth as lambs in the midst of wolves.
10.4: Take neither purse, nor valise, nor sandals: salute no one by the way.
10.5: Into whatsoever house you may enter, first say, Peace be unto this house.
10.6: And if the son of peace may be there, your peace shall rest upon it: but if not, it shall return unto you.
10.7: Abide in the same house, eating and drinking those things which are with them: for the laborer is worthy of his hire. Go not from house to house.
10.8: Into whatsoever city you may enter and they may receive you, eat those things which are placed by you:
10.9: and heal the sick who are in it, and say to them, The kingdom of God has come nigh unto you.
10.10: And into whatsoever city you may enter, and they may not receive you, having come out into the streets of the same, say,
10.11: Even the dust from your city, that cleaveth to our feet, do we wipe off against you: but know this, that the kingdom of God is at hand.
10.12: For I say unto you, that it will be more tolerable in that day for Sodom than for that city.
10.13: Woe unto thee, Chorazin! woe unto thee, Bethsaida! for if the mighty works which were wrought in you had been in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting down in sackcloth and ashes.
10.14: Moreover it shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon in the judgment than for you.
10.15: And thou, Capernaum, art thou not exalted up to heaven? thou shalt be cast down to Hades.
10.16: He that heareth you heareth me; he that rejecteth you rejecteth me; and he that rejecteth me rejecteth Him that sent me.
10.17: And the seventy returned with joy, saying, Lord, even the demons are subordinated to us in thy name.
10.18: And He said to them, I saw Satan having fallen as the lightning from heaven.
10.19: Behold I have given you authority to tread upon serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy; and nothing shall hurt you.
10.20: Moreover do not rejoice in this, that the spirits are subject unto you; but rejoice that your names are written in the heavens.
10.21: At the same hour He rejoiced in the Holy Spirit, and said, I praise thee, O Father, Lord of the heaven and the earth, because thou hast hidden these things from the wise and prudent, and revealed them to babes: yea, Father, because it was thus pleasing in thy sight.
10.24: For I say unto you, that many kings and prophets desired to see those things which you see, and saw them not; and to hear those things which you hear, and heard them not.
10.25: And behold, a certain lawyer stood up tempting Him, saying, Teacher, having done what shall I inherit eternal life?
10.26: He said to him, What has been written in the law? how do you read it?
10.27: And he responding said, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with divine love from all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind; and thy neighbor as thyself.
