10.31: And by chance a certain priest came down that way: and seeing him, passed by on the other side.
10.32: And likewise also a Levite, being at the place, coming and seeing, passed by on the other side.
10.33: And a certain Samaritan, on a journey, came near him: and seeing, had compassion on him,
10.34: and having come to him, he bound up his wounds, pouring in oil and wine: and having mounted him on his own beast, carried him to a tavern, and cared for him.
10.35: And on the morrow, taking out two denaria, gave them to the host, and said, Care for him; and whatsoever you expend in addition, on my return, I will pay you.
10.36: Which one of these three seems to you to have been the neighbor of him who fell among the thieves?
10.37: And he said, The one having done mercy with him. And Jesus said to him, Go, thou, and do likewise.
10.38: And it came to pass while they were going round, He also came into a certain village: and a certain woman by name Martha received Him into her house.
10.39: And there was a sister to her called Mary, who indeed sitting down at the feet of the Lord, continued to hear his word:
10.40: and Martha was very busy about much serving. And standing over Him, she said, Lord, is there no care to thee that my sister has left me to serve alone? then say to her that she must assist me.
10.41: And the Lord responding said to her, Martha, Martha, you are solicitous and encumbered concerning many things:
10.42: but there is need of one thing: for Mary has chosen the good part, which shall not be taken from her.

11.1: And it came to pass, that He was in a certain place praying; when He ceased, one of His disciples said to Him, Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples.
11.3: give unto us this day our daily bread:
11.4: and forgive us our sins; for we also do forgive every one owing us: and lead us not into temptation.
11.6: since my friend came to me from the road, and I have nothing which I may place before him.
11.8: I say unto you, If indeed having risen he will not give unto him, because he is his friend, yet on account of his shamelessness, rising he will give him as much as he needs.
11.9: And I say unto you, Ask, and it shall be given unto you; seek, and you shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you.
11.10: For every one asking receives; and the one seeking finds; and to the one knocking it shall be opened.
11.11: And which father of you shall if his son ask bread, will he give him a stone? or indeed a fish, will he instead of a fish give him a serpent?
11.12: Or indeed shall he ask an egg, will he give him a scorpion?
11.13: If then you, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, then how much more will your Father who is from heaven give the Holy Spirit to them that ask Him?
11.14: And He was casting out a demon, and he was dumb: and it came to pass, the demon having gone out, the dumb spoke; and the multitudes were astonished.
11.15: And certain ones of them said, He casts out the demon through Beelzebul, the prince of the demons.
11.16: And others tempting, continued to seek with Him a sign from heaven.
11.18: And if Satan were indeed divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? Because you say I am casting out demons through Beelzebul.
11.19: But if I through Beelzebul cast out the demons, through whom do your sons cast them out? Therefore they shall be your judges:
11.20: but if I through the finger of God cast out the demons, then the kingdom of God has come nigh unto you.
11.21: When the strong man armed may keep his palace, his goods are in peace:
11.22: but when one stronger than he, having come, may conquer him, he takes away his panoply in which he trusted, and divides his spoils.
11.23: The one not being with me is against me; and the one not gathering with me scatters abroad.
11.24: When the unclean spirit may go out from the man, he goes through dry places; seeking rest, and finding none, he says, I will return into my own house, whence I came out.
11.25: And having come he finds it swept and beautified.
11.26: Then he goes, and takes seven other spirits more wicked than himself; and having come in he dwells there: and the last state of that man is worse than the first.
11.29: And the multitudes being assembled, He began to say, This is a wicked generation: it seeks after a sign, and no sign shall be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah.
11.30: For as Jonah was a sign to the Ninevites, so shall the Son of man also be a sign to this generation.
11.31: The queen of the south will rise in judgment with this generation, and condemn them; because she came from the uttermost parts of the earth, to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and behold, a greater than Solomon is here.
11.32: The men of Nineveh will rise in judgment with this generation, and condemn it: because they repented at the preaching of Jonah; and behold a greater than Jonah is here.
11.33: No one, having lighted a lamp, putteth it in a cellar, nor under a bushel, but on a candlestick, in order that those coming in may see the light.
11.34: The light of the body is the eye: therefore when thine eye may be clear, truly thy whole body is lighted; but when it may be had, truly thy body is dark.
11.35: See then that the light which is in thee is not darkness.
11.36: If then thy whole body is lighted, having no part dark, all will be lighted, as when a lamp may light thee with its brightness.
11.37: And while He was speaking, a Pharisee asked Him, that He would dine with him: and having come in, He sat up at the table.
11.38: And the Pharisee seeing, was astonished because He was not first baptized before dinner.
11.39: And the Lord said to him, Now you Pharisees purify the outside of the cup and the plate, but the interior is full of extortion and wickedness.
11.40: Ye fools, did not the One having made the outside also make the inside?
11.41: Therefore give alms of your substance; and behold all things are pure unto you.
11.43: Woe unto you, Pharisees! because you love the front seat in the synagogues, and salutations in the forums.
11.44: Woe unto you! because you are like tombs unseen, and men walking over them do not know it.
11.45: And a certain one of the theologians responding says to Him, Teacher, speaking these things yon indeed insult us.
11.46: And He said, Woe unto you, theologians! because you lay burdens on the people difficult to be borne, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.
11.47: Woe unto you! because you build the sepulchers of the prophets, and your fathers killed them.
11.48: Therefore you are witnesses and you consent unto the works of your fathers: because they slew them, and you build.
11.49: Therefore the wisdom of God said, I will send unto them prophets and apostles; and some of them they will slay and persecute.
11.50: In order that the blood of all the prophets poured out from the foundation of the world, may be required from this generation;
11.51: from the blood of Abel unto the blood of Zachariah, who perished between the altar and the house; yea, I say unto you, it shall be required of this generation.
11.52: Woe unto you, theologians! because you have taken away the key of knowledge: you did not come in, and you prohibited those who were coming in.
11.53: And He having come out from thence, the scribes and Pharisees began vehemently to press on Him, and mouth after Him concerning many things;
11.54: laying in wait, to catch something from His mouth.

12.2: But there is nothing hidden, which shall not be revealed: and concealed, that shall not be made known.
12.3: Therefore so many things as you spoke in the darkness shall be heard in the light; and whatsoever you spoke in the ear in the secret chambers shall be proclaimed upon the houses.
12.4: And I say unto you, my friends, Be not afraid of those killing the body, and after these things, having nothing more to do.
12.5: But I will show you whom you must fear: Fear him, who after he kills has power to cast into hell. Yea, I say unto you, Fear him.
12.6: Are not five sparrows sold for two pennies? and one of them is not forgotten before God.
12.7: But even the hairs of your head are all numbered. Fear not: ye are more important than many sparrows.
12.9: But the one denying me before the people will be denied before the angels of God.
12.10: And every one who shall speak a word against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him: but to him having blasphemed against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven.
12.11: But when they may carry you into the synagogues, and tribunals, and authorities; do not be solicitous as to what you may apologize, or what you may say:
12.12: for the Holy Spirit will teach you in that hour the things which it behooveth you to speak.
12.13: And a certain one from the multitude said to Him, Teacher, speak to my brother, to divide the inheritance with me.
12.14: And He said to him; Man, who established me judge or a divider over you?
12.15: And He said to them, See, and beware of all covetousness: because his life is not in that which aboundeth to any one, from those things belonging to him.
12.16: He spake a parable to them, saying, The farm of a certain rich man was very productive:
12.17: and he was reasoning in himself, saying, What shall I do, because I have no place where I shall store my fruits?
12.18: And he said, I will do this: I will take down my barns, and build greater, and there I will gather all my fruits and my goods.
12.19: And I will say to my soul, Soul, thou hast much goods laid up for many years; take thine ease, eat, drink, be merry.
12.21: So is every one laying up treasure for himself, and not rich toward God.
12.22: And He spoke to His disciples, Therefore I say unto you, Be not solicitous for your soul, what you may eat; nor for your body, what you may put on.
12.23: The soul is more than food, and the body more than raiment.
12.24: Observe the ravens, because they neither sow nor reap; to which there is no storehouse nor barn, and God feeds them; are you not much better than the fowls?
12.25: And which one of you being solicitous is able to add one moment to his existence?
12.26: If then you are powerless in the smallest matter, why are you solicitous about other things?
12.28: And if God so clothes the verdure flourishing in the fields to-day, and to-morrow cast into the oven; how much more are you, O ye of little faith?
12.29: And do not seek what you may eat, and what you may drink, and with what you are clothed;
12.30: for the heathens of the world are seeking after all these things: but your Father knows that you have need of these things.
12.33: Sell your possessions and give alms; make for yourselves purses that will not get old, and treasure in the heavens which can not be stolen, where the thief does not draw nigh, nor the moth corrupt.
12.34: For where your treasure is, there your heart will be.
12.36: and be you like unto men waiting for their lord, when he may rise up from the marriage feast; in order that, coming and knocking, they may open unto him immediately.
12.37: Blessed are those servants, whom the lord having come will find watching: truly I say unto you, that he will gird himself, and have them sit down, and having come will serve them.
12.38: If at the second, and third, watch he may come, happy are ye.
12.39: Know this, that if the landlord knew at what hour the thief cometh, he would not have permitted his house to be broken into.
12.40: Be ye also ready: because at an hour you do not think the Son of man cometh.
12.41: And Peter said to Him, Lord, do you speak this parable to us, or to all?
12.42: The Lord said, Who then is the faithful, wise steward, whom the lord will establish over his house-hold, to give them their food in season?
12.43: Happy is that servant, whom his lord having come shall thus find watching.
12.44: Truly I say unto you, that he will establish him over all his possessions.
12.45: But if that servant may say in his heart, my lord delayeth his coming, and may begin to smite the servants and handmaidens, and to eat and drink, and be drunken;
12.46: the lord of that servant will come in a day in which he does not expect, and in an hour in which he does not know, and will cut him off, and will appoint his part with the unbelievers.
12.47: But that servant knowing the will of his lord, and not preparing or doing according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes.
12.48: But the one not knowing, and doing things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with few. But to every one to whom much is given, much will be required of him: and to whom they commit much, of him they will ask the more.
12.49: I have come to send fire on the earth; and what do I will, if it is already kindled?
12.50: And I have a baptism to be baptized with; and how am I straitened till it may be perfected!
12.51: Do you think that I have come to give peace on the earth? I say unto you, Nay, but division.
12.52: For from now, there shall be five in one house divided, three shall be divided against two, and two against three:
12.53: the father against the son, and the son against the father; and the mother against the daughter, and the daughter against the mother; the mother-in-law against the daughter-in-law, and the daughter-in-law against the mother-in-law.
12.54: And he also spoke to the multitudes, When you may see a cloud rising from the west, you immediately say, that the rain cometh; and it is so:
12.55: and when the south wind is blowing, you say, that it will be hot; and it is so.
12.56: You hypocrites, you know how to discern the face of the earth and the firmament; and how do you not discern this time?
12.57: Why do you not judge righteous judgment, even with reference to yourselves?
12.58: For as you go with your adversary to the ruler, give attention on the way that you be reconciled with him; lest he may deliver you to the judge, and the judge shall turn you over to the officer, and the officer will cast you into prison.
12.59: I say unto you, You can by no means come out thence, till you have even paid the last mite.

13.1: And there were certain ones at that time announcing to him concerning the Galileans, whose blood Pilate mixed with their sacrifices.
13.3: T say unto you, Nay: but unless you may repent, you shall all likewise perish.
13.4: Or those eighteen, on whom the tower in Saloam fell, and killed them, do you think that they were offenders above all the men that dwell in Jerusalem?
13.5: I say unto you, Nay: but unless you may repent, you will all likewise perish.
13.9: and if it may bear fruit in the future; and if not you shall cut it down.
13.10: And He was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.
13.11: And behold, a woman having a spirit of infirmity eighteen years; and she was bowed together, and not at all able to straighten up.
13.12: And Jesus seeing her, called to her, and said, Woman, thou art loosed from thy infirmity:
13.13: and He placed His hands on her: and immediately she straightened up, and continued to glorify God.
13.14: And the chief ruler of the synagogue, responding, being grieved because Jesus healed on the Sabbath, said to the multitude, There are six days in which it behooveth us to work: therefore during these, coming, be healed, and not on the Sabbath-day.
13.15: And the Lord responded to him, and said, Ye hypocrites, does not each one of you loose his ox or his donkey from the stall, and leading him away, give him water on the Sabbath?
13.16: Did it not behoove this one, being a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan bound, lo, these eighteen years, to be loosed from this bondage on the Sabbath-day?
13.17: And He speaking these things, all opposing Him became ashamed: and the whole multitude rejoiced over all the illustrious works wrought by Him.
13.18: Then He said, To what is the kingdom of God like? and to what shall I liken it?
13.19: It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man having taken, cast into his garden; and it grew, and became a tree; and the birds of heaven lodged in its branches.
13.20: And again He said, To what shall I liken the kingdom of God?
13.21: It is like leaven, which a woman having taken, hid in three measures of meal, until the whole was leavened.
13.22: And He was journeying through cities and villages, teaching, and making His journey towards Jerusalem.
13.23: And one said to Him, Lord, are the saved few? And He said to them,
13.24: Agonize to enter in through the narrow gate: because many, I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and will not be able.
13.25: When the landlord may rise up, and close the door, and you may begin to stand without, and knock at the door, saying, Lord, open unto us; and responding he will say unto you, I know not whence you are.
13.26: Then you will begin to say, We ate and drank in thy presence, and thou didst preach in our streets.
13.27: And he will say, I tell you, I know you not whence you are; depart from me, all you workers of iniquity.
13.28: And there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you shall see Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets, in the kingdom of God, and you cast out.
13.29: And they will come from the east and west, and the north and south, and will sit down in the kingdom of God.
13.30: And behold, the last shall be first, and the first shall be last.
13.31: At that hour certain Pharisees came to Him, saying; Depart, and go hence: because Herod wishes to slay thee.
13.32: And He said to them, Having gone, tell that fox, Behold, I cast out demons and perfect healings to-day and to-morrow, and on the third day I am made perfect.
13.33: Moreover it behooves Me to travel to-day and to-morrow and the day following: because it does not behoove a prophet to perish outside of Jerusalem.
13.34: O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them that have been sent unto thee! how frequently did I wish to gather thy children, in the manner in which a hen doth gather her brood under her wings, and ye were not willing!

14.1: And it came to pass when He entered into the house of one of the rulers of the Pharisees on the Sabbath to eat bread, that they were watching Him.
14.2: And, behold, a certain dropsical man was before Him.
14.3: And Jesus responding spoke to the theologians and Pharisees, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath-day, or not? and they were silent.
14.4: And taking him by the hand, He healed him, and sent him away.
14.5: And responding to them He said; Of which one of you shall his son or his ox fall into a pit, and will he not immediately lift him out on the Sabbath-day?
14.6: and they were not able to respond to these things.
14.7: And He spoke a parable to those whom He had called, warning them that they should not choose the first couches; saying to them,
14.8: When you may be called by any one to a marriage feast, do not sit down upon the first couch; lest one more worthy than thee may have been called by him,
14.9: and the one having called thee and him, having come in shall say to thee, Give place to him; and then thou shalt with shame begin to take the last place.
14.11: Because every one who shall exalt himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted.
14.12: And He spoke to the one having also invited Him, When you may make a dinner or a supper, do not call your rich friends, nor your brothers, nor your kindred, nor your neighbors; lest they may also invite thee in turn, and there may be a recompense unto thee.
14.13: But when you may make a feast, invite the poor, maimed, lame, blind:
14.14: and thou shalt be happy; because they have nothing with which to recompense thee: and it shall be recompensed unto thee in the resurrection of the just.
14.21: And the servant coming, announced these things to his lord. Then the land-lord being angry said to his servant, Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and lead in hither the poor and maimed and blind and lame.
14.22: And the servant said, Lord, it is done as thou didst command, and yet there is room.
14.23: And the lord said to the servant, Go out into the roads and hedges, and compel them to come in, in order that my house may be filled:
14.24: for I say unto you, that no one of these men who have been invited shall taste of my supper.
14.25: And many multitudes were journeying along with Him, and turning He said to them,
14.26: If any one comes to me, and does not hate his father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brothers, and sisters, and even yet his own soul, he is not able to be my disciple.
14.27: Whosoever does not carry his cross, and come after me, is not able to be my disciple.
14.29: Lest he having laid the foundation, and being unable to complete it, all who see it may begin to mock him,
14.30: saying, that this man began to build, and was not able to complete it.
14.31: Or what king, going forth to engage in war with another king, will not first sitting down counsel if he is able with ten thousand to meet him who is coming against him, with twenty thousand?
14.32: But if not, while he is yet a great way off, sending an embassy, he asks for those things which appertain to peace.
14.33: Thus then every one of you who does not consecrate all his possessions, is not able to be my disciple.
14.34: Therefore salt is good: but if the salt may lose its savor, with what shall it be salted?
14.35: It is neither good for the land nor for excrement: they cast it out. He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.

15.1: And all the publicans and sinners were drawing nigh to Him to hear Him.
15.2: And the Pharisees and scribes were murmuring, saying, that, He receives sinners, and eats with them.
15.3: And He spoke this parable to them, saying,
15.4: What man of you, having a hundred sheep, and having lost one of them, does not leave the ninety and nine in the desert, and go after the lost one, until he may find it?
15.5: And having found it, places it on his shoulders, rejoicing:
15.6: and having come into the house, calls together the friends and neighbors, saying to them, Rejoice with me, because I have found my sheep which was lost.
15.7: I say unto you that so there will be joy in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, rather than ninety and nine just persons who have not need of repentance.
15.8: Or what woman having ten drachmae, if she may lose one drachma, does she not light a candle, and sweep the house, and seek diligently till she may find it?
15.9: And having found it, she calls together her friends and neighbors, saying, Rejoice with me, because I have found the drachma which I lost.
15.10: So, I say unto you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner that repenteth.
15.13: And not many days afterward the younger son gathering all together, departed into a far-off country; and there wasted his substance living riotously.
15.14: And he having expended all, a severe famine came into that country; and he began to be in want.
15.15: And having gone he joined himself to one of the citizens of that country: and he sent him into his fields to feed swine:
15.16: and he was desiring to fill his stomach from the pods, which the swine were eating: and no one gave unto him:
15.17: and having come to himself he said, How many hired servants of my father have bread in abundance, but here I perish with hunger!
15.18: Having risen I will go to my father, and say to him, Father, I have sinned against heaven, and in thy sight:
15.19: and I am no more worthy to be called thy son: make me as one of thy hired servants.
15.20: And having risen, he came to his father. And he being yet a great way off, his father saw him, and was moved with compassion, and having run, fell upon his neck, and kissed him copiously.
15.23: and bring hither the fatted calf, slay him, and eating, let us be merry:
15.24: because this my son was dead, and is alive again; was lost, and is found. And they began to be merry.
15.25: And his elder son was in the field: and while coming he drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing.
15.26: And calling one of the servants, asked him what these things might be.
15.28: And he was angry, and did not wish to come in: and his father having gone out, continued to intreat him. And responding he said to the father,
15.29: Behold, I serve thee so many years, and have never transgressed thy commandment: and thou hast never given me a kid, that I may rejoice with my friends:
15.30: but when this thy son, the one devouring thy living with harlots came, thou hast slain for him the fatted calf.
15.31: And he said to him, Child, thou art always with me, and all mine are thine:
15.32: and it behooved me to be glad and rejoice; because this thy brother was dead, and is alive; was lost, and is found.

16.1: And He also spoke to His disciples, There was a certain rich man, who had a steward; and he was slandered to him as wasting his goods.
16.2: And having called him, he said to him, What is this which I hear concerning thee? give an account of thy stewardship; for thou art not able to be steward any longer.
16.3: And the steward said within himself, What shall I do, because my lord takes away my stewardship from me? I am not able to dig; I am ashamed to beg.
16.4: I know what I shall do, in order that when I am deposed from the stewardship, they may receive me into their houses.
16.5: And calling each one of the debtors of his lord, he said to the first, How much do you owe my lord?
16.8: And the lord praised the steward of unrighteousness because he acted shrewdly: because the sons of this age are wiser in their generation than the sons of the light.
16.9: And I say unto you, Make unto yourselves friends of the mammon of unrighteousness, in order that, when it may fail, they may receive you into eternal tabernacles.
16.10: He that is faithful in the least is also faithful in much: and he that is unrighteous in the least is unrighteous in much.
16.11: If therefore you were not faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will intrust to you the true?
16.12: If you were not faithful in the interest of another, who will give you your own?
16.13: No servant is able to serve two masters: for he will hate the one, and love the other; or he will cleave to the one, and despise the other. You are not able to serve God and mammon.
16.14: And the Pharisees, being avaricious, were hearing all these things, and murmuring against Him.
16.15: And He said to them, Ye are those who justify yourselves before the people; but God knows your hearts: because that which is exalted among the people is abomination in the sight of God.
16.16: The law and the prophets were until John: from that time the kingdom of God is preached, and every one presses into it.
16.17: And it is easier that heaven and earth pass away, than one tittle fall from the law.
16.19: There was a certain rich man, and he was habitually clothed in purple and fine linen, faring sumptuously every day.
16.20: But a certain beggar, Lazarus by name, was laid at his gate, full of sores,
16.21: and desiring to be fed by the crumbs falling from the table of the rich man; but the dogs also coming continued to lick his sores.
16.22: And it came to pass that the beggar died, and himself was carried by the angels into the bosom of Abraham: and the rich man also died, and was buried.
16.23: And in Hades lifted up his eyes, being in torment, sees Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bosom.
16.26: And in addition to all these things, there is a great gulf fixed between us and you, in order that those wishing to go hence to you may not be able, neither can they come thence to us.
16.28: for I have five brothers; in order that he may testify to them, that they may not also come to this place of the torment.

17.1: And He spoke to His disciples, It is impossible for offenses not to come: but woe unto him, through whom they come;
17.2: it is good for him if a millstone is hung around his neck, and he is cast into the sea, rather than that he may offend one of these little ones.
17.3: Take heed to yourselves. If thy brother may sin, rebuke him; if he may repent, forgive him.
17.4: But if he may sin against thee seven times a day, and seven times turn again to thee, saying, I repent; thou shalt forgive him.
17.5: And the apostles said to the Lord, Increase our faith.
17.8: But will he not say to him, Prepare what I may sup, and girding thyself, minister unto me, until I may eat and drink; and after these things you eat and drink?
17.9: Whether does he thank the servant because he did the things which were commanded?
17.10: Likewise also, when you may do those things which are commanded you, say that, We are unprofitable servants; we have done that which we ought to do.
17.11: And it came to pass, while He was journeying to Jerusalem, and He was going through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.
17.12: He coming into a certain village, ten lepers met Him, who stood afar off;
17.13: and lifting up their voice, saying, Thou, Jesus, Master, have mercy on us.
17.14: And seeing, He said to them, Go and show yourselves to the priest. And it came to pass while they were going, they were cleansed:
17.15: and one of them, seeing that he was healed, returned, with a loud voice glorifying God,
17.16: and he fell upon his face at His feet, giving thanks to Him: and he was a Samaritan.
17.17: And Jesus responding said, Were not the ten cleansed?
17.18: Where are the nine? And they were not found returning to give thanks to God, except this one foreigner.
17.19: And He said to him, having arisen, go: thy faith hath saved thee.
17.20: Then being interrogated by the Pharisees, when the kingdom of God is coming, He responded to them and said, The kingdom of God comes not with observation:
17.21: neither will they say; Lo, here! or, there! for behold, the kingdom of God is among you.
17.22: And He said to the disciples, The days will come, when you will desire to see one of the days of the Son of man, and will not see it.
17.23: And they will say to you, Lo, here! lo, there! go not away, nor follow them.
17.24: For as the lightning, flashing out of the one part under the heaven, gleams into the other part under heaven, so shall be the Son of man in His day.
17.25: But it behooves Him first to suffer many things and to be set at nought by this generation.
17.26: And as it was in the days of Noah, so it will be in the days of the Son of man.
17.27: They were eating, they were drinking, they were marrying, they were getting married, until the day on which Noah entered into the ark, and the flood came and destroyed them all.
17.28: Likewise also as it was in the days of Lot; they were eating, they were drinking, they were buying, they were selling, they were planting, they were building;
17.29: and on the day on which Lot went out from Sodom, fire and brimstone rained from heaven and destroyed them all.
17.30: According to these things it will be in the day the Son of man is revealed.
17.31: In that day, let not him who is on the house, and his goods in the house, come down to take them: and likewise let not him who is in the field turn back.
17.33: Whosoever may seek to save his soul shall lose it: and whosoever shall lose it shall find it.
17.34: I say unto you, on that night two men shall be on one bed; the one shall be taken and the other left.
17.35: Two women shall be grinding at the same mill; the one shall be taken, and the other shall be left.
17.37: Responding they say to Him, Where, Lord? And He said to them, Where the body is, there the eagles will also be gathered together.

18.1: And He spoke a parable to them that it behooves them to pray always, and not to faint;
18.2: saying, There was a certain judge in a certain city, fearing not God, and regarding not man.
18.3: And there was a widow in that city; and she continued to come to him, saying, Avenge me of mine adversary.
18.5: yet because this widow causes me trouble, I will avenge her, lest coming forever she may smite me in the face.
18.6: But the Lord said, I fear what the unjust judge says.
18.7: And shall not God avenge His elect, crying to Him day and night, and He is long-suffering over them?
18.8: I say unto you, that He will avenge them speedily. Moreover the Son of man having come, will He then find faith upon the earth?
18.9: And He spoke this parable to certain ones having confidence in themselves that they are righteous, and despising the rest.
18.10: Two men went up into the temple to pray; the one a Pharisee, and the other a publican.
18.11: The Pharisee standing was praying in these words, God, I thank thee because I am not like the rest of the men, extortioners, unjust, adulterous, or even as this publican:
18.12: I fast twice per week; I give tithes of all things so many as I possess.
18.14: I say unto you, He went down to his house justified rather than the other: because every one exalting himself shall be abased; and the one humbling himself shall be exalted.
18.15: And they were indeed bringing the infants to Him, that He should touch them: but the disciples seeing rebuked them.
18.16: And Jesus calling them to Him, said, Suffer the little children to come unto me, and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God.
18.17: Truly I say unto you, whosoever may not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, can not enter into it.
18.18: And a certain ruler asked Him, saying, Good Teacher, having done what, shall I inherit eternal life?
18.19: And Jesus said to him, Why do you call me good? No one is good, except One, God.
18.20: You know the commandments, thou must not commit adultery, thou must not murder, thou must not steal, thou must not bear false witness, honor thy father and mother.
18.22: And Jesus hearing these things, said to him, Still one thing is lacking to thee: Sell all things whatsoever you have, and give to the poor, and you shall have treasure in heaven: and come, follow me.
18.23: And hearing these things, he went away very sorrowful; for he was exceedingly rich.
18.24: Jesus seeing him said, How hardly will those having riches enter into the kingdom of God!
18.25: For it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to go into the kingdom of God.
18.26: And those hearing said, And who is able to be saved?
18.27: And He said, Those things which are impossible with men are possible with God.
18.28: And Peter said, Behold, we have left all things, and followed thee.
18.29: And He said to them, Truly I say unto you, that there is no one who has left house, or parents, or brothers, or wife, or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
18.30: who may not receive a hundredfold in this time, and in the coming age eternal life.
18.31: And taking the twelve aside, He said to them, Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and all things which have been written by the prophets shall be perfected to the Son of man.
18.32: For He will be delivered to the Gentiles; and be mocked, and insulted, and spat upon:
18.33: and having scourged Him, they will kill Him; and He will arise the third day.
18.34: And they understood none of these things; and this word was hidden from them, and they did not know the things spoken.
18.35: And it came to pass, while He was drawing nigh to Jericho, a certain blind man was sitting by the wayside begging.
18.36: And hearing the multitude passing by, he inquired what it might be.
18.37: And they told him that Jesus the Nazarene is going along.
18.38: And he cried out saying, Jesus, thou son of David, have mercy on me.
18.39: And the passersby continued to rebuke him, that he should keep silent: but he continued to cry out much more, O thou son of David, have mercy on me.
18.40: And Jesus standing, commanded him to be led to Him; and he drawing nigh, He asked him,
18.41: What do you wish that I shall do to you? And he said, Lord, that I may look up.
18.42: And Jesus said to him, Look up: thy faith hath saved thee.
18.43: And immediately he looked up, and followed Him, glorifying God: and all the people, seeing, gave praise to God.

19.1: And having come in He passed through Jericho.
19.2: And behold, a certain man by name called Zaccheus; and he was chief of the publicans, and he was rich.
19.3: And he was seeking to see Jesus, who He is; and was not able on account of the multitude, because he was small in stature.
19.4: And having run forward in advance, he went up in a sycamore-tree in order that he might see Him: because He was about to pass that way.
19.5: And when He came to the place, Jesus looking up, saw him, and said to him, Zaccheus, hastening, come down; for it behooveth me to abide in thy house this day.
19.6: And hastening, he came down, and received Him rejoicing.
19.7: And all seeing, murmured, saying, that He is come in to abide with a sinner man.
19.8: And Zaccheus standing, said to the Lord, Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have taken any thing from any one fraudulently, I restore fourfold.
19.9: And Jesus said to him, This day salvation has come to this house, because he also is a son of Abraham;
19.10: for the Son of man came to seek and to save that which is lost.
19.11: And they hearing these things, proceeding, He spoke a parable, because he is nigh unto Jerusalem, and they think the kingdom of God is about to be made manifest immediately.
19.15: And it came to pass, when he returned, having received the kingdom, and he said, that those servants should be called, to whom he had given the money, in order that he might know what each one had gained by their merchandise.
19.16: And the first came, saying, Lord, thy pound has gained ten pounds.
19.18: And the second one came, saying, Lord, thy pound has gained five pounds.
19.21: for I feared thee, because thou art an austere man: thou takest up that which thou hadst not laid down, and thou reapest that which thou hast not sown.
19.22: And he says to him, Out of thine own mouth I will judge thee, thou wicked servant. Didst thou know that I am an austere man, taking up what I have not laid down, and reaping what I have not sown?
19.23: Wherefore indeed didst thou not put my money in the bank? and having come I would have received the same with the product.
19.24: And he said to the bystanders, Take the pound from him, and give it to the one having ten pounds.
19.26: I say unto you, that to every one having it shall be given; and from every one not having, it shall be taken away even that which he hath.
19.27: Moreover bring these my enemies, not wishing me to rule over them, hither, and slay them before me.
19.28: And speaking these things, He was journeying before them, going up to Jerusalem.
19.29: And it came to pass, when He drew nigh unto Bethphage and Bethany, to the mount called the Mount of Olives, and He sent away two of His disciples,
19.30: saying, Go into the village over against you; in which entering you will find a colt tied, on which no one of men ever sat: loosing, lead him hither.
19.31: And if any one may ask you, Why do you loose him? thus say to him, that the Lord hath need of him:
19.32: and those having been sent, departing, found as Jesus told them.
19.33: And they loosing the donkey, his master said to them, Why do you loose the donkey?
19.34: And they said, The Lord hath need of him.
19.35: And they led him to Jesus: and casting their garments on the colt, they mounted Jesus on them.
19.36: And He going forward, they were strewing their garments in the road.
19.37: And He already drawing nigh to the descension of the Mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples began to praise God with a loud voice for all those miracles which they saw; shouting,
19.39: And certain ones of the Pharisees from the multitude said to Him, Teacher, rebuke thy disciples:
19.40: and He responding said to them, I say unto you, that if these may keep silent, the rocks will cry out.
19.41: And when He drew near, seeing the city He wept over it,
19.42: saying, If thou indeed hadst known, truly in this thy day, the things appertaining to thy peace! but now they are hidden from thy eyes.
19.43: Because the days will come upon thee, and thine enemies will cast a fortification about thee, and surround thee, and press in on thee from all directions,
19.44: and will slay thee, and thy children in thee; and will leave in thee not a stone upon a stone; because thou hast not known the time of thy visitation.
19.45: And having come into the temple, He began to cast out those buying and selling,
19.47: And He was teaching daily in the temple, and the chief priests and scribes and the first men of the people were seeking to destroy Him.
19.48: And they were not finding what they might do; for all the people hung on Him, hearing Him.

20.1: And it came to pass, on one of those days, He teaching the people in the temple, and preaching the gospel, the priests, and scribes, along with the elders stood up against Him;
20.2: and they spoke to Him, saying, Tell us by what authority you are doing these things? Who is the one having given you this authority?
20.3: And responding He said to them, I will ask you one word; and you tell me:
20.4: Was the baptism of John from heaven, or from men?
20.7: And they responded, We do not know whence it is.
20.8: And Jesus said to them, Neither do I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
20.10: And in season he sent a servant to the husbandmen that they might give to him of the fruit of the vineyard, and the husbandmen beating him, sent him away empty.
20.11: And he proceeded to send to them another servant, and they beating and dishonoring him sent him away empty.
20.12: And he proceeded to send a third: and wounding him, they cast him out also.
20.13: And the lord of the vineyard said, What shall I do? I will send my own beloved son: perchance seeing, they will reverence him.
20.15: And casting him out from the vineyard they slew him; what then will the lord of the vineyard do?
20.16: He will come and destroy those husbandmen, and will give the vineyard to others. And hearing, they said, Let it not be so.
20.17: And looking upon them, He said, What is that which has been written, The stone which the builders rejected, the same has come to be the head of the corner.
20.18: Every one having fallen on that stone will be dashed to pieces; and on whomsoever it may fall, it will grind him to powder.
20.19: And the chief priests and scribes sought to lay hands on Him at this hour, and feared the people; for they knew that He spoke this parable against them.
20.20: And laying in wait for Him, they sent sharpers, feigning themselves to be righteous, that they might catch his word, in order to turn Him over to the government and authority of the proconsul.
20.21: They asked Him saying, Teacher, we know that thou dost speak and teach correctly; and thou dost not receive the face; but thou dost teach the way of God in truth:
20.22: is it lawful for us give tribute to Caesar, or not?
20.23: And He knowing their rascality, said to them, Why tempt ye me?
20.25: And He said to them, Therefore render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's, and unto God the things which are God's.
20.26: And they were not able to criticise His word before the people: and being astonished at His answer, they were silent.
20.27: And certain ones of the Sadducees, who deny that there is a resurrection, coming forward asked Him,
20.28: saying, Teacher, Moses wrote to us, That if the brother of any one may die having a wife, and the same may die childless, that his brother must take his wife and raise up seed to his brother.
20.29: Then there were seven brothers; and the first receiving a wife died childless.
20.31: and the third received her, and likewise also the seven; they left no children and died.
20.32: Last of all the woman also died.
20.33: Therefore in the resurrection of which one of them is she the wife? for the seven had her a wife.
20.34: And responding Jesus said to them, The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage,
20.35: but those counted worthy to attain that age and the resurrection, which is from the dead,
20.36: neither marry nor are given in marriage; for they are not able yet to die; for they are like the angels, and sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.
20.37: But that the dead are raised, Moses also mentioned at the Bush, when he says; The Lord, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.
20.38: He is not the God of the dead but of the living; for all live unto Him.
20.39: And certain of the scribes responding said; Teacher, you spoke beautifully.
20.40: And they no longer dared to ask Him anything.
20.41: And He said to them; How do they say that the Christ is the son of David?
20.42: And David himself says in the Book of the Psalms, The Lord said to my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand,
20.43: until I may make thine enemies the footstool of thy feet.
20.44: Therefore David calls Him Lord, and how is He his son?
20.45: And all the people hearing, He said to His disciples,
20.47: Who devour the houses of the widows, and pray long through pretext; they shall receive the greater judgment.

21.1: And looking up, He saw the rich casting their gifts into the treasury.
21.2: And He also saw a certain poor widow, casting in thither two mites.
21.3: And He said; Truly I say unto you, That this poor widow cast in more than all.
21.4: For they all of that which abounds unto them cast into the gifts of God: but she out of her scarcity cast in all her living which she had.
21.5: And certain ones speaking concerning the temple, that it was ornamented with beautiful stones and offerings, He said,
21.7: And they asked Him, saying, Teacher, when then shall these things be? and what shall be the sign when these things may be about to come to pass?
21.8: And He said, See that you are not deceived. For many will come in my name, saying, I am He; and The time is at hand: go ye not after them.
21.9: And when ye may hear of wars and commotions, be not affrighted: for it behooveth these things first to take place; but the end is not immediately.
21.10: Then He said to them, Nation shall rise up against nation, and kingdom against kingdom:
21.11: and there shall be great earthquakes, famines and pestilences in divers places; and there shall be great terrors and signs from heaven.
21.13: And it shall come to pass to you for a testimony.
21.14: Place it in your hearts, not to premeditate your defense:
21.15: for I will give to you mouth and wisdom, which all who are opposed to you will not be able to gainsay nor resist.
21.16: And you shall be delivered up also by your parents, and brothers, and relatives, and friends; and they will kill some of you.
21.17: And you shall be hated by all, on account of my name:
21.18: and not a hair from your head shall perish.
21.19: In your patience gain your souls.
21.20: And when you may see Jerusalem shut up by the armies, then know that her desolation is nigh.
21.21: Then let those in Judea fly to the mountains; and let those in the midst of it depart out; and let not those in the country come into it.
21.22: Because these are the days of vengeance, to fill up all things which have been written.
21.23: But alas to those in gestation and nursing in those days! For there shall be great distress upon the earth, and wrath to this people.
21.24: And they shall fall by the edge of the sword, and be led captive into all nations: and Jerusalem shall be trodden down by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles may be fulfilled.
21.25: And there will be signs in the sun and in the moon and in the stars; and commotion of the nations of the earth in their perplexity, the sea and the wave roaring;
21.26: the souls of men failing from fear, and expectation of those things coming upon the world: for the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
21.27: And then they will see the Son of man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
21.28: And these things beginning to take place, straighten up, and lift up your heads; because your redemption is nigh.
21.29: And He spoke a parable to them: Behold the fig-tree, and all the trees:
21.30: when they may already put forth, seeing, know for yourselves that summer is nigh.
21.31: So you also, when you see these things take place, know that the kingdom of God is nigh.
21.32: Truly I say unto you, that this race may not pass away, until all these things shall be fulfilled.
21.33: But heaven and earth shall pass away, but my word can not pass away.
21.35: For as a lasso it will come upon all the people who are sitting down upon the face of the whole earth.
21.36: Therefore watch, praying all the time, that you may be counted worthy to escape all these things which are about to come to pass, and to stand before the Son of man.
21.37: And He was teaching in the temple during the days; and during the nights going out, He was lodging in the mountain called Mount of Olives.
21.38: And all the people gathered in the temple to hear Him.

22.1: And the feast of the unleavened bread, called the passover, was nigh.
22.2: And the chief priests and scribes were seeking how they might kill Him; for they feared the people.
22.3: And Satan entered into Judas called Iscariot, being of the number of the twelve.
22.4: And having gone away, he spoke with the chief priests and the magistrates, how he might betray Him to them.
22.5: And they rejoiced, and promised to give him money.
22.6: And he promised them, and was seeking an opportunity to deliver Him unto them in the absence of the multitude.
22.7: And the day of the unleavened bread came, in which it behooved to slay the passover.
22.8: And He sent Peter and John, saying, Going prepare for us the passover, in order that we may eat it.
22.9: And they said to Him, Where do you wish that we may prepare it?
22.10: And He said to them, Behold, you having come into the city, a man will meet you carrying a pitcher of water; follow him into the house where he is going.
22.11: And say to the landlord, The Teacher says to thee, Where is the guest-chamber, where I may eat the passover with my disciples?
22.12: And he will show you a large upper room furnished: there prepare.
22.13: And having gone away, they found as He told them; and prepared the passover.
22.14: And when the hour arrived, He sat down and the apostles along with Him.
22.15: And He said to them, I desired with desire to eat this passover with you before I suffer: for I say to you,
22.16: I eat this no more, until it may be fulfilled in the kingdom of God.
22.17: And receiving the cup, having given thanks, He said, Take this, and divide it among yourselves;
22.18: for I say to you, I shall from now drink no more from the fruit of the vine, until the kingdom of God may come.
22.19: And taking bread, blessing it, He broke it, and gave it to them, saying, This is my body given for you: do this in remembrance of me.
22.20: Likewise also the cup after supper, saying, This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which is poured out in your behalf.
22.21: Moreover behold, the hand of the one betraying me is with me at the table.
22.22: Indeed the Son of man goes, according to that which has been appointed: but woe to that man by whom He is betrayed!
22.23: And they began to inquire among themselves, who then of them is the one of them about to do this.
22.24: And there was a contention among them, which one of them seems to be the greater,
22.26: But you are not thus: but let the greater among you be as the younger; and the leader as the waiter.
22.27: For which is the greater, he that sitteth at the table, or the waiter? is not the one sitting? but I am in the midst of you as the waiter.
22.28: But you are those who have remained with me in my temptations.
22.29: And I appoint unto you a kingdom, as my Father appointed unto me,
22.30: in order that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom; and you shall sit upon thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
22.31: Simon, Simon, behold, Satan sought you out, to sift you as wheat:
22.32: but I prayed for you, that your faith may not fail you: and thou, when having turned, strengthen thy brethren:
22.33: but he said to Him, Lord, I am ready to go with thee to prison and to death.
22.34: And He said; I say unto thee, Peter, the cock shall not crow this day, before that thou shalt thrice deny that thou knowest me.
22.35: Then He said to them, When I sent you without purse, and valise, and sandals, did you lack anything? And they said; Nothing.
22.38: And they said, Lord, behold, here are two swords. And He said to them, It is sufficient.
22.39: And having gone out, He departed, according to custom, into the Mount of Olives; and His disciples followed Him.
22.40: He being at the place, He said to them, Pray that you enter not into temptation.
22.41: And He was separated from them about a stone's cast; and putting down His knees, continued to pray,
22.43: And an angel from heaven appeared unto Him, strengthening Him.
22.44: And being in agony He continued to pray the more earnestly. And His sweat was like drops of blood falling down upon the ground.
22.45: And having risen from prayer, having come to His disciples, He found them sleeping on account of weariness,
22.46: and He said to them, Why do you sleep? Arising pray, that you may not enter into temptation.
22.47: And He still speaking, behold, a multitude and the one called Judas, one of the twelve, was coming before them; and he drew near to Jesus to kiss Him.
22.48: And Jesus said to him, Judas, do you betray the Son of man with a kiss?
22.49: And those around Him seeing what was coming on Him, said, Lord, shall we smite with the sword?
22.50: And one of them smote the servant of the high priest, and cut off his right ear.
22.51: And Jesus responding said, Hold on until this: and touching his ear, healed him.
22.52: Jesus said to the high priests, and magistrates of the temple, and elders who were assembled to Him; You have come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs.
22.53: I being daily with you in the temple, you reached not out your hands unto me. But this is your hour, and the power of darkness.
22.54: And taking Him, they led Him away, and led Him into the house of the chief priest. And Peter followed Him a long way off.
22.55: And having lighted a fire in the midst of the court, and they sitting together, Peter was sitting in the midst of them.
22.56: And a certain maidservant, seeing him sitting at the fire, and fixing her eyes on him, said, This man was with Him.
22.57: And he denied Him, saying, Woman, I know Him not.
22.58: And after a brief interval another seeing him, said, Truly, thou art one of them. And Peter said, Man, I am not.
22.60: And Peter said, Man, I know Him not. And immediately, he yet speaking, the cock crew.
22.62: And having gone out, he wept bitterly.
22.63: And the men having Him, began to mock, beating Him,
22.64: and covering Him, they continued to ask saying, Prophesy, who is the one smiting thee.
22.65: And blaspheming, they continued to speak many other things against Him.
22.66: And when it was day, the eldership of the people was convened, and the chief priests and scribes, and they led Him into their sanhedrim.
22.67: Saying, If thou art the Christ, tell us. And He said to them, If I may tell you, you will not believe:
22.68: and if indeed I will ask you, you will not respond to me, or release me.
22.69: And from now the Son of man shall be sitting on the right hand of the power of God.
22.71: And they said, Why have we yet need of testimony? for we heard from His own mouth.

23.1: And all the multitude of them rising up, lead Him to Pilate.
23.2: And they began to accuse Him, saying, We found Him perverting the nation, and forbidding to give tribute to Caesar, saying that He is Christ, a King.
23.4: And Pilate said to the chief priests and the multitudes, I find nothing criminal in this man.
23.5: And they became stronger and stronger, saying, He stirs up the people, teaching throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee unto this place.
23.6: And Pilate hearing, asked if He is a Galilean man.
23.7: And learning that He is from the jurisdiction of Herod, he sent Him up to Herod, being himself in Jerusalem in those days.
23.8: And Herod seeing Jesus, rejoiced exceedingly: for from a long time, wishing to see Him, because He was hearing about Him; and he was hoping to see some miracle wrought by Him.
23.9: And he asked Him with many words; and He responded to him nothing.
23.10: But the high priest and scribes stood by, accusing Him vehemently.
23.11: But Herod along with his soldiers having indeed treated Him with contempt, and mocked Him, putting on Him a scarlet robe, sent Him back to Pilate.
23.12: And both Herod and Pilate on that day became friends with one another: for they were hitherto in enmity either to other.
23.13: Pilate having called together the chief priests and the rulers and the people,
23.14: said to them, You have brought to me this man, as revolutionizing the people: and behold, I, judging Him before you, found nothing in this man criminal of those things which you accuse against Him.
23.15: But Herod did not: for he sent Him back to us; and behold, nothing worthy of death has been done by Him.
23.16: Therefore having scourged Him, I will release Him.
23.19: who had been cast into prison on account of certain sedition made in the city, and murder.
23.20: Then Pilate again called to them, wishing to release Jesus.
23.22: And he spoke to them the third time, For what evil hath He done? I found nothing in Him worthy of death: therefore having scourged Him, I will release Him.
23.23: And they continued to lay on with great voices, demanding that He should be crucified: and the voices of them and the high priests continued to grow stronger.
23.24: And Pilate decided that their request should be granted.
23.25: And released him who on account of sedition and murder had been cast into prison, and delivered up Jesus according to their wish.
23.26: And when they were leading Him away, taking a certain Simon, a Cyrenean, coming from the country, they placed the cross on him, to carry it after Jesus.
23.27: And a great multitude of people followed Him, and of women who were both weeping and bewailing Him.
23.31: Because if they do these things in the green tree, what may be done in the dry?
23.32: And two malefactors were also led away with Him, to be executed.
23.33: And when they came to the place called Calvary. There they crucified Him, and the malefactors, one on the right and one on the left.
23.35: The people stood looking: and the rulers were even mocking with themselves, saying, He saved others; let Him save Himself, if He is the Christ, the elect of God.
23.36: And the soldiers were also mocking, coming and bringing the vinegar to Him,
23.37: and saying, If thou art the King of the Jews, save thyself.
23.38: And the superscription was also over Him: THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
23.41: and we indeed justly; for we are receiving the deservings of the things we did: but this one has done nothing amiss.
23.42: And he said to Jesus, Lord, remember me when thou mayest come in thy kingdom.
23.43: And Jesus said to him, Truly I say unto thee, This day shalt thou be with me in Paradise.
23.44: And it was about the sixth hour, and there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.
23.45: And the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was rent in the middle.
23.47: And the centurion seeing that which took place, glorified God, saying, Surely this was a righteous man.
23.48: And all the multitudes being present at that scene, seeing those things which took place, were going away beating their breasts.
23.49: And all His acquaintances stood a great way off and the women who having followed along with Him from Galilee, seeing these things.
23.50: And behold, there was a man by name Joseph, being a councilor, a good and righteous man,
23.51: (for he was not consenting unto their counsel and deed), from Arimathea, a city of the Jews, who also himself was looking for the kingdom of God.
23.52: He having come to Pilate, begged the body of Jesus.
23.53: And having taken it down, he wrapped it in linen, and placed it in a hewn sepulcher, where no one ever was laid.
23.54: And it was Preparation day, and the Sabbath was drawing nigh.
23.55: And the women, who had come along with him out of Galilee, having followed down, saw the sepulcher, and where His body was placed.
23.56: And having returned, they prepared aromatics and myrrh: and they kept the Sabbath according to the commandment.

24.1: And on the first of the Sabbath, at the depth of the dawn, they came to the sepulcher, bearing the aromatics which they had prepared,
24.2: And they found the stone, having been rolled away from the sepulcher.
24.3: And coming in they found not the body of the Lord Jesus.
24.4: And it came to pass, while they were at a loss concerning this, and behold, two men stood by them in shining garments:
24.5: and they being afraid, and turning their face towards the ground, they said to them, Why seek ye the living among the dead?
24.6: He is not here, but He is risen. Remember how He spoke to you, being with you in Galilee,
24.7: Saying That it behooveth the Son of man to be delivered into the hands of sinners, and to be crucified, and to rise again on the third day.
24.9: And having returned from the sepulcher, they proclaimed all these things to the eleven, and all the rest.
24.10: And Mary Magdalene, and Joanna, and Mary the mother of James: and the other women with them spoke these things to the apostles.
24.11: And their words appeared before them like a dream; and they doubted them.
24.13: And behold, two of them on that day were journeying to a village, distant from Jerusalem sixty furlongs, to which was the name Emmaus:
24.14: and they were conversing with one another concerning all those things which had transpired.
24.15: And it came to pass, while they are talking and making inquiry, Jesus Himself also having come nigh, journeyed along with them:
24.16: and their eyes were held so as not to recognize Him.
24.17: And He said to them, What speeches are these which you are interchanging to one another, walking along? And they stood still, looking sad.
24.19: And He said to them, What? And they said to Him, The things concerning Jesus the Nazarene, who was a prophet-man mighty in work and word before God and all the people.
24.20: How the chief priests and our rulers indeed delivered Him up to the condemnation of death, and they crucified Him.
24.21: But we were hoping that He is the one about to redeem Israel: but truly in addition to all these things, this is the third day from which these things took place.
24.22: But certain women from us truly surprised us, being early at the sepulcher;
24.23: and not seeing His body, came, saying, they had also seen a vision of angels, who say that He is alive.
24.24: And certain ones of those with us went away to the sepulcher, and found as the women also said: and they saw Him not.
24.25: And He said to them, O ye foolish, and slow in heart to believe in all those things which the prophet spoke!
24.26: Did it not behoove Christ to suffer, and to enter into His glory?
24.27: And beginning from Moses and all the prophets, He expounded to them in all the Scriptures, the things concerning Himself.
24.28: And they drew nigh to the village, whither they were going: and He made as though He would go further:
24.29: and they constrained Him, saying, Abide with us: because it is at the evening, and the day has already declined. And He came in to abide with them.
24.30: And it came to pass, while He was reclining with them at the table, taking bread, He blessed it, and breaking it, He gave it to them:
24.31: and their eyes were opened, and they recognized Him; and He vanished from them.
24.32: And they said to one another, Did not our heart bum within us, while He was talking to us on the way, as He was expounding the Scriptures to us?
24.33: And rising up the same hour, they returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven and those with them gathered together,
24.34: saying, The Lord indeed is risen, and was seen by Simon.
24.35: And they expounded those things on the way, and bow He was made known to them in the breaking of the bread.
24.36: And they speaking these things, He stood in their midst,
24.37: and they being affrighted and filled with fear, thought they saw a spirit.
24.38: And He said to them, Why are you excited, and why do reasonings arise in your heart?
24.39: See my hands and my feet, that I am He: feel me; and see, because a spirit has not flesh and bones, as you see me having.
24.42: And they gave Him a piece of baked fish:
24.43: and taking it, He did eat in their presence.
24.44: And He said to them, These are my words which I spoke to you, being still with you, that it behooves all things which have been written concerning me in the law of Moses, and the prophets, and the Psalms, to be fulfilled.
24.45: Then He opened their mind, that they might understand the Scriptures.
24.46: And He said to them, As it has been written, That Christ must suffer, and rise from the dead on the third day;
24.47: and repentance unto remission of sins is to be preached in His name to all nations, beginning from Jerusalem.
24.48: You are witnesses of these things.
24.49: And I send the promise of the Father upon you: and you tarry in the city, until you may be endued with power from on high.
24.50: And He led them out even unto Bethany; and having lifted up His hands, He blessed them.
24.51: And it came to pass, while He was blessing them, He departed from them, and was carried up into heaven.
24.52: And they returned to Jerusalem with great joy:
24.53: and were constantly in the temple, praising God.

1.1: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
1.2: The same was in the beginning with God.
1.3: All things were made by Him, and without Him nothing was made, that has been made.
1.4: In Him was life, and the life was the light of the men.
1.5: And the light shineth in the darkness, and the darkness comprehended it not.
1.6: There was a man having been sent from God, whose name was John;
1.7: The same came for a witness, that he might bear witness concerning the light, in order that all through him might believe.
1.8: He was not the light, but came that he might bear witness concerning the light.
1.9: That was the true light, which lighteth every man, coming into the world.
1.10: He was in the world, and the world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not.
1.11: He came unto His own, and His own received Him not.
1.12: But so many as received Him, to them gave He the right to become the children of God, to those believing on His name:
1.13: who were born not of bloods, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
1.14: The Word was made flesh, and tented among us (and we beheld His glory, the glory as of the only begotten with the Father), full of grace and truth.
1.15: John beareth witness concerning Him, and cried out saying; This is He of whom I spoke, He that cometh after me has been before me:
1.16: because He was my Creator. And of His fullness we all received grace upon grace.
1.17: Because the law was given by Moses; grace and truth came through Jesus Christ.
1.18: No one has ever seen God; the only begotten Son, the one being in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared him.
1.19: This is the testimony of John when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem, that they might ask him,
1.20: Who art thou? and he confessed and denied not, and confessed that, I am not the Christ.
1.22: And he responded, No. Then they said to him, Who art thou? that we may give an answer to those having sent us. What do you say concerning yourself?
1.23: I am the voice of one roaring in the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord as Isaiah the prophet said.
1.24: And those having been sent were of the Pharisees.
1.25: And they asked him, and said to him, Then why do you baptize, if you are not the Christ, nor Elijah, nor that prophet?
1.26: John responded to them, saying, I baptize with water: There standeth One in your midst whom you do not know,
1.27: the One coming after me, of whom I am not worthy that I may loose the latchet of His sandal.
1.28: These things took place in Bethany beyond the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
1.29: On the following day he sees Jesus coming to him, and says, Behold the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world.
1.31: And I did not know Him, but in order that He may be made manifest to Israel, on this account I came baptizing with water.
1.32: And John testified saying, I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and remained on Him.
1.33: And I did not know Him, but the One having sent me to baptize with water, He said to me, On whom you may see the Spirit descending and remaining on Him, He is the one baptizing with the Holy Ghost.
1.34: And I have seen, and testified that He is the Son of God.
1.35: On the following day John again stood, and two of his disciples,
1.36: and looking upon Jesus walking about, says, Behold, the Lamb of God.
1.37: And the two disciples heard him speaking and followed Jesus.
1.38: Jesus turning and seeing them following, says to them, What are you seeking? and they said to Him, Doctor, (which is said, being interpreted, Teacher), where dwellest thou?
1.40: Andrew, the brother of Simon Peter, was one of the two hearing from John, and follows Him;
1.41: he first finds his own brother Simon, and says to him, We have found Messiah, which is being interpreted, Christ.
1.42: He led him to Jesus. Jesus looking upon him said; Thou art Simon the Son of Jonah, thou shalt be called Cephas (which is interpreted, Peter).
1.44: Philip was from Bethsaida, of the city of Andrew and Peter.
1.45: Philip finds Nathanael and says to him, We have found Him, of whom Moses and the prophets, in the law, did write, Jesus the son of Joseph, who is from Nazareth.
1.47: Jesus saw Nathanael coming to Him, and says concerning him, Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom there is no guile.
1.49: Nathanael responded, Rabbi, thou art the Son of God, the King of Israel.
1.51: And He says to him, Truly, truly, I say unto you, you shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man.

2.1: On the third day there was a marriage in Cana of Galilee; and the mother of Jesus was there:
2.2: and Jesus and His disciples were invited to the marriage.
2.3: And they had no wine, because the wine of the marriage was exhausted. Then the mother of Jesus says to Him, There is no wine.
2.4: And Jesus says to her, What is that to me and to thee? O woman, my hour is not yet come.
2.5: His mother says to the servants, Do whatsoever He may say to you.
2.6: And there were six waterpots of stone sitting there according to the purification of the Jews, containing about two or three firkins. Jesus says to them,
2.8: And He says to them, Now draw out and carry to the chief ruler of the feast,
2.9: and they brought it to him. And when the ruler of the feast tasted the water, having been made wine, and did not know whence it is (but the servants having drawn the water knew), the ruler calls the groom,
2.11: Jesus did this, the beginning of miracles, in Cana of Galilee, and manifested His glory; and His disciples believed on Him.
2.12: After this He and His mother, and His brothers and His disciples went down into Capernaum, and abode there not many days.
2.13: And the passover of the Jews were nigh, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
2.14: And He found in the temple those selling oxen and sheep and doves, and the money-changers sitting:
2.15: and having made a scourge of cords, He cast all out of the temple, both the sheep and the oxen, and poured out the money of the exchangers, and over-turned the tables.
2.16: And He said to those selling doves; Take these things hence, make not the house of my Father a house of merchandise.
2.17: And His disciples remembered that it is written, The zeal of thy house doth eat me up.
2.18: Then the Jews responded and said to Him, What sign do you show us, because you do these things?
2.20: Then the Jews said, Forty and six years was this temple being built, and wilt thou rear it up in three days?
2.21: But He spoke concerning the temple of His body.
2.22: Then when He arose from the dead, His disciples remembered that He said these things, and believed the Scripture and words which Jesus spoke.
2.23: And when He was in Jerusalem at the feast, during the passover, many believed on His name, seeing His miracles which He was doing;
2.24: and Jesus did not intrust Himself to them because He knows all men,
2.25: and because He had no need that any one should witness concerning man; because He was knowing what was in man.

3.1: There was a man of the Pharisees, the name to him Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews;
3.2: the same came to Him by night, and said to Him, Rabbi, we know that thou hast come a teacher from God; for no one is able to do these miracles, which thou art doing, unless God may he with him.
3.3: Jesus responded and said to him, Truly, truly, I say unto thee, unless any one may be born from above, he is not able to see the kingdom of God.
3.4: Nicodemus says to him; How is a man able to be born, being old? whether he is able to enter the second time into the womb of his mother, and be born?
3.5: Jesus responded, Truly, truly, I say unto thee, Unless any one may be born of water and Spirit, he is not able to enter into the kingdom of the heavens.
3.6: That which has been born of the flesh is flesh; and that which has been born of the Spirit is spirit.
3.7: Be not astonished because I said to thee; It behooveth you to be born from above.
3.8: The Spirit breathes on whom He willeth, and thou hearest His voice, but dost not know whence He cometh and whither He goeth; so is every one who has been born of the Spirit.
3.9: Nicodemus responded and said to Him, How are these things able to he?
3.11: Truly, truly, I say unto thee, that we speak what we know, and testify what we have seen; and you received not our testimony.
3.12: If I spoke to you things upon the earth, and you do net believe, how will you believe, if I speak to you of things in heaven?
3.13: No one hath ascended up into heaven, but the one having come down from heaven, the Son of man, who is in heaven.
3.14: And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so does it behoove the Son of man to be lifted up:
3.15: that every one believing in Him may have eternal life.
3.17: For God sent not His Son into the world that He may condemn the world; but that the world through Him may be saved.
3.18: He that believeth on Him is not condemned; but he that believeth not, has already been condemned, because he has not believed on the name of the only begotten Son of God.
3.19: And this is the condemnation, that light has come into the world, and men love darkness rather than light; for their works are evil.
3.20: For every one doing evil hates the light, and does not come to the light, in order that his works may not be convicted;
3.21: but every one doing the truth comes to the light, that his works may be made manifest, because they have been wrought in God.
3.22: After these things Jesus and His disciples came into the Judean country; and there He was tarrying with them and baptizing.
3.23: And John was also baptizing in Enon near Salim, because there were many waters there: and they came and baptized.
3.24: For John was not yet cast into prison.
3.25: And there was a disputation of the disciples of John, concerning purifying.
3.26: And they came to John, and said to him, Rabbi, He who is with thee beyond the Jordan, to whom thou hast borne witness, behold, the same baptizeth, and all are coming to Him.
3.28: You are witnessing to me, that I said, I am not the Christ, but that I am sent before Him.
3.29: The one having the bride is the Bridegroom: but the friend of the Bridegroom is the one standing and hearing him, rejoiceth with joy on account of the Bridegroom: This, my joy has been made complete.
3.30: It behooveth Him to increase, and me to decrease.
3.31: He that cometh from above is above all;
3.32: the one being of the earth is of the earth, and speaks of the earth. The one coming from heaven witnesses what He has seen and heard, and no one receives His testimony.
3.33: The one having received His testimony hath set his seal, that God is true.
3.34: For whom God sent speaketh the words of God: for He does not give His spirit by measure.
3.35: The Father loves the Son, and has given all things in His hands.
3.36: He that believes on the Son has eternal life; but he that believeth not the Son shall not see life, but the wrath of God abideth on him.

4.1: Thus when the Lord knew when the Pharisees heard that Jesus is making and baptizing more disciples than John
4.2: (truly Jesus himself was not baptizing, but His disciples),
4.3: He left Judea and came again into Galilee.
4.4: And it behooved Him to go through Samaria.
4.5: Then He comes into a city of Samaria, called Sychar, near the place which Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
4.6: And the well of Jacob was there. Then Jesus having become weary from the journey, was sitting thus by the well: it was about the sixth hour.
4.7: A woman comes from Samaria to draw water. Jesus says to her, Give me to drink.
4.8: For His disciples had gone into the city, that they might purchase food.
4.9: A Samaritan woman says to Him, How do you, being a Jew, ask to drink from me, being a Samaritan woman?
4.10: And Jesus responded and said to her, If you knew the gift of God, and the one who is speaking to you, Give me to drink; you would have asked him, and he would have given you living water.
4.11: The woman says to Him, Sir, thou hast no windlass, and the well is deep: whence hast thou living water?
4.12: Art thou greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well, and himself and his sons, and his herds, drank of it?
4.14: but whosoever may drink of the water that I shall give to him shall never thirst; but the water which I shall give to him shall be in him a well of water springing up unto eternal life.
4.15: Then the woman says to Him, Sir, give me this water, that I may not thirst, nor come hither to draw.
4.16: He says to her, Go, call thy husband, and come hither.
4.17: The woman responded and said, I have no husband. Jesus says to her, Well didst thou say, I have no husband:
4.18: for thou hast had five husbands; and he whom thou now hast is not thy husband: thou hast spoken this truly.
4.19: The woman says to Him, Sir, I perceive that thou art a prophet.
4.20: Our fathers worshiped in this mountain; and you say, that in Jerusalem is the place where it behooveth to worship.
4.22: You worship, you know not what: we worship that which we know: because salvation is of the Jews.
4.23: But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and in truth: for the Father seeketh such worshiping Him.
4.24: God is a Spirit, and it behooveth those who worship Him to worship in spirit and in truth.
4.25: The woman says to Him, I know that Messiah cometh (who is called Christ): when He may come, He will proclaim to us all things.
4.26: Jesus says to her, I who speak to thee am He.
4.27: And at this time His disciples came, and were wondering because He was speaking with the woman; no one said, What seekest thou? or, Why do you speak with her?
4.28: Then the woman left her waterpot, and went away into the city, and says to the men,
4.30: They came out from the city, and came to Him.
4.31: Meanwhile His disciples were asking Him, saying, Master eat.
4.32: He said to them, I have meat to eat, which you know not.
