19.13: And certain ones of the itinerant Jewish exorcists undertook to call the name of the Lord Jesus, over those having evil spirits saying, I adjure you in the name of Jesus whom Paul is preaching.
19.14: And there were certain seven sons of one Sceva, a Jewish high priest, doing this.
19.15: But the evil spirit responding said to them, I know Jesus, and am acquainted with Paul; but who are you?
19.16: And the man in whom was the evil spirit, leaping on them, domineering over both of them, prevailed against them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded.
19.17: And this became known to all, both Jews and Greeks, dwelling at Ephesus; and fear fell upon them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified;
19.18: and many of those having believed came, confessing, and renouncing their practices.
19.19: And many of those practicing curious arts, having brought their books, burnt them before all: and they estimated the price of them, and found it to be fifty thousand pieces of silver.
19.20: Thus the word of the Lord increased and accumulated strength according to His power.
19.22: And having sent two of those ministering to him, Timothy and Erastus, into Macedonia, himself spent the time in Asia.
19.23: And at that time there was no small commotion concerning the way.
19.24: For a certain Demetrius by name, a silversmith, making silver shrines of Diana, was bringing no small gain to the mechanics,
19.25: whom having assembled and the laborers about such things, he said, Men, you know that it is from this work that prosperity is to us:
19.26: and you see and hear, that not only at Ephesus, but almost throughout all Asia, that this Paul having persuaded them has turned away a great multitude, saying that there are no gods made with hands.
19.27: And not only is this interest in danger to us to come into disrepute; but even the temple of the great goddess Diana to be considered for nought, and they are about even to despise the majesty of her, whom all Asia and the world worships.
19.28: And hearing and being filled with rage, they continued to cry out, saying, Great is Diana of the Ephesians.
19.29: And the city was filled with commotion: and they rushed of one accord into the theatre, seizing Gaius and Aristarchus, the Macedonians, the companions of Paul.
19.30: And Paul wishing to go in unto the people, the disciples suffered him not;
19.31: and certain ones of the Asiatic rulers, also being friends to him, having sent to him, continued to entreat him not to give himself up into the theatre.
19.32: Then indeed they continued to cry out some one thing, and some another: for the church was confused; and the most of them did not know on account of what they had come together.
19.33: And some from the crowd forced in Alexander, the Jews precipitating him forward; and Alexander, beckoning with his hand, wished to apologize to the people.
19.34: But recognizing that he is a Jew, there was one voice from all crying out about two hours, Great is Diana of the Ephesians.
19.35: And the city clerk having dismissed the multitudes, said, Ephesian men, for what one of men is there that does not know that the city of the Ephesians is a worshiper of the great goddess Diana, and of the statue having fallen down from Jupiter?
19.36: Therefore these things being unquestionable, it is necessary that you become calm, and do nothing rashly.
19.37: For you have led in these men, who are neither robbers of temples, nor are they blaspheming your goddess.
19.38: If indeed therefore Demetrius, and the mechanics along with him, have a charge against any one, the courts are in session, and there are lawyers: let them implead one another.
19.39: But if you are seeking something concerning other things, it shall be settled in the lawful church.
19.40: For indeed we are in danger of prosecution for the disturbance this day, there being no cause concerning which we shall be able to give a reason for this uproar.
19.41: And having said these things, he dismissed the church.

20.1: After the uproar ceased, Paul, having sent for the disciples and exhorted them, bidding them adieu, departed to go into Macedonia.
20.2: And having come through those regions, and exhorted them with much speaking, he came into Greece;
20.3: and having remained three months, a plot rising against him from the Jews, when about to sail for Syria, he was of a mind to return through Macedonia.
20.4: And Sopater the (son) of Pyrrhus, the Berean, and Aristarchus, the Thessalonian, and Secundus; and Gaius the Derbean, and Timothy; and Tychicus and Trophimus the Asiatics, accompanied him;
20.5: and these having gone in advance, awaited us in Troas;
20.6: and we, after the days of unleaven bread, sailed from Philippi, and came to them into Troas within five days; where we spent seven days.
20.7: And on the first of the Sabbaths we being assembled to break bread, Paul spoke to them, being about to depart the following day, and continued his discourse till midnight:
20.8: and there were many lamps in the upper room, where we were assembled.
20.9: Paul speaking more prolixly, there was a certain young man, Eutychus by name, sitting in the window, being borne down with deep sleep, completely relaxed by sleep, fell down from the third story, and was taken up dead.
20.11: and having come up, and broken the bread, and eaten, and talking a long time, until daydawn, thus he departed.
20.12: And they led up the boy alive, and were comforted exceedingly.
20.13: But we, having come in advance to the ship, embarked for Assos, thence being about to take up Paul, for he had so commanded us, himself being about to go on foot.
20.14: And when he met us at Assos, taking him up, we came to Mitylene.
20.15: And thence having sailed away on the following day we arrived opposite Chios; and on the following day we touched at Samos, and on the next day we came into Miletus.
20.16: For Paul decided to sail by Ephesus, in order that it might not be necessary for him to spend the time in Asia: for he was hastening, if it might be possible for him to be in Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost.
20.17: And having sent from Miletus into Ephesus, he called for the elders of the church.
20.18: And when they came to him, he said to them, You know, that from the first day from which I came unto Asia, how I was with you all the time,
20.19: serving the Lord with all humility, and tears, and temptations, which came upon me through the plots of the Jews:
20.20: how I omitted nothing of those things which are profitable, that I should not declare unto you and teach you publicly and from house to house,
20.21: witnessing both to Jews, and to Greeks, repentance toward God, and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ.
20.23: except that the Holy Ghost in every city witnesses to me, saying that bonds and tribulations await me.
20.24: But I consider my life worthy of no consideration to myself, so as to finish my course, and the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus, to bear testimony to the gospel of the grace of God.
20.25: And now, behold, I know that you all, among whom I came preaching the gospel of the kingdom, shall see my face no more.
20.26: Therefore I witness to you this clay, that I am pure from the blood of all men;
20.27: for I did not shrink to declare unto you all the counsel of God.
20.28: Take heed to yourselves, and all the flock, over which the Holy Ghost has placed you shepherds, to shepherdise the church of God, which He bought with His own blood.
20.29: I know, that after my departure grievous wolves will rise up against you, not sparing the flock;
20.30: and men from you yourselves will rise up, speaking perverse things, in order to lead away disciples after them.
20.31: Watch therefore, remembering, that three years night and day I ceased not admonishing you with tears.
20.32: And now I commend you to God and the word of His grace, who is able to edify you, and give you an inheritance among all the sanctified.
20.33: I have not sought the silver, or gold, or raiment of any one;
20.34: you yourselves know, that these hands did minister to my necessities, and those along with me.
20.35: I have shown you all things, that it so behooveth you laboring to assist the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that He said, It is more blessed to give than to receive.
20.36: And having said these things, putting down his knees along with them all, he prayed.
20.37: And the weeping of all was great, and falling on the neck of Paul, they continued to kiss him copiously,
20.38: being especially grieved at the word which he had spoken, that they were about to see his face no more. And they accompanied him to the ship.

21.1: And when it came to pass, that we having been farewelled by them, embarked, sailing straight forward, we arrived at Cos, and on the following day to Rhodes, and thence to Patara.
21.2: And finding a ship sailing into Phoenicia, having embarked, we moved out.
21.3: And coming in sight of Cyprus, and leaving it on the left, we sailed to Syria, and disembarked at Tyre: for there the ship was delivering her cargo.
21.4: And finding disciples, we tarried there seven days: who continued to say to Paul through the Spirit, that he should not go to Jerusalem.
21.5: And when it came to pass that we refitted during those days, having come out, we departed, all sending us forth, along with the women and children, out of the city: and putting down the knees on the shore, having prayed,
21.6: we farewelled one another, and went up into the ship; and they returned to their own homes.
21.7: And we continuing our voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, and having saluted the brethren, we remained with them one day.
21.8: And on the following day, having come out, we came into Caesarea: and having entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, being one of the seven, we abode with him.
21.9: And there were to him four virgin daughters, prophesying.
21.10: And we remaining many days, a certain prophet, by name Agabus, came down from Judea;
21.11: and having come to us, and taking the girdle of Paul, binding his own feet and hands, said, These things says the Holy Ghost, The man whose girdle this is, will the Jews in Jerusalem bind and deliver into the hands of the Gentiles.
21.12: And when we heard these words, both we, and the citizens, exhorted him not to go up to Jerusalem.
21.13: Then Paul responded and said, What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? for I am ready not only to be bound, but to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
21.14: And he not being persuaded, we acquiesced, saying, Let the will of the Lord be done.
21.15: And after those days, taking our luggage, we went up to Jerusalem:
21.16: and some of the disciples from Caesarea went along with us, bringing Mnason a certain Cyprian, an old disciple, with whom we should lodge.
21.17: And we being in Jerusalem, the brethren received us gladly.
21.18: And on the following day, Paul goes with us to James; and all the elders assembled.
21.19: And having saluted them, he related each one of those things which God did among the Gentiles through his ministry.
21.20: And they hearing, continued to glorify God, and said to him, You see, brother, how many myriads there are of those who believe; and they are all zealots of the law:
21.21: and they have been informed concerning thee, that thou art teaching all the Jews who are among the Gentiles apostasy from Moses, saying that they are not to circumcise their children, nor to walk according to the customs.
21.22: Then what is it? it is altogether necessary that the multitude come together: for they will hear that you have come.
21.23: Therefore do this which we tell thee. There are four men among us having a vow upon them;
21.24: taking them, be purified along with them, and be at charges for them, that they may shave their head: and all shall know that there is nothing of those things they have been informed concerning thee; but that thyself art walking, keeping the law.
21.25: But concerning the Gentiles who have believed, we have sent to them, adjudicating that they keep themselves from idolatry, and blood, and strangulation, and fornication.
21.26: Then Paul, having taken the men, the next day being purified along with them, enters into the temple, proclaiming the fulfillment of the days of purification, until an offering may be made for each one of them.
21.27: And when the seven days were about to have an end, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole multitude, and laid hands on him, crying out,
21.28: Israelitish men, help: this is the man, teaching all everywhere against the people, and the law, and this place, and he has even yet led Greeks into the temple, and polluted this holy place.
21.29: For they saw Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, whom they supposed that Paul led into the temple.
21.30: And the whole city was excited, and there was a commotion of the people: and taking Paul, they dragged him out of the temple; and immediately the doors were closed.
21.31: And seeking to kill him, the report went up to the chiliarch of the band, that all Jerusalem is in commotion;
21.32: who immediately, taking soldiers and centurions, ran to them: and they, seeing the chiliarch and the soldiers, ceased beating Paul.
21.33: Then the chiliarch, having come nigh, took Paul, and commanded that he should be bound with two chains; and was making inquiry who he might be, and what he had done.
21.34: And they continued to cry aloud in the multitude, some one thing, and some another: and he, being unable to know the certainty on account of the uproar, commanded that he should be led into the castle.
21.35: Then when he was on the threshold, it happened that he was carried by the soldiers, on account of the violence of the mob;
21.36: for the multitude of the people were following, crying out, Take him away.
21.38: Are you not that Egyptian who before these days rising up and leading away into the desert four hundred men of daggers?
21.39: But Paul said, I am indeed a Jewish man, a Tarsean, a citizen of Cilicia, no mean city: but, I pray you, permit me to speak to the people.
21.40: And he permitting, Paul, standing on the threshold, beckoned with his hand to the people: and there being great silence, he spoke to them in the Hebrew tongue, saying:

22.2: And hearing that he was speaking to them in the Hebrew tongue, they kept silent the more.
22.3: And he says, I am Jewish man, having been born in Tarsus of Cilicia, having been brought up in this city, educated at the feet of Gamaliel according to the accuracy of patristic law, being a zealot of God, as you all are this day;
22.4: who after this way persecuted unto death, binding and committing to prison both men and women;
22.5: as the high priest also, and all the eldership, witnessed me: from whom having also received letters from the brethren in Damascus, I was on my way, being about to lead them also hither into Jerusalem bound, that they might be punished.
22.7: and I felt upon the ground, and heard a voice, saying to me, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
22.8: And I responded, Who art thou, Lord? And He said to me, I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom thou art persecuting.
22.9: And those being along with me saw the light indeed, but heard not the voice of the one speaking to me.
22.11: And when I did not see on account of the glory of that light, and being led by the hand by those journeying with me, I came into Damascus.
22.14: And he said, The God of our fathers hath chosen thee to know His will, and see the Just One, and hear the voice from His mouth;
22.15: because thou shalt be a witness for Him to all men of those things which thou hast seen and heard.
22.16: And now why tarriest thou? arising, be baptized, and wash away thy sins, calling on His name.
22.17: And it happened unto me, having returned into Jerusalem, and while I was praying in the temple, I was in an ecstasy;
22.18: and I saw Him speaking to me, Hasten, and depart quickly out of Jerusalem, because they will not receive thy testimony concerning me.
22.19: And I said, Lord, they know that I was imprisoning and binding those believing on thee throughout the synagogue;
22.20: and when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I was standing by, and consenting, and keeping the garments of those killing him.
22.21: And He said to me, Go: because I will send thee far away to the Gentiles.
22.22: And they continued to hear him until this word, and lifted up their voice, saying, Take away such a one from the earth: for it is not appropriate for him to live.
22.23: And they crying out, and rending their garments, and throwing dust into the air,
22.24: the chiliarch commanded that he should be led into the castle, saying that he should be tested by scourges, in order that he might know on account of what cause they continued so to cry out against him.
22.25: And when they were extending him to the scourges, Paul said to the centurion standing by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man who is a Roman, and uncondemned?
22.26: And the centurion hearing, having come to the chiliarch, announced to him, saying, What are you about to do? for this man is a Roman.
22.27: And the chiliarch, having come to him, said; Tell me, are you a Roman? And he said, Yes.
22.29: Then immediately those about to scourge him departed from him: and the chiliarch also feared, knowing that he was a Roman, and that he had bound him.
22.30: And on the following day, wishing to know the certainty as to what he is accused of by the Jews, he loosed him, and commanded the chief priests and all the sanhedrin to come together, and leading down Paul, he placed him in their midst.

23.2: And the high priest Ananias commanded those standing near him to smite him in the mouth.
23.3: Then Paul said to him, God is about to smite thee, thou whitewashed wall: indeed thou art sitting judging me according to the law, and dost thou command me to be smitten contrary to the law?
23.7: And he speaking this, there was a dissension of the Pharisees and Sadducees: and the multitude was divided.
23.8: For the Sadducees indeed say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit: but the Pharisees confess both.
23.9: And there was a great clamor: and certain ones of the scribes on the part of the Pharisees, rising up, continued to strive, saying, We find nothing evil in this man: but has a spirit or an angel spoken to him?
23.10: And the dissension being great, the chiliarch fearing lest Paul may be torn to pieces by them, commanded the army, having gone down, to take him from their midst, and lead him into the castle.
23.11: And on the following night, the Lord standing over him, said, Take courage: for as thou hast testified to the things concerning me in Jerusalem, so it behooveth thee also to testify to me in Rome.
23.12: And it being day, the Jews having formed a conspiracy, obligated themselves by an oath, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they might kill Paul.
23.13: And there were more than forty having made this plot:
23.14: who, having come to the chief priests and elders, said, We have anathematized ourselves with an anathema, to taste nothing until we may kill Paul.
23.15: Now therefore do you appeal to the chiliarch along with the sanhedrim, that he may lead him down to you, as about to investigate matters concerning him more thoroughly: and we are ready to kill him before he comes nigh.
23.16: And the son of Paul's sister, having heard of ambuscade, coming and entering into the castle, reported it to Paul.
23.17: And Paul, having called one of the centurions, said, Lead this young man to the chiliarch: for he has something to tell him.
23.18: Then indeed taking him, he led him to the chiliarch, and says, Paul the prisoner, having called me, requested me to lead this young man to you, having something to tell you.
23.19: And the chiliarch taking him by the hand, and having gone away privately, asked him, What is that which you have to tell me?
23.20: And he said, The Jews have entered into an agreement to ask you that to-morrow you may lead Paul to the sanhedrim, as about to make inquiry as to something more definite concerning him.
23.21: Therefore do not be persuaded by them: for more than forty of them lie in wait for him, who have obligated themselves by an oath, neither to eat nor drink until they may kill him: and now they are ready, awaiting the promise from you.
23.23: And having called a certain two of the centurions, he said, Get ready two hundred soldiers that they may go unto Caesarea, and seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen, from the third hour of the night;
23.24: and prepare beasts of burden, that, having carried away Paul, you may deliver him safe to Felix the governor.
23.25: Writing a letter having this form:
23.26: Claudius Lysias to the most noble governor Felix, greeting.
23.27: This man, having been taken by the Jews, and being about to be put to death by them, having interposed with my army, I took out of their hands, having learned that he is a Roman:
23.28: and wishing to know the cause on account of which they clamored against him, I led him into their sanhedrim:
23.29: whom I found accused concerning questions of their law, having no charge worthy of death or bonds.
23.30: And a plot from them being revealed to me to be against the man, I sent him to thee, having commanded his accusers also to speak in thy presence.
23.31: Then indeed the soldiers, according to that which had been commanded them, taking Paul led him by night to Antipatris:
23.32: And on the following day letting the cavalry go on with him, they returned to the castle.
23.33: Who, having come into Caesarea, and delivered the letter to the governor, also committed Paul to him.
23.34: And having read, and made inquiry of what jurisdiction,
23.35: and ascertaining that he is from Cilicia, said, I will hear thee, when thy accusers may also be present, having commanded that he should be kept in Herod's judgment hall.

24.1: And after five days Ananias the high priest with certain elders, and a certain orator Tertyllus, came down, who appeared before the governor against Paul.
24.2: And he having been called, Tertyllus began to accuse him, saying,
24.3: Receiving great peace through thee, and prosperity accruing to this nation through thy wisdom, we receive with all gratitude, both always, and everywhere, O most noble Felix.
24.4: But in order that I may not weary you excessively, I exhort you to hear us patiently according to your clemency.
24.5: For having found this man pestilential, and stirring up seditions to all the Jews who are throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes:
24.6: who also endeavored to pollute the temple: whom we indeed arrested,
24.8: with whom you yourself, having made inquiry, are able to know concerning all these things of which we accuse him.
24.9: And the Jews were consenting, saying, Truly these things are so.
24.10: And Paul responded, the governor beckoning to him to speak; Knowing you to be a judge to this nation from many years, I cheerfully apologize as to the things concerning myself:
24.11: you being able to know, that there are not more than twelve days to me since I came up to Jerusalem to worship.
24.12: Neither did they find me in the temple disputing with any one, or causing an excitement of the multitude, neither in the synagogues, nor throughout the city:
24.13: neither are they able to prove before you the things which they are now accusing me.
24.14: But I confess this to you, that according to the way which they call heresy, so worship I the God of our fathers, believing all things which have been written in the law and in the prophets:
24.15: having hope towards God, which they themselves also receive, that there is going to be a resurrection, both of the just and unjust.
24.16: In this I also exercise, to always have a conscience void of offense toward God and men.
24.17: And after many years I came to do alms and offerings to my race;
24.18: in which they found me having been purified in the temple, not with rabble, nor with an uproar; and were certain Jews from Asia,
24.19: whom it behooves to be present before me, and accuse me, if they should have anything against me.
24.20: Or let them tell what injustice they found, while I was standing before the sanhedrim,
24.21: except concerning this one voice, which I cried out standing in their midst, that concerning the resurrection of the dead I am judged before you this day.
24.22: And Felix having learned more thoroughly the things concerning the way, deferred them, saying, When Lysias the chiliarch may come down, I will diagnose the things appertaining to you:
24.23: having commanded the centurion to keep him, and let him have liberty, and prohibit no one of his friends from ministering unto him.
24.24: And after certain day, Felix with Drusilla his wife, being a Jewess, coming, sent for Paul, and heard him concerning the faith which is towards Christ Jesus.
24.25: And he reasoning concerning righteousness and temperance and the coming judgment, Felix, being alarmed, responded, Go thy way for this time; and having received an opportunity, I will call for thee:
24.26: at the same time also hoping that money will be given to him by Paul; therefore indeed the more frequently sending for him, he conversed with him.
24.27: But two years having passed away Felix received Porcius Festus as his successor: and Felix, wishing to confer on the Jews a favor, left Paul bound.

25.1: Then Festus having entered upon his office, after three days went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem;
25.2: and both the chief priests and the first men of the Jews appeared before him against Paul, and continued to entreat him,
25.3: asking favor against him, in order that he might send him to Jerusalem, making a plot to kill him on the road.
25.4: Then indeed Festus responded, that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and himself was about to go away quickly:
25.5: Then, says he, Let the influential ones among you, coming down, accuse him, if there is anything wrong in the man.
25.6: And having tarried with them not more than eight or ten days, having come down to Caesarea, on the following day, sitting on the tribunal, he commanded that Paul should be brought forth.
25.7: And he being present, the Jews having come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing against him charges many and heavy, which they were not able to prove.
25.8: And Paul apologizing, that Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar, have I done anything wrong.
25.10: And Paul said, I am standing at the tribunal of Caesar, where it behooves me to be judged. To the Jews I have done nothing wrong, as you indeed well know.
25.11: If therefore I indeed am guilty of unrighteousness, and have done anything worthy of death, I do not ask not to die: but if nothing of these things of which they accuse me is true, no man is able to gratify them (by my death): I appeal unto Caesar.
25.12: Then Festus, having spoken with the council, responded, Thou hast appealed unto Caesar; thou shalt go unto Caesar.
25.13: And some days having passed away, king Agrippa and Bernice came down to Caesarea, saluting Festus.
25.14: And while they were spending many days there, Festus expounded to the king the matters appertaining to Paul, saying, A certain man has been left a prisoner by Felix:
25.15: concerning whom, I being in Jerusalem, the chief priests and elders of the Jews appeared before me, asking condemnation against him;
25.16: to whom I responded, that it is not the customs to the Romans to slay any man gratuitously, before that the accused may have his accusers face to face, and receive a place of defence concerning the charge.
25.17: Then they, having come together to this place, making no delay, immediately sitting on the judgment-seat, I commanded that the man should be led forth;
25.18: concerning whom his accusers standing by, brought no evil charge of those things which I supposed:
25.19: but they had certain questions against him concerning their own religion, and about a certain Jesus, who is dead, whom Paul was saying that He is alive.
25.20: And I, being at a loss as to the question concerning these things, asked him if he is willing to go to Jerusalem, and there to be judged concerning these things.
25.21: And Paul having demanded that he should be kept for the diagnosis of Augustus, I demanded that he should be kept until I shall send him to Caesar.
25.22: And Agrippa said to Festus, I myself also would wish to hear the man. He says, To-morrow you shall hear him.
25.23: Then on the following day, Agrippa and Bernice having come with great pomp, and entering into the auditorium, along with the chiliarchs, and chief men of the city, and, Festus commanding, Paul was led forth.
25.24: And Festus says, O king Agrippa, and all ye men present with us, you see this man, concerning whom the whole multitude of the Jews is besieging me, both at Jerusalem and here, crying out that it does not behoove him to live any longer.
25.25: But I discovered that he had done nothing worthy of death, however he himself appealing to Caesar, I decided to send him.
25.26: Concerning whom I have nothing definite to write to my lord; therefore I have led him to you, and especially to thee, O king Agrippa, in order that, there being an investigation, I may have something which I shall write;
25.27: for it seems to me to be unreasonable, sending a prisoner, and not to signify charges against him.

26.1: And Agrippa said to Paul, It is permitted to thee to speak for thyself. Then Paul reaching forth his hand, proceeded with his defence:
26.2: O king Agrippa, I consider myself happy, being about this day to make my defence before thee concerning all those things of which I am accused by the Jews:
26.3: especially as thou art acquainted with all the customs and questions among the Jews: therefore I pray you to hear me patiently.
26.4: Moreover indeed all the Jews know my life from my youth; being from the beginning in my nation and in Jerusalem,
26.5: knowing me originally, if they may be willing to testify, that according to the most rigid sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
26.6: And now for the hope of the promise which is from God to our fathers, I stand being judged:
26.7: unto which our twelve tribes constantly worshiping night and day, hope to attain: concerning which hope I am accused by the Jews, O king.
26.8: Why is it judged by you incredible, if God shall raise the dead?
26.9: Moreover indeed, I thought to myself that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus the Nazarene:
26.10: which I did also in Jerusalem, and shut up many of the saints in prison; and having received authority from the chief priests, and they being slain, I gave my vote against them;
26.11: and throughout all the synagogues, frequently punishing them, I compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceeding mad against them, I was persecuting them even also unto foreign cities.
26.12: Meanwhile journeying to Damascus with power and authority of the chief priests, I saw on the way, O king,
26.13: about midday, a light from heaven above the brightness of the sun, shining around me and those traveling with me;
26.14: and we all having fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? it is hard for thee to kick against goads.
26.15: And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou art persecuting.
26.16: But rise up, and stand upon thy feet: for unto this have I appeared unto thee, to make thee a minister and a martyr both of those things which thou hast seen, and of which I will appear unto thee;
26.17: delivering thee from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee,
26.18: to open their eyes, to turn them from darkness unto light, and from the power of Satan unto God, in order that they may receive remission of sins, and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in me.
26.19: Therefore, O king, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision:
26.20: but first to those in Damascus, and also in Jerusalem, and throughout all the country of Judea, and to the Gentiles, I was preaching that they should repent and turn to God, doing things worthy of repentance.
26.21: On account of these things the Jews, taking me while in the temple, endeavored to kill me.
26.22: Then having received help from God, I have stood unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses said were about to come to pass:
26.23: how that Christ must suffer, how being the first from the resurrection of the dead, he is to proclaim light both to the people, and the Gentiles.
26.24: And he making his defence to these things, Festus says with a loud voice, O Paul, thou art beside thyself; many writings turned thee into insanity.
26.25: But Paul says, I am not a maniac, most noble Festus; but I speak forth the words of truth and soberness.
26.26: For the king, to whom I also speak boldly, knows concerning these things: for I am persuaded that nothing of these things is hidden; for this has not been done in a corner.
26.27: O king Agrippa, dost thou believe the prophets? I know that thou believest them.
26.29: And Paul said, I would to God, that both in little and in much, not only you, but also all of those hearing me this day, were such as I am, except these bonds.
26.30: And the king, and the governor, and Bernice, and those sitting with them, arose up:
26.31: and having gone away, they were talking to one another, saying, that This man is doing nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
26.32: But Agrippa said to Festus, This man was able to have been released, if he had not appealed to Caesar.

27.1: And when it was determined that we should sail away into Italy, they committed both Paul and certain other prisoners to the centurion, Julius by name, of the band of Augustus.
27.2: And having embarked on an Adramyttium ship, about to sail to those places along Asia, we set sail; Aristarchus, the Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
27.3: And on the following day we disembarked at Sidon; and Julius, treating Paul kindly, permitted him having gone to his friends to receive their benefactions.
27.4: And having embarked from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary:
27.5: and having sailed through the sea which is opposite Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came down into Myra of Lycia.
27.6: And there the centurion having found an Alexandrian ship sailing into Italy; transferred us into it.
27.7: And sailing slowly during many days, and were come with difficulty over against Cnidus, the wind not favoring us, we sailed under Crete, opposite Salmone;
27.8: and, with difficulty passing by it, we came into a certain place called Fair Havens, near to which was the city Lasea.
27.9: And much time passing away, and navigation being already unsafe, because the Fast had already passed by, Paul exhorted them,
27.10: saying to them, Men, I perceive that this voyage is going to be with peril and much loss, not only with the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.
27.11: But the centurion trusted the pilot and midshipman, rather than the things spoken by Paul.
27.12: And the harbor being unsafe for spending the winter, most of them projected to the council to depart thence, if perchance they might be able, having arrived into Phoenix, to spend the winter there; a harbor of Crete, looking toward the southeast and the northeast.
27.13: And the south wind blowing, thinking they could achieve their purpose, lifting up a sail, they went coasting along near Crete.
27.14: Not long afterward a typhonic wind, called Euraquilo, set in against her;
27.15: and the ship having been seized, and being unable to resist the wind, having given away to it, we were borne along.
27.16: And running under a certain island called Clauda, we were scarcely able to get possession of the boat:
27.17: which lifting up they used helps, under-girding the ship; and fearing lest they might fall into Syrtis, lowering the gear, they were thus carried along.
27.18: And we being tossed violently by the storm, they were successively making the casting out,
27.19: and on the third day with their own hands they threw overboard the tackling of the ship;
27.20: and neither sun nor stars appearing for many days, and there being no small tempest on us, finally all hope of saving us was taken away.
27.21: And there being much fasting, Paul standing in their midst, said, O men, truly it behooved you obeying me, not to depart from Crete, and incur this injury and loss.
27.22: And now I exhort you to take courage: for there will be no loss of the life of you, except the ship.
27.23: For the angel of God, whose I am, and whom indeed I serve, stood by me this night,
27.25: Therefore cheer up, O men: for I believe God, that it shall be according to the manner which He has spoken to me.
27.26: But it behooves us to fall upon a certain island.
27.27: And when it was the fourteenth night, we being borne along in the Adriatic Sea, about the middle of the night the sailors surmised that some country was coming to them.
27.28: And having sounded, they found it twenty fathoms; and moving on a short distance, and sounding again, they found it fifteen fathoms;
27.29: and fearing lest they may fall out against rough places, casting four anchors from the stern, they were praying that the day should come.
27.30: And the sailors seeking to escape from the ship, and lowering the boat into the sea, with a pretext as about to cast anchors from the prow,
27.31: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, Unless these may remain in the ship, you are not able to be saved.
27.32: Then the soldiers cut the ropes away from the boat, and let it fall out.
27.33: But until the day was about to come, Paul exhorted all to take food, saying, Already this day you remain in a state of solicitude, the fourteenth day, receiving nothing.
27.34: Therefore I exhort you to take food: for this is for your safety: for not a hair of your head shall perish.
27.35: And having spoken these words, and taken bread, he gave thanks to God in the presence of all, and breaking it, began to eat.
27.36: And all becoming cheerful, themselves also took food.
27.37: And we were two hundred and seventy-six souls in the ship.
27.38: And having been revived by the food, they lightened the ship, casting the wheat over into the sea.
27.39: And when it was day, they did not recognize the land: but discovered a certain gulf having a shore, into which they determined, if possible, to thrust out the ship.
27.40: And having knocked off the anchors, they left them in the sea, at the same time loosing the bands of the rudders, and raising up the main sail to the blowing wind, they made for the shore.
27.41: And having fallen into a place where two seas met, they broke the ship, and indeed the prow, sticking fast, remained motionless, but the stern was torn off by the violence (of the wind).
27.42: And the counsel of the soldiers was that they should kill the prisoners, lest some one, having outswum them, might escape:
27.43: but the centurion, wishing to save Paul, forbade them from their counsel; and commanded that those who were able to swim, having first thrown themselves overboard, to go to the land;
27.44: and the rest, some on planks, and others on some parts from the ship. And thus it came to pass that all came safe to the land.

28.1: And having been saved, we recognized that the island is called Melita.
28.2: And the barbarians extended no small philanthropy to us: for, having kindled a fire, they received us all to it, on account of the recent rain and cold.
28.3: And Paul having gathered up a certain bundle of sticks, and placed it on the fire, a viper, having come out from the heat, fastened on his hand.
28.4: But when the barbarians saw the beast hanging from his hand, they said to one another, Surely this man is a murderer, whom, having been saved from the sea, justice did not permit to live.
28.5: Then indeed, having shaken off the beast into the fire, he suffered no injury:
28.6: and they were looking for him to be about to swell up and suddenly fall down dead. But having looked a long time, and seeing nothing out of place come to him, changing their minds, they said that he was a god.
28.7: But in the regions around about that place there were farms belonging to the chief man of the island, by name Publius: who, having received us, entertained us courteously three days.
28.8: And it came to pass, that the father of Publius was lying prostrate with fevers and dysentery: to whom Paul having come in, and prayed, laying hands on him, healed him.
28.9: And this taking place, the rest also, on the island having diseases, continued to come to him, and be healed;
28.10: who also honored us with many honors; and conferred on us, departing, those things appertaining to use.
28.11: And after three months we embarked in an Alexandrian ship, having spent the winter in the island, dedicated to the sons of Jupiter.
28.12: And having disembarked into Syracuse, we remained three days;
28.13: thence having come circuitously, we arrived into Rhegium. And after one day there being a south wind, we came the second day to Puteoli,
28.14: where having found brethren, we were entreated to remain with them seven days: and thus we came into Rome.
28.15: And the brethren, hearing the news concerning us, came thence to meet us at the Appian Forum and Three Taverns: whom Paul, seeing, having given thanks to God, took courage.
28.16: And when we came into Rome, it was permitted to Paul to remain to himself with the soldier guarding him.
28.18: who judging me, were counseling to release me, because there was nothing worthy of death in me:
28.19: and the Jews speaking against it, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not having anything for which to accuse my nation.
28.20: Then for this cause I have called you, to see you, and talk to you: for on account of the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
28.21: And they said to him, Neither have we received letters from Judea concerning you, neither has any one of the brethren coming, proclaimed or spoken anything evil concerning you.
28.22: But we desire to hear from you what you think: for indeed concerning this sect, it is known to us that it is everywhere spoken against.
28.23: And having appointed a day with him, many came to him into his hired house, to whom witnessing he expounded the kingdom of God, indeed persuading them concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses, and the prophets, from morning unto evening.
28.24: And some of them indeed believed the things spoken, but others continued to doubt;
28.25: and they being disharmonious to one another, dispersed, Paul saying one word, that truly the Holy Ghost spoke through the prophet Isaiah to your fathers, saying,
28.26: Go to this people, and say, By hearing ye shall hear, and may not understand; and seeing you shall see, and may not perceive:
28.27: for the heart of this people is waxed gross, and they heard with their ears heavily, and closed their eyes; lest they may see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and turn, and I shall heal them.
28.28: Therefore let it be known unto you, that this salvation of God is sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear.
28.30: And he spent a whole biennium in his own hired house, and received all those coming to him,
28.31: preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things concerning the Lord Jesus, with all boldness, uninterruptedly.

1.1: Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called an apostle, having been separated unto the gospel of God,
1.2: which He proclaimed beforehand through His prophets in the holy scriptures,
1.3: concerning his Son, having been born of the seed of David according to the flesh;
1.4: having been ordained the Son of God with power, according to the spirit of holiness, from the resurrection of the dead, of Jesus Christ our Lord:
1.5: through whom we received grace and apostleship, unto obedience of faith among all the Gentiles, in behalf of his name:
1.6: among whom ye are also called of Jesus Christ:
1.7: to all the beloved of God who are in Rome, saints having been called. Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.8: In the first place, indeed, I praise my God through Jesus Christ for you all, because your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world.
1.9: For God is my witness, whom I serve in my spirit in the gospel of his Son, how I unceasingly make mention of you always in my prayer;
1.10: praying, if by any means I shall be prospered in the will of God to come to you.
1.11: For I long to see you, in order that I may impart unto you a certain spiritual grace, that you may be established;
1.12: but this is the consolation among you through faith in one another, both of you and me.
1.13: But I do not wish you to be ignorant, brethren, that frequently I purposed to come to you, and was hindered hitherto, in order that I may have some fruit among you, as well as also among other Gentiles.
1.14: I am debtor both to the Greeks, and to the barbarians; both to the wise, and the unwise:
1.15: so to my utmost ability, I am ready to preach the gospel to you who are in Rome also.
1.16: For I am not ashamed of the gospel: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
1.17: For the righteousness of God is revealed in him from faith to faith: as has been written, But the just shall live by faith.
1.18: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who hold the truth in unrighteousness;
1.19: because that which is known of God is manifest in them; for God has revealed it to them:
1.20: for the invisible things of Him from the creation of the world are seen, being known by the things which are made, even His eternal power and divinity; so that they are without excuse:
1.21: because, knowing God, they did not glorify Him as God, neither were they thankful; but they became vain in their reasonings, and their foolish heart was darkened.
1.22: Saying that they were wise, they became fools,
1.23: and changed the glory of the invisible God into the similitude of the likeness of corruptible man, and of birds, and of quadrupeds, and of creeping things.
1.24: Therefore God gave them up, in the lusts of their hearts, to impurity, to dishonor their bodies among themselves:
1.25: who changed the truth of God into a lie, and worshiped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is blessed for evermore: amen.
1.26: On account of this God gave them up to the lusts of dishonor: for indeed their women changed the natural use to that which is against nature:
1.27: likewise also the men, having left the natural use of the woman, burned in their desire towards one another; men with men working out disgrace, and receiving the reward of their error among themselves which it behooved.
1.28: And as they did not approve to have God in their knowledge, God gave them up to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are inappropriate;
1.29: being filled with all injustice, wickedness, vice, covetousness; full of envy, murder, strife, deceitfulness, evil affection;
1.30: whisperers, calumniators, haters of God, insulters, proud, arrogant, practitioners of evils, disobedient to parents,
1.31: covenant-breakers, incontinent, without natural affections, unmerciful,
1.32: who, knowing the rightfulness of God, that those who do such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but they even delight in those who are doing them.

2.1: Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, every one judging. For in whatsoever thou art judging another, thou art condemning thyself; for thou judging art doing the same things.
2.2: For we know that the judgment of God according to truth is against those doing such things.
2.3: But do you consider this, O man, judging those doing such things, and doing the same, that you shall escape the judgment of God?
2.4: Do you look with contempt upon the riches of his goodness and forbearance and longsuffering; not knowing that the goodness of God is leading you to repentance?
2.5: But according to thy hardness and thy impenitent heart, thou art treasuring up to thyself wrath against the day of wrath and of the revelation of the righteous judgment of God;
2.6: who will give to each one according to his works:
2.7: to those indeed who with patience of good work are seeking glory and honor and immortality, eternal life:
2.8: but to those who are of self-seeking, and disobedient to the truth, but obedient to unrighteousness, there are indignation and wrath.
2.9: Tribulation and anguish upon every soul of man that is working out evil, both the Jew first, and the Greek;
2.10: but glory and honor and peace to every one doing good; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
2.11: For there is no respect of persons with God.
2.12: For so many as sinned without law will also perish without law; and so many as sinned under the law shall be judged by the law;
2.13: for the hearers of the law are not righteous with God, but the doers of the law shall be justified.
2.14: For when the Gentiles, not having the law, may by nature do the things of the law, they, not having the law, are a law unto themselves:
2.15: who show the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience witnessing, and their thoughts accusing or indeed excusing with one another,
2.16: in the day when God will judge the secrets of men through my gospel according to Jesus Christ.
2.17: But if you are denominated a Jew, and rest in the law, and boast in God,
2.18: and know his will, and approve the things which are excellent, being taught by the law;
2.19: and persuade yourself that you are a guide of the blind, a light of those who are in darkness, an instructor of the ignorant,
2.20: a teacher of the juveniles, having a form of knowledge and truth in the law;
2.21: therefore do not you who teach another teach yourself? do you, who preach not to steal, steal?
2.22: do you, who say not to commit adultery, commit adultery? do you, who abominate idolatry, rob temples?
2.23: do you, who boast in the law, through the transgression of the law dishonor God?
2.24: For the name of God is blasphemed by you among the Gentiles, as has been written.
2.25: For circumcision indeed profits, if you do the law: but if you be a transgressor of the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
2.26: Then if uncircumcision may keep the righteousness of the law, will not his uncircumcision be counted for circumcision?
2.27: and that which is uncircumcision by nature, perfecting the law, will judge you, who through the letter and circumcision are a transgressor of the law.
2.28: For he is not a Jew who is one outwardly; neither is circumcision that which is outwardly in the flesh.
2.29: But he is a Jew, who is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the spirit, not in the letter; whose praise is not of men, but of God.

3.1: Then what more belongs to the Jew, or what is the profit of circumcision?
3.2: Much every way. For indeed, in the first place, the oracles of God were committed unto them.
3.3: For what if some did not believe? whether will their unbelief destroy the faith of God?
3.4: it could not be so: but let God be true, and every man a liar; as indeed it has been written, In order that you may be justified in your words, and shall prevail, in your judgment.
3.5: But if our unrighteousness commends the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is God unjust administering wrath? I speak according to a man.
3.6: It could not be so: then how will God judge the world?
3.7: And if the truth of God through my falsehood abounded unto His glory, why am I still judged as a sinner?
3.8: are we not indeed thus traduced, and as some say we speak, that, Let us do evil in order that good may come? whose condemnation is just.
3.9: Then what? are we the better? By no means: for we have proven already that both Jews and Greeks are all under sin;
3.10: as has been written, There is no one good, not one:
3.11: there is no one who understands, there is no one who seeks out God;
3.12: all have gone away, they have all together become unprofitable; there is no one who is doing good, there is not one.
3.13: Their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips.
3.14: Whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness.
3.15: Whose feet are swift to shed blood:
3.16: destruction and misery are in their ways:
3.17: and they have not known the way of peace.
3.18: The fear of God is not before their eyes.
3.19: But we know that so many things as the law speaks, it says to those under the law: that every mouth may be stopped, and the whole world may become guilty before God.
3.20: Therefore no flesh shall be justified by works of law: for through law there is a perfect knowledge of sin.
3.21: And now the righteousness of God without law has been made manifest, being witnessed by the law and the prophets;
3.22: but the righteousness of God through faith of Jesus Christ is unto all who believe: for there is no difference,
3.23: for all sinned, and come short of the glory of God;
3.24: being freely justified by his grace, through the redemption which is in Christ Jesus:
3.25: whom God sent forth an expiation through faith in his blood, unto the manifestation of His righteousness through the remission of the sins which are passed,
3.26: in the forbearance of God; unto the manifestation of his righteousness at the present time, so that he is just, and justifying him who is of the faith of Jesus.
3.27: Then where is boasting? It is excluded. By what law? of works? No; but by the law of faith.
3.28: For we conclude that a man is justified by faith without works of law.
3.29: Whether is he the God of the Jews only? is He not also the God of the Gentiles? Yea, also of the Gentiles:
3.30: truly there is one God, who will justify the circumcision by faith, and the uncircumcision through faith.
3.31: Then do we make void the law through faith? It could not be so: but we establish the law.

4.1: Then what shall we say that Abraham, our father according to the flesh, has found?
4.2: For if Abraham were justified by works, he has glorification; but not before God.
4.4: But to him that worketh, the reward is not reckoned according to grace, but according to debt;
4.5: but to him that worketh not, but believeth on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is reckoned for righteousness.
4.6: Indeed David also speaks of the blessedness of the man, to whom God imputes righteousness without works,
4.8: blessed is the man of whom the Lord may not impute sin.
4.9: Then does this blessedness come on the circumcision, or on the uncircumcision? for we say That faith was imputed to Abraham for righteousness.
4.10: Then how was it imputed? to him, being in circumcision or uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
4.11: And he received the sign of circumcision, and the seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had in uncircumcision: that he should be the father of all who believed, through uncircumcision; and righteousness should be imputed to them;
4.12: and the father of circumcision to them who not only are of the circumcision, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had in uncircumcision.
4.13: For the promise to Abraham or his seed, that he should be the heir of the world, was not through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.
4.14: For if the heirs were by the law, faith has been made void, and the promise vitiated.
4.15: For the law works out wrath: for where there is no law, there is no transgression.
4.16: Therefore it is by faith, in order that it may be by grace; that the promise may be sure to all the seed; not only of the law, but also of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all,
4.17: as it has been written, That I have constituted thee the father of many nations, before God whom he believed, who quickens the dead, and calls things which are not as really existing:
4.18: who against hope confided in hope, that he should be the father of many nations, according to that which had been spoken, So shall thy seed be:
4.19: and being not weak in faith, he considered not his body already dead, being about a hundred years old, and the deadness of Sarah's womb:
4.20: but he staggered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was filled up with dynamite through faith, having given glory to God;
4.21: and being fully assured, that whatsoever he has promised, he is able also to perform.
4.22: Therefore it was indeed imputed unto him for righteousness.
4.23: And it was not written on account of him alone, that it was imputed to him;
4.24: but on account of us also, to whom it is about to be imputed, who believe on him who raised up our Lord Jesus from the dead;
4.25: who was delivered on account of our transgressions, and raised for our justification.

5.1: Therefore having been justified by faith, let us have peace toward God through our Lord Jesus Christ:
5.2: through whom we also have access by faith unto this grace in which we stand, and let us rejoice in the hope of the glory of God.
5.3: And not only so, but let us also rejoice in tribulation; knowing that tribulation works out endurance;
5.4: and endurance, approval; and approval, hope:
5.5: and hope makes not ashamed; because the divine love of God has been poured out in our hearts by the Holy Ghost who has been given unto us.
5.6: For we being yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly:
5.7: for scarcely will one die for a righteous man; for perhaps some one even dares to die for a good man.
5.8: And God commends his love to us, because, we being yet sinners, Christ died for us.
5.9: How much more then, having now been justified by his blood, shall we be saved from wrath through him.
5.10: For if being enemies we are reconciled to God through the death of his Son; how much more, being reconciled, shall we be saved through his life:
5.11: but not only so, but even rejoicing in God through Jesus Christ our Lord, through whom we now received reconciliation.
5.12: Therefore, as by one man sin came into the world, and death by sin; and thus death came upon all men, in that all sinned;
5.13: (for until the law sin was in the world: but sin is not imputed, there being no law;
5.14: but death reigned from Adam unto Moses, even on those who did not sin after the similitude of Adam's transgression, who is the type of him who is to come.
5.15: But not as was the transgression, even so is the free gift: for if by the transgression of one many died, how much more by the grace of one man, Jesus Christ, did the grace of God and the gift abound unto many!
5.16: And not as by the one having sinned, is the free gift; for indeed, judgment was from one unto condemnation, but the free gift is from many transgressions unto justification.
5.17: For if by the transgression of one death reigned through one; how much more shall those receiving the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness reign in life through the one, Christ Jesus!)
5.18: Therefore then, as by the transgression of one, judgment came to all men to condemnation; so also through the righteousness of one, the free gift came on all men unto the justification of life:
5.19: for as by the disobedience of one man many were made sinners, so also by the obedience of one man shall many be made righteous.
5.20: But the law came, that the transgression might abound; but where sin did abound, there did grace superabound:
5.21: in order that as sin reigned through death, so may grace reign also through righteousness unto eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.

6.1: Then what shall we say? must we abide in sin, in order that grace may abound?
6.2: It could not be so. How shall we, who are dead unto sin, live any longer in it?
6.3: Whether do you not know, that so many of us as were baptized unto Jesus Christ were baptized into His death?
6.4: Therefore we were buried with him by baptism into death: in order that as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, so must we also walk in newness of life.
6.5: For if we have grown together in the likeness of His death, we shall also be in the likeness of his resurrection:
6.6: knowing this, that our old man is crucified along with him, in order that the body of sin may be destroyed, that we may no longer serve sin;
6.7: for the one having died has been made free from sin.
6.8: But if we died along with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him:
6.9: knowing that Christ having risen from the dead dies no more; death no longer has dominion over him.
6.10: For the death that he died, he died unto sin once: but the life that he lives, he lives unto God.
6.11: So you also thus reckon yourselves dead unto sin, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ.
6.12: Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body that you should obey the lusts of it:
6.13: neither present your members arms of iniquity unto sin; but present yourselves to God, as alive from the dead, and your members arms of righteousness unto God.
6.14: For sin shall not have dominion over you: for you are not under the law, but under grace.
6.15: What then? can we commit sin, because we are not under the law, but under grace? it could not be so.
6.16: Do you not know, that to whom you present yourselves servants unto obedience, ye are servants to whom you obey; whether of sin unto death, or obedience unto righteousness?
6.17: But thanks be unto God, that whereas ye were servants of sin, but you have obeyed from the heart the type of teaching into which ye were delivered:
6.18: but having been made free from sin, ye became servants unto righteousness.
6.19: I speak after the manner of a man on account of the weakness of your carnality. For as ye presented your members as servants unto impurity and lawlessness pursuant to lawlessness, so now present your members servants unto righteousness pursuant to sanctification.
6.20: For when you were the servants of sin, you were free from righteousness.
6.21: What fruit then had you at that time in those things in which you are now ashamed? for the end of these things is death.
6.22: But now having been made free from sin, and having become servants unto God, you have your fruit unto sanctification, and the end eternal life.
6.23: For the wages of sin is death; but the free gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord,

7.1: Whether are you ignorant, O brethren, for I speak to those knowing the law, for the law hath dominion over a man for so long time as he may live?
7.2: For a woman who is under her husband has been given to her husband by the law so long as he lives; but if the husband may die, she is free from the law of the husband.
7.3: Then if she may be married to another man, her husband still living, she will be designated an adulteress: but if her husband may die, she is free from the law; and is no adulteress, though she is married to another man.
7.4: So, my brethren, ye are dead to the law through the body of Christ, that ye should be married to another, to him who is risen from the dead, in order that we may bring forth fruit unto God.
7.5: For when we were in carnality, the emotions of sins, which were through the law, did work in our members to bring forth fruit unto death.
7.6: But now we have been made free from the law, being dead in that in which we were held; so that we serve in the newness of the spirit, and not in the oldness of the letter.
7.7: Then what shall we say? is the law sin? It could not be so; but I did not know sin except through the law: for indeed I had not known lusts, unless the law said, Thou shalt not covet.
7.8: But sin, taking occasion through the commandment, did work in me all concupiscence; for without law sin was dead.
7.9: But I was alive at one time without law: but the commandment having come, sin revived,
7.10: and I died; and the commandment, which was unto life, the same was unto death.
7.11: For sin, taking occasion through the commandment, deceived me, and through it slew me.
7.12: So the law is indeed holy, and the commandment holy, and righteous, and good.
7.13: Then did that which is good become death to me? it could not be so: but sin, that it may appear sin, through the good was working out death to me, in order that sin may be exceedingly sinful through the commandment.
7.14: For we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, having been sold under sin.
7.15: For that which I do, I know not: for I do that which I do not will; but I do that which I hate.
7.16: But if I do that which I do not will, I consent to the law that it is beautiful;
7.17: but now it is no more I that do it, but sin dwelling in me.
7.18: For I know that in me, that is, in my carnal mind, there dwells no good thing. For to will is present with me, but to do that which is beautiful is not:
7.19: for the good which I will I do not; but the evil which I do not will, that I do.
7.20: If I do that which I do not will, it is no longer I that do it, but sin dwelling in me.
7.21: Then I find a law, that, to me wishing to do that which is beautiful, that the evil is present with me:
7.22: for I delight in the law of God according to the inward man;
7.23: but I see another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members.
7.24: O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?
7.25: Thanks be unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord: then therefore with the mind I serve the law of God; but with carnality the law of sin.

8.1: There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus.
8.2: For the law of the Spirit of life has made thee free from the law of sin and of death.
8.3: For there was an impotency of the law, in which it was weak through depravity, God having sent his own Son in the likeness of the sin of depravity and for sin, condemned sin in depravity:
8.4: in order that the righteousness of the law may be fulfilled in us, who walk not according to depravity, but according to the spirit.
8.5: For those being in harmony with depravity, do mind the things of depravity, and those in harmony with the Spirit, the things of the Spirit:
8.6: for the mind of depravity is death: and the mind of the Spirit is life and peace.
8.7: Therefore the mind of depravity is enmity toward God: for it is not subordinated to the law of God, for it is not able so to be.
8.8: But those being in depravity are not able to please God.
8.9: But ye are not in depravity, but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God dwells in you. But if any one has not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of His.
8.10: But if Christ is in you, the body is dead so far as sin is concerned; but the Spirit is life so far as righteousness is concerned.
8.11: But if the Spirit of Him who raised up Jesus from the dead dwells in you, the one having raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also create life in your mortal bodies through His Spirit, who dwells in you.
8.12: Then therefore, brethren, we are debtors, not to depravity, to live according to depravity.
8.13: For if you live according to depravity, you are about to die: but if through the Spirit you kill the practices of the body, you shall live.
8.14: For so many as are led by the Spirit of God, these are the sons of God.
8.16: The Spirit Himself witnesses along with our spirit, that we are the children of God.
8.17: And if children, indeed heirs; truly heirs of God, and joint heirs with Christ; if we suffer together, in order that we may also be glorified together.
8.18: For I reckon that the sufferings of these present times are not worthy to be compared to the glory which is about to be revealed in us.
8.19: For the earnest expectation of the creature awaits the revelation of the sons of God.
8.20: For the creature has been subordinated to mortality, not willingly, but through Him who subordinated it;
8.21: therefore indeed pursuant to hope, the creature itself shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the liberty of the glory of the children of God.
8.22: For we know that all creation groans together and travails together until now;
8.23: and not only so, but we ourselves, having the earnest of the Spirit, and we ourselves groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption of sons, the redemption of our body.
8.24: For we are saved by hope: but hope which is seen is not hope: for why does any one indeed hope for that which he sees?
8.25: But if we hope for that which we do not see, we wait for it with patience.
8.26: And likewise the Spirit also helps our infirmity. For we know not what we should pray for as it behooves us: but the Spirit himself makes intercession with unutterable groanings:
8.27: but he that searches the hearts knows what is the mind of the Spirit, because he makes intercession towards God in behalf of the saints.
8.28: But we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them that are called according to his purpose.
8.29: Because whom he did foreknow, he did also predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, in order that he might be the firstborn among many brethren:
8.30: and whom He did foreknow, them he also called: and whom he called, them he also justified: and whom he justified, them He also glorified.
8.31: Then what shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
8.32: Indeed he who spared not his own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how will He not with him, freely give us all things?
8.33: Who will lay anything to the charge of God's elect?
8.34: It is God who justifies: who is he that condemns? It is Christ who died, and rather who is risen, who is on the right hand of God, who indeed is interceding in our behalf.
8.35: Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? shall tribulation, or anguish, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?
8.37: But in all these we are more than conquerors through him that loved us.
8.38: For I am persuaded that, neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come,
8.39: nor powers, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

9.1: I speak the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience bearing me witness in the Holy Ghost,
9.2: that there is great sorrow to me and incessant grief to my heart.
9.3: For I would pray, that I myself might be an offering from Christ; in behalf of my brethren, my kindred according to the flesh:
9.4: who are Israelites, of whom is the adoption of sons, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service, and the promises:
9.5: of whom are the fathers, and of whom is Christ according to the flesh. Who is over all, God blessed forever: amen.
9.6: But not as that the word of God has been a failure. For these are not all Israel who are of Israel;
9.7: neither are the children all the seed of Abraham; but in Isaac shall thy seed be called;
9.8: that is the children of the flesh the same are not the children of God; but the children of the promise are counted for the seed.
9.10: Not only so; but Rebecca also having cohabitation of one, our father Isaac;
9.11: for the children not having been born, neither having done anything good or evil, in order that the purpose of God might stand according to election not of works, but of him that calleth,
9.12: and it was said to her, The elder shall serve the younger:
9.13: as has been written, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated.
9.14: Then what shall we say? Is there unrighteousness with God? It could not be so.
9.15: For he says to Moses, I will have mercy on whom I do have mercy, and I will commiserate whom I do commiserate.
9.16: Then it is not of him that willeth, nor him that runneth, but of God who shows mercy.
9.17: For the scripture says to Pharaoh, For this very thing have I raised you up, that I may show forth my power in you, and that my name may be proclaimed in all the earth.
9.18: Then therefore he has mercy on whom he will, and whom he will he hardens.
9.19: Then thou wilt say to me, Why does he yet find fault? For who has resisted his will?
9.20: O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Whether shall the thing formed say to him that formed it. Why did you make me thus?
9.21: Has not the potter the right of the clay, from the same lump to make one part a vessel unto honor, and another unto dishonor?
9.22: But if God, wishing to show forth his indignation and make his power known, endured with much longsuffering the vessels of indignation having been perfected unto destruction:
9.23: and in order that he might make known the riches of his glory on the vessels of mercy, which he before prepared unto glory?
9.24: whom he called, even us, not only of the Jews, but also of the Gentiles:
9.25: as he says in Hosea, I will call them my people, who are not my people; and her beloved, who is not beloved:
9.27: but Isaiah cries out in behalf of Israel, Though the number of sons of Israel may be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shall be saved.
9.28: For perfecting the word and cutting it short, will the Lord do a complete work on the earth:
9.29: and as Isaiah has before spoken; Unless the Lord of Sabaoth left to us a seed, we would have become as Sodom, and would have been made like unto Gomorrah:
9.30: Then what shall we say? That the Gentiles, not pursuing righteousness, received righteousness, and the righteousness which is from faith:
9.31: but Israel, following after the law, did not attain unto the law of righteousness.
9.32: Why? Because they sought it not from faith, but as it were from works: they stumbled over the stone of stumbling,
9.33: as has been written, Behold, I lay in Zion a stone of stumbling and a rock of offence: and he that believeth on him shall not be ashamed.

10.1: Brethren, indeed the desire of my heart and my prayer to God in their behalf, is for their salvation.
10.2: For I testify to them, that they have a zeal of God, but not according to perfect knowledge;
10.3: for being ignorant of God's righteousness, and seeking to establish their own righteousness, they have not submitted to the righteousness of God.
10.4: For Christ is the end of the law unto righteousness to every one who believes.
10.5: For Moses describes the righteousness which is of the law, that the man having done this shall live in it.
10.7: or, Who shall descend into the abyss? that is, to bring him up from the dead.
10.8: But what says it? The word is nigh thee, in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is, the word of faith, which we preach.
10.9: That if you may confess with your mouth the Lord Jesus, and may believe with your heart that God raised him from the dead, you shall be saved:
10.10: for with the heart it is believed unto righteousness; and with the mouth it is confessed unto salvation.
10.11: For the scripture says, Every one believing on him shall not be ashamed.
10.12: For there is no difference between Jew and Greek: for the same is Lord of all, rich unto all that call on him.
10.13: For every one who may call on the name of the Lord shall be saved.
10.14: Then how can they call on him on whom they have not believed? and how can they believe on him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear without a preacher?
10.15: And how can they preach, unless they may be sent forth? as has been written, How beautiful are the feet of those, who preach the gospel of good things!
10.16: But they have not all heard the gospel. For Isaiah says, Lord, who has believed our report?
10.17: Then faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the word of Christ.
10.18: But I say, Have they not all heard? Yea, truly, Their sound has gone out into all the earth, and their words unto the ends of the world.
10.19: But I say, Whether does not Israel know? Moses first says, I will provoke you to jealousy with that which is no nation, and with a nation void of understanding I will anger you.
10.20: But Isaiah is bold, and says, I was found by those not seeking after me; and made manifest to those not inquiring after me.

11.1: Then I say, Did God cast away his people? it could not be so. For I am indeed an Israelite, of the seed of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
11.2: God did not cast away his people whom he foreknew. Do you not know what the scripture says in Elijah, how he makes intercession to God against Israel?
11.3: Lord, they have slain thy prophets, they have digged down thine altars: and I am left alone, and they are seeking my life.
11.4: But what says the answer to him? I have left unto myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knee to Baal.
11.5: Thus then there is even at this time a remnant left according to the election of grace:
11.6: and if by grace, it is not at all by works: since in that case grace is no more grace.
11.7: What then? Israel did not attain that which he was seeking, but the election obtained it, and the rest were hardened:
11.8: as has been written, God has given them the spirit of slumber, eyes that they should not see, and ears that they should not hear, unto this day.
11.9: And David says, Let their table be made a snare, and a trap, and a stumblingblock, and a recompense unto them:
11.10: and let their eyes be darkened, that they may not see, and bow down their back always.
11.11: Then I say; Whether did they stumble that they may fall? it could not be so: but by their fall, salvation came to the Gentiles, in order to provoke them to jealousy.
11.12: But if the fall of them was the riches of the world, and the depletion of them the riches of the Gentiles; how much more their fulness?
11.13: But I speak to you Gentiles. Inasmuch then as I am an apostle of the Gentiles, I glorify my ministry:
11.14: if perchance I may provoke my flesh, and save some of them.
11.15: For if the casting away of them was the reconciling of the world, what will their reception be, but life from the dead?
11.16: But if the first fruit was holy, the lump is also: if the root was holy, the branches are also.
11.17: And if certain ones of the branches were broken off, and you being a wild olive-tree are grafted in among them, and have become a partaker of the root of the fatness of the olive-tree;
11.18: boast not against the branches: but if you boast, you are not bearing the root, but the root you.
11.20: Beautifully; they were broken off by unbelief, but you stand by faith, Think not high things, but fear.
11.21: For if God spared not the natural branches, neither will he spare you.
11.22: Then behold the goodness and severity of God: upon those who fell indeed, severity; but upon you the goodness of God, if you may abide in his goodness: since you too may be cut off.
11.23: But these also, if they may not abide in unbelief, shall be grafted in: for God is able to graft them in again.
11.24: For if you, having been cut off the olive tree which is wild by nature, and contrary to nature were grafted into the good olive tree: how much more shall these, who are the natural branches, be grafted into their own olive tree?
