6.16: And what harmony has the temple of God with idols? for we are the temple of the living God; as God said; I will live in them, and walk about among them; and I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
6.18: and I will be to you for a Father, and you shall be unto me for sons and daughters, says the Lord Almighty.

7.1: Therefore having these promises, beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from all the filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
7.2: Receive us: we have injured no one, we have corrupted no one, we have defrauded no one.
7.3: I do not speak for castigation: for I have said before, that you are in our hearts to die with you and to live with you.
7.4: My boldness to you is great, my rejoicing over you is much: I have been filled with consolation, I superabound with joy in all our tribulation.
7.5: For we having come into Macedonia, our flesh had no rest, but in everything being troubled; fightings without, fears within.
7.6: But God, the one comforting the humble, comforted us by the coming of Titus;
7.7: and not only by his coming, but also by the consolation with which he was comforted by you, proclaiming unto us your longing, your mourning, your zeal for me; so that I rejoiced the more.
7.8: But if I grieved you in the letter, I do not regret it, if indeed I did regret it; for I see that, if that letter indeed grieved you for an hour,
7.9: now I rejoice, not because you grieved, but because you grieved unto repentance: for you grieved toward God, in order that you may receive damage by us in nothing.
7.10: For a godly sorrow works repentance unto salvation not to be regretted; but the sorrow of the world works out death.
7.11: For behold, how great enthusiasm, yes, how great apology, yes, how great clearing up, yes, how great fear, yes, how great longing, yes, how great zeal, yes, how great avenging, this same godly sorrow did work in you! In everything you have established yourselves to be pure in the matter.
7.12: Since then indeed I wrote to you, not on account of the one having done the wrong, nor on account of the one having suffered the wrong, but in order that your zeal, which is in our behalf to you before God, might be made manifest.
7.13: Therefore we have been comforted. But we rejoiced the more exceedingly in our consolation over the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by you all:
7.14: because if I have gloried with him in anything over you, I wag not made ashamed; but as I spoke all things to you in truth, so our rejoicing over Titus was true.
7.15: And the affections of him, remembering the obedience of you all, how you received him with fear and trembling, are the more abundantly towards you.
7.16: I rejoice because in everything I have confidence in you.

8.1: But, brethren, we make known to you the grace of God which has been given in the churches of Macedonia;
8.2: because in a great trial of affliction the abundance of their joy and deep poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality.
8.3: Because I witness, that according to their ability, and beyond their ability they were anxious,
8.4: with much exhortation praying our favor and the fellowship of the ministry which is to the saints:
8.5: and not as we hoped, but they gave themselves first to the Lord, and to us through the will of God:
8.6: that we should exhort Titus, that as he formerly began it, he may indeed also complete this grace unto you.
8.7: But as in every thing you abound, in faith, and in word, and knowledge, and in all zeal, and in divine love from you in us, that you may also abound in this philanthropy.
8.8: I speak not according to commandment, but through the zeal of others also proving the sincerity of your divine love.
8.9: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, being rich, for your sakes he became poor, that you through his poverty might be made rich.
8.10: And herein I give my judgement: for this is profitable to you, who not only began to do, but to be anxious, a year ago:
8.11: but now indeed complete the work; in order that as there was a promptitude of willing, there shall also be a completion out of your ability.
8.12: For if there is first a willing mind, it is acceptable according to what one may have, and not according to what he has not.
8.13: For it is not that there may be relief to others, affliction to you, but that it may be according to equality: at this time your abundance may correspond to their deficiency,
8.14: that their abundance may correspond with your deficiency, in order that there may be equality:
8.15: as has been written, He that had much did not super-abound; and he that had little did not lack.
8.16: But thanks be unto God, who gives this same enthusiasm in your behalf in the heart of Titus;
8.17: because he indeed accepted our exhortation; and being the more enthusiastic, came unto you of his own accord.
8.18: But we sent with him the brother, whose praise in the gospel is through all the churches;
8.19: not only so, but having been elected by the churches our traveling companion with this philanthropy, administered by us to the glory of the Lord himself, and your promptitude:
8.20: and avoiding this, lest any one may blame us in this benefaction administered by us:
8.21: for we provide things honest, not only in the sight of the Lord, but also before the people.
8.22: And we sent our brother along with him to them, whom we have tried, being frequently zealous in many things, but now much more zealous, with great confidence towards you.
8.23: Whether in behalf of Titus, my companion and fellow-laborer towards you; or our brethren, the apostles of the churches, the glory of Christ.
8.24: Moreover manifesting the exhibition of your love, and our boasting to them in your behalf, in the face of the churches.

9.1: For indeed concerning the ministry which is to the saints, it is superfluous for me to write to you.
9.2: For I know your promptitude, of which I am boasting to the Macedonians in your behalf, that Achaia was ready a year ago; and your zeal has aroused many.
9.3: But I sent the brethren, in order that our boasting which is in your behalf may not be in vain in this region; in order that, as I was saying, your were ready:
9.4: lest perhaps, if the Macedonians may come with me, and find you unprepared, we may be put to shame, in this confidence, (that we may say not, you).
9.5: Therefore I considered it necessary to exhort the brethren, that they may come to you beforehand, and perfect your preannounced benefaction, that it may be ready, as a benefaction, not as a stingy contribution.
9.6: But it is this, he that soweth sparingly shall also reap sparingly; and he that soweth bountifully shall also reap bountifully.
9.7: As each one has predetermined in his heart; not of reluctance, or of constraint: for God loves the hilarious giver.
9.8: But God is able to make all grace abound unto you; in order that, always having all sufficiency in every thing, you may abound unto every good work: as has been written,
9.9: He has scattered abroad, he has given to the poor; his righteousness abides forever.
9.10: But he that gives seed to the sower, will also give bread to the eater, and multiply your sowing, and increase the fruits of your righteousness:
9.11: in every thing being enriched in all purity, which works out through us thanksgiving to God.
9.12: Because the ministry of this free-will offering is not only supplying the deficiencies of the saints, but also superabounding through much thanksgiving to God;
9.13: through the approval of this ministry, glorifying God in the submission of your testimony to the gospel of Christ, and the purity of your fellowship unto them and unto all;
9.14: and through their prayer in your behalf, earnestly longing to see you on account of the grace of God superabounding unto you.
9.15: Thanks be unto God for His unspeakable gift.

10.1: But I Paul exhort you through the meekness and gentleness of Christ, who before your face am indeed humble among you, but being absent am bold towards you:
10.2: but I pray, that being present I may not be bold with the confidence with which I consider myself bold towards certain ones who regard us as walking about according to the flesh.
10.3: For walking in the flesh, we do not wage war according to the flesh;
10.4: for the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty to God unto the pulling down of strongholds;
10.5: casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalts itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ;
10.6: and being ready to avenge every disobedience, when your obedience may be complete.
10.7: Do you look at things according to the outward appearance? If any has trusted to himself that he belongs to Christ, let him again consider this in reference to himself, that as he belongs to Christ, so do we also.
10.8: For if I shall in any thing the more abundantly boast concerning our power which the Lord gave us for your edification, and not for your destruction, I will not be ashamed:
10.9: in order that I may not seem as it were to terrify you by my letters.
10.10: Because they say, His letters are indeed weighty and powerful; but the presence of his body is weak, and his speech contemptible.
10.11: Let such a one consider this, that, such as we are in word by our letters while absent, such we really are in work being present.
10.12: For we are not bold to number or compare ourselves with certain ones of those who recommend themselves: but they, measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves to themselves, are not wise.
10.13: But we will not boast in things without measure, but according to the measure of the rule which measure God has measured to us, to reach even unto you.
10.14: For not as not reaching unto you do we stretch ourselves, for we have advanced in the gospel of Christ even unto you:
10.15: and not boasting in things without measure, in the labors of others, but having hope of your faith increasing among you, to be magnified according to our rule exceedingly,
10.16: to preach the gospel in the regions beyond you, not to glory according to the rule of others in things made ready.
10.17: But he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord;
10.18: for he that commends himself is not approved, but whom the Lord commends.

11.1: I would that you bear with me a little in my folly: yes indeed you do bear with me.
11.2: For I am jealous of you with the jealousy of God: for I espoused you to one husband, to present you a pure virgin to Christ;
11.3: but I fear, lest, as the serpent beguiled Eve by his craftiness, your minds may be corrupted from the simplicity which is in Christ.
11.4: For if indeed one coming preaches another Jesus, whom we have not preached, or you receive another spirit, which you did not receive, or another gospel which you did not receive, well do you bear with him.
11.5: For I consider that I am not inferior to the chief of the apostles.
11.6: If indeed rude in speech, but not in knowledge; but in every thing making manifest unto you in all things.
11.7: Did I commit sin humbling myself that you may be exalted, because I preached unto you the gospel of God gratuitously?
11.8: I robbed other churches, having received support for your ministry, and being present with you and being destitute, I burdened no one;
11.9: for the brethren, having come from Macedonia, supplied my deficiency; and in everything I rendered myself not burdensome to you, and will so render.
11.10: The truth of Christ is in me, that this glorying shall not cease unto me in the regions of Achaia.
11.11: Why? because I do not love you with divine love? God knows.
11.12: But what I am doing, I indeed will do, in order that I may cut off occasion from those wishing occasion, in order that in whatsoever they may glory, they may be found even as we are.
11.13: For such are false apostles, deceitful workers, transforming themselves into the apostles of Christ.
11.14: And no wonder; for Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light.
11.15: Then it is no great wonder if his ministers are transformed as the ministers of righteousness; whose, end shall be according to their works.
11.16: Again I say, Let no one consider me to be a fool; but if not, receive me as a fool, in order that I may indeed glory some little.
11.17: What I say, I am not saying according to the Lord, but as it were in folly, in this confidence of glorying.
11.18: Since many glory in the flesh, I will glory also.
11.19: For cheerfully do you, being wise, bear with the foolish:
11.20: for you bear with them, if any one enslaves you, if any one devours you, if any one captures you, if any one is exalted against you, if any one smites you in the face.
11.21: I speak according to disparagement, as that we are weak; but in whatsoever any one is bold, (I speak it in folly,) I am bold also.
11.22: Are they Hebrews? I am also. Are they Israelites? I am also. Are they the seed of Abraham? I am also.
11.23: Are they the ministers of Christ? (I speak as a mad man,) I am more; in labors more abundantly, in stripes more abundantly, in prisons more frequently, in deaths often;
11.24: from the Jews five times I received forty stripes save one,
11.25: thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, thrice was I shipwrecked, a day and a night I spent in the deep.
11.26: Often in journeys, in perils of rivers, in perils of robbers, in perils from my own race, in perils from the Gentiles, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderness, in perils in the sea, in perils among false brethren;
11.27: in labor and in toil, in vigils often, in hunger and in thirst, in fastings often, in cold and in nakedness.
11.28: Besides all these, that which comes upon me daily, the care of all the churches.
11.29: Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is offended, and I do not burn?
11.30: But if it behooves me to glory, I will glory in those things appertaining to my infirmities.
11.31: The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the one being blessed forever, knows that I lie not.
11.32: In Damascus Areta the governor of the king, guarded the city of the Damascenes, to arrest me:
11.33: and through a window was I let down in a basket by the wall, and escaped his hands.

12.1: It behooves me to glory, indeed it is not profitable, I will come to visions and revelations of the Lord.
12.2: I knew a man in Christ, fourteen years ago, whether in the body, I know not; whether out of the body, I know not, such a one having been caught up even to the third heaven.
12.3: And I knew such a man, whether in the body, or out of the body, I know not; God knows,
12.4: that he was caught up to Paradise, and heard unutterable words, which it is impossible for a man to speak.
12.5: Concerning such a one I will glory: but concerning myself I will not glory, except in my infirmities.
12.6: For if I shall wish to glory, I will not be a fool; for I speak the truth: but I fear, lest some one may consider with reference to me above what he sees me, or hears from me.
12.7: And that I may not be exalted by the abundance of revelations, a thorn was given unto me in the flesh, the messenger of Satan that he may buffet me, in order that I may not be exalted.
12.8: Three times I called on the Lord concerning this, that it may depart from me.
12.9: And he said to me, My grace is sufficient for thee: for power is made perfect in weakness. Therefore most delightfully I will glory the more in my infirmities, in order that the power of Christ may abide on me.
12.10: Therefore I delight in infirmities, in insults, in difficulties, in persecutions, and in tight places, for Christ's sake: for when I am without strength, then I am dynamite.
12.11: I have become a fool: you did compel me. For I ought to be commended by you: for I am not inferior to the very chief of the apostles, if indeed I am nothing.
12.12: For indeed the signs of the apostleship are wrought in me in all patience, in miracles and in wonders and in dynamites.
12.13: For what is that in which you are inferior to other churches, except that I did not burden you? forgive me this wrong.
12.14: Behold, the third time I am ready to come to you; and I will not spare: for I do not seek yours, but you. For the children ought not to lay up treasures for the parents, but the parents for the children,
12.15: But I will most delightfully spend and be spent for your souls. If the more abundantly I love you am I loved the less?
12.16: But let it he so, I did not burden you; but, being crafty, I caught you with guile.
12.17: Which one of those whom I sent unto you, did I fleece you through him?
12.18: I called Titus, and sent the brother along with him: whether did Titus defraud you? did we not walk by the same Spirit? did we not in the same tracks?
12.19: For a long time you were thinking that I am apologizing to you. We speak before God in Christ; but all things, beloved, are for your edification.
12.20: For I fear lest, having come, I may not find you as I wish, and may not be found by you as you wish; lest perhaps strife, jealousy, animosities, selfseekings, calumniations, eavesdroppings, inflations, outfallings, are among you;
12.21: lest, I again having come, my God will humble me before you, and I will mourn over many of those having previously committed sins, and not having repented over the uncleanness and the fornication and debauchery which they have done.

13.1: This the third time I am coming to you: in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word shall be established.
13.2: I have told you beforehand, and I am speaking to you in advance, as being present the second time, even now absent, that, if I may come to you again, I will not spare those who have previously sinned, and all the rest;
13.3: since you are seeking the approval of Christ, who is speaking in me, who is not weak towards you, bit mighty among you.
13.4: For indeed he was crucified from weakness, but he lives by the power of God: for we indeed are weak in him, but we shall live with him through the power of God unto you.
13.5: Prove your own selves, if you are in the faith; examine yourselves; whether do you not know yourselves, that Christ Jesus is in you? unless indeed you are reprobates.
13.6: But I hope that you shall know that we are not reprobates.
13.7: But we are praying unto God, that he may do you no evil, not in order that we may appear approved, but that you may do that which is good, and we may be as disapproved.
13.8: For we are not able to do any thing against the truth, but for the truth.
13.9: For we rejoice when we may be weak, and you may be strong: we are praying for even this, your perfection.
13.10: Therefore being absent I write these things, in order that being present, I may not use severity, according to the power which the Lord has given me for edification, and not for destruction.
13.11: Finally, brethren, farewell. Be perfect; be of good comfort; think the same thing, live in peace: and the God of love and peace will be with you.
13.12: Salute one another with a holy kiss.
13.14: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit, be with you all.

1.1: Paul, an apostle, not from men, nor through man, but through Jesus Christ, and God the Father, who raised him from the dead,
1.2: and all the brethren who are with me, to the churches of Galatia.
1.3: Grace to you and peace from God the Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ,
1.4: who gave Himself for our sins, in order that he might redeem us from the present evil age, according to the will of God even our Father:
1.5: To whom be glory unto the ages of the ages. Amen.
1.6: I am astonished that you are so quickly removed from him who called you in the grace of Christ into another gospel;
1.7: which is not another: but there are certain ones who are troubling you, and wishing to pervert the gospel of Christ.
1.8: But indeed if we, or an angel from heaven, may preach unto you any other gospel except that which we have preached unto you, let him be accursed.
1.9: As we have before said, and now again I tell you, If any one preaches to you a gospel except that which you have received, let him be accursed.
1.10: For must I now believe men, or God? whether do I seek to please men? if I were still pleasing men, I would not be the servant of Christ.
1.11: But I make known to you, brethren, the gospel was preached to me, that it is not according to a man;
1.12: for I did not receive it from man, neither was I taught it, but through the revelation of Jesus Christ.
1.13: For you have heard of my life formerly in Judaism, that I was persecuting the church of God exceedingly, and destroying it:
1.14: and I was prominent in Judaism above many comrades in my race, being exceedingly zealous of the traditions of my fathers.
1.15: When the one having separated me, from the womb of my mother, and called me through his grace, was pleased
1.16: to reveal his Son in me, that I might preach him among the Gentiles; immediately I conferred not with flesh and blood:
1.17: neither did I go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me; but I went away into Arabia, and returned again to Damascus.
1.18: Then after three years I went up to Jerusalem to see Cephas, and remained with him fifteen days;
1.19: but I saw no other of the apostles, except James the brother of the Lord.
1.20: Which things moreover I write unto you, behold, before God, that I lie not.
1.21: Then I went into the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
1.22: But I was unknown by face to the churches of Judea which are in Christ.
1.23: But they were only hearing that The one persecuting us at one time is now preaching the faith which he was once desolating;
1.24: and they continued to glorify God in me.

2.1: Then after fourteen years, I again went up to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking also Titus with me;
2.2: but I went up according to revelation; and I presented to them the gospel which I am preaching among the Gentiles, but privately to the prominent ones, lest perhaps I am running, or did run, in vain.
2.3: But neither was Titus the one with me, being a Greek, compelled to be circumcised:
2.4: but on account of the false brethren having crept in, who came in to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Jesus, in order that they shall bring us into bondage:
2.5: to whom I rendered not submission for an hour; in order that the truth of the gospel may abide with you.
2.6: But of those seeming to be something what they were at that time makes no difference to me: God does not receive the face of man: for those seeming to me to be prominent added nothing extra:
2.7: but on the contrary, seeing that I am intrusted with the gospel of the uncircumcision, like Peter of the circumcision,
2.8: for the one having wrought with Peter unto the apostleship of the circumcision also wrought with me unto the Gentiles:
2.9: and having known the grace of God which was given unto me, James and Cephas and John, who seem to be pillars, gave to me and Barnabas the right hand of fellowship, that we should go to the Gentiles, and they to the circumcision;
2.10: only that we should remember the poor; which very thing I was also zealous to do.
2.11: And when Cephas came into Antioch, I withstood him to the face, because he was to blame.
2.12: For before certain ones came from James, he was eating along with the Gentiles: but when they came, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing those who were of the circumcision.
2.13: And the rest of the Jews also reciprocated with him; so that even Barnabas was led away by their dissimulation.
2.14: But when I saw that they are not walking uprightly according to the truth of the gospel, I said to Cephas in the presence of all, If you being a Jew are living like the Gentiles and not like the Jews, how do you compel the Gentiles to judaize?
2.15: We being Jews by nature, and not sinners of the Gentiles,
2.16: knowing that a man is not justified by works of law, but through the faith of Christ Jesus, and we have believed into Christ Jesus, in order that we may be justified by faith of Christ, and not by works of law, because by works of law no flesh shall be justified.
2.18: For if I again build the things which I have destroyed, I constitute myself a transgressor.
2.20: I am crucified along with Christ; and I live no longer, but Christ lives in me; and the life which I now live in the flesh, I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
2.21: I do not make void the grace of God: for if righteousness was through law, then Christ died gratuitiously.

3.1: O foolish Galatians, who has been bewitching you, before whose eyes Jesus Christ was set forth having been crucified?
3.2: I only wish to learn this from you, Did you receive the Spirit by works of law, or by hearing of faith?
3.3: Are you so foolish? having begun in the Spirit, are you now made perfect in the flesh?
3.4: Have you suffered so many things in vain? if indeed in vain.
3.5: Then did the one imparting to you the Spirit, and working miracles, among you, do it by works of law, or by hearing of faith?
3.6: As Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.
3.7: Then know that those who are of faith, the same are the sons of Abraham.
3.9: Therefore those who are of faith are blessed with faithful Abraham.
3.11: But that no one is justified by law in the sight of God, is evident: because, The just shall live by faith:
3.12: though the law is not of faith; but the one having done these things shall live in them.
3.14: in order that the blessing of Abraham in Christ Jesus may come to the Gentiles; in order that we may receive the promise of the Spirit through faith.
3.15: Brethren, I speak according to a man, nevertheless no one disannuls, or adds to, the covenant of a man which has been confirmed.
3.17: And I say this; The law which was given after four hundred and thirty years, does not disannul the covenant which had been before confirmed of God, so as to make the promise of none effect.
3.18: For if the inheritance were by law, it is no more by promise: but God gave it to Abraham through the promise.
3.19: Then what is the law? It was added on account of the transgressions, until the seed to whom the promise was made should come; being ordained by angels in the hand of a mediator.
3.20: A mediator is not of one; but God is one.
3.21: Then was the law against the promises of God? it could not be so. For if the law was given being able to create life, truly justification would have been by law:
3.22: but the scripture has shut up all things unto sin, in order that the promise through faith of Jesus Christ may be given to those who believe.
3.23: But before faith came, we were kept under law, being shut up to the faith about to be revealed.
3.24: Therefore the law became our schoolmaster to lead us to Christ, in order that we may be justified by faith;
3.25: but faith having come, we are no longer under the schoolmaster.
3.26: For you are all the sons of God, through faith, in Christ Jesus;
3.27: for so many of you as were baptized into Christ have put on Christ.
3.28: There is no longer Jew nor Greek, nor bond nor free, nor male and female: for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
3.29: But if you belong to Christ then you are the seed of Abraham, heirs according to the promise.

4.1: But I say, so long as the heir is an infant, he differs not from a slave, being lord of all things,
4.2: but he is under nurses and stewards until the adoption of the father.
4.3: So also we, when we were infants, were enslaved under the elements of the world:
4.4: but when the fulness of time came, God sent forth his own Son, having been born of a woman, having been born under law,
4.5: in order that he might redeem those under law, that we might receive the adoption of sonship.
4.7: So you are no longer a servant but a son; and if a son, truly an heir through God.
4.8: But you indeed, not knowing God, at that time served those who by nature are not gods:
4.9: but now having known God, and rather having become known of God, how do you turn again to the weak and beggarly elements which you wish to serve again as formerly?
4.10: Do you keep days, and months, and times and years?
4.11: I fear lest I have labored unto you in vain.
4.12: Be ye as I am, because I am as you are, brethren, I am praying for you.
4.13: You have not injured me: you know that through weakness of the flesh I formerly preached the gospel unto you:
4.14: and you did not despise, nor spit upon, your temptation in my flesh; but you received me as an angel of God, as Christ Jesus.
4.15: Where then is your happiness? for I testify to you that, if possible, having plucked out your eyes, you would have given them to me.
4.16: Therefore have I become your enemy, telling you the truth?
4.17: They zealously seek you in no good way; but they wish to exclude you, in order that you may zealously seek them.
4.18: It is good always to be zealous in a good thing, and not only in my coming to you.
4.19: My children, for whom I again travail in pain until Christ may be formed in you,
4.20: but I wish to come unto you now, and change my voice; because I am at a loss in reference to you.
4.21: Tell me, you wish to be under law, do you not hear the law?
4.22: For it is written that Abraham had two sons; one by a bond-maid and one by a freewoman.
4.23: But the one indeed of the bond-maid was born according to the flesh, and the one of the freewoman through the promise.
4.24: Which things are allegorized: for these are the two covenants; the one indeed from mount Sinai, generating children into bondage, which is Hagar.
4.25: For this mount Sinai is in Arabia, and corresponds with Jerusalem which now is: for she is in bondage with her children.
4.26: But Jerusalem who is above is free, who is our mother:
4.27: for it is written, Rejoice, thou barren one who does not bring forth; break forth and cry aloud, thou that dost not travail: because many more are the children of the barren than of her having a husband.
4.28: But you, brethren, are the children of Isaac, according to the promise.
4.29: But as the one at that time having been born according to the flesh persecuted the one according to the Spirit, even so it is now.
4.30: But what says the scripture? Cast out the bondwoman and her son: for the son of the bondwoman shall not inherit with the son of the free.
4.31: Therefore, brethren, we are not the children of the bondwoman, but of the free.

5.1: Christ has set you free with freedom, Therefore stand, and be not again entangled with the yoke of bondage.
5.2: Behold I Paul say unto you, that, if you may be circumcised, Christ shall profit you nothing.
5.3: And again I witness to every man who is circumcised, that he is debtor to do the whole law.
5.4: You have been divorced from Christ, whosoever are justified by law: you have fallen from grace.
5.5: For we through the Spirit do await the hope of righteousness through faith.
5.6: For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision or uncircumcision avails anything; but faith working through divine love.
5.7: You were running well; who did hinder you that you should not obey the truth?
5.8: The persuasion is not of the one calling you.
5.9: A little leaven leavens the whole lump.
5.10: I have confidence in reference to you in the Lord, that you shall be none otherwise minded: but the one troubling you shall bear the judgment, whosoever he may be.
5.11: But I, brethren, if I yet preach circumcision, why do I still suffer persecution? then the offence of the cross would be done away.
5.12: I would that those troubling you shall indeed cut themselves off.
5.13: For you were called unto liberty, brethren; only use not the liberty unto an occasion to the flesh, but through divine love serve one another.
5.14: For the whole law has been fulfilled in one word, in this; Thou shalt love thy neighbor with divine love as thyself.
5.15: But if you bite and devour one another, take heed that you may not be consumed one of another.
5.16: And I say, Walk about in the Spirit, and do not perfect the lust of carnality.
5.17: For carnality wars against the Spirit, and the Spirit against carnality; for these are antagonistical to one another; so that you may not do the things which you may wish.
5.18: But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under law.
5.19: But the works of carnality are manifest, which are fornication, uncleanness, debauchery,
5.20: idolatry, sorcery, enmities, strife, jealousy, animosities, selfseekings, divisions, heresies,
5.21: envyings, drunkenness, revellings, and things like unto these: which I tell you beforehand, as I did previously say to you, that those doing such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God.
5.22: But the fruit of the Spirit is divine love, joy, peace, long suffering, kindness, goodness, faith,
5.23: meekness, holiness; against such things there is no law.
5.24: But those belonging to Christ Jesus have crucified carnality with the passions and lusts.
5.25: If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit.
5.26: Let us not be fond of vain glory, provoking one another, envying one another.

6.1: Brethren, if indeed a man may be overtaken in some transgression, you who are spiritual, perfect such an one in the spirit of meekness; watching yourself, lest you may also be tempted.
6.2: Bear the burdens of one another, and so fulfill the law of Christ.
6.3: For if any one seems to be something, being nothing, he deceives himself.
6.4: But let each one prove his own work, and then he shall have rejoicing to himself alone, and not to another;
6.5: for each one shall bear his own responsibility.
6.6: But let the one who is taught the word communicate to the one teaching in all good things.
6.7: Be not deceived; God is not mocked. For whatsoever a man may sow, that shall he also reap:
6.8: because the one sowing to his own flesh shall of the flesh reap corruption; but the one sowing to the Spirit, shall of the Spirit reap eternal life.
6.9: But let us not get weary doing that which is good: for in due time we will reap, fainting not.
6.10: Then therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all, especially to those who are of the household of faith.
6.11: You see with how large letters I have written unto you with my own hand.
6.12: So many as wish to make a fair show in the flesh, these compel you to be circumcised; only that they do not suffer persecution on account of the cross of Christ.
6.13: For neither do those who are circumcised keep the law; but they wish you to be circumcised, in order that they may glory in your flesh.
6.14: But it would be impossible for me to glory, except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by which the world has been crucified to me, and I to the world:
6.15: for neither is circumcision anything, nor uncircumcision, but a new creature.
6.16: And so many as shall walk by this rule, peace and mercy be unto them, and unto the Israel of God.
6.17: Finally let no one give me troubles: for I bear in my own body the marks of Jesus.
6.18: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, brethren: Amen.

1.1: Paul, the apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, to the saints who are in Ephesus, and to the faithful in Christ Jesus.
1.2: Grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: Blessed is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the one having blessed us with all spiritual blessing in the heavenlies in Christ:
1.4: as he elected us in himself before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless in his presence.
1.5: in love having predestinated us unto the adoption of sons unto himself through Jesus Christ, according to the good pleasure of his will,
1.6: unto the praise of the glory of his grace, with which he has blessed us in the Beloved:
1.7: in whom we have redemption through his blood, the remission of transgressions, according to the riches of his grace,
1.8: which he has abounded unto us in all wisdom and understanding,
1.9: having made known unto us the mystery of his will, according to his own good pleasure, which he purposed in himself
1.10: in the economy of the fulness of the times, to rehead all things in Christ, those in the heavens, and those upon the earth; in him,
1.11: in whom we were also chosen by lot, having been predestinated according to the purpose of him who works all things within us according to the counsel of his own will;
1.12: that we should be unto the praise of his glory, who first exercised hope in Christ:
1.13: in whom you also, having heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation, in whom, also having believed, you were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promise,
1.14: who is the earnest of our salvation, unto the redemption of the possession, unto the praise of his glory.
1.15: Therefore I also, having heard of the faith among you in the Lord Jesus, and your love which is toward all the saints,
1.16: I do not cease giving thanks for you making mention of you in my prayers;
1.17: in order that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of the glory, may grant unto you the spirit of wisdom and of revelation in the perfect knowledge of himself;
1.18: the eyes of your heart having been enlightened, that you may know what is the hope of his calling, what the riches of the glory of his inheritance among the saints,
1.19: and what the excellent majesty of his power toward us who believe, according to the working of the power of his might
1.20: which he has wrought in Christ, raising him from the dead, and seating him on his right hand in the heavenlies,
1.21: above all government, and authority, and power, and lordship, and every name named, not only in this age, but in the age to come:
1.22: and has subordinated all things beneath his feet, and given him to be head over all things to the church,
1.23: which is his body, the fulness of him who fills all things in all.

2.1: You, who were dead in trespasses and in your sins,
2.2: in which at one time you walked about according to the age of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, the spirit which is now working in the sons of disobedience;
2.3: among whom we all indeed at one time lived in the lusts of our flesh, doing the will of the flesh and of the thoughts, and we were by nature the children of wrath, like the rest also:
2.4: but God, being rich in mercy, on account of his great love with which he loved us,
2.5: created life in us in Christ, who were dead in trespasses, by grace you have been saved,
2.6: and he has raised you up, and caused you to sit in the heavenlies, in Christ Jesus:
2.7: in order that he may show in coming ages the superabounding riches of his grace in kindness toward us in Christ Jesus.
2.8: For by grace you have been saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God:
2.9: not of works, in order that no one may boast:
2.10: for we are his workmanship, having been created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God before prepared that we should walk in them.
2.11: Therefore remember, that when you were Gentiles in the flesh, called Uncircumcision by that which is called Circumcision, made in the flesh with hands;
2.12: because you were at that time without Christ, being alienated from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers of the covenants of the promise, having no hope and being atheists in the world.
2.13: But now you are in Christ Jesus, who being at one time far off have been made nigh by the blood of Christ.
2.14: For he is our peace, the one having made both one, and having broken down the middle wall of partition,
2.15: having destroyed the law of commandments in ordinances, through his flesh, the enmity, in order that He might create the two in himself into one new man, making peace;
2.16: and that he may reconcile both in one body to God through the cross, having slain the enmity on in.
2.17: And having come he preached the gospel of peace to you, who were far away, and peace to them who were nigh:
2.18: because through him we both have access in one Spirit to the Father.
2.19: Then therefore you are no longer strangers and sojourners, but fellow-citizens of the saints, and members of the household of God,
2.20: having been built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief cornerstone,
2.21: in whom the entire edifice, being assimilated, increases into a holy temple in the Lord;
2.22: in whom also you are built together into a habitation of God in the Spirit.

3.1: Therefore I Paul, the prisoner of Christ for the sake of you Gentiles,
3.2: if indeed you have heard the economy of the grace of God which is given to me unto you;
3.3: that according to revelation the mystery was made known to me, as I formerly wrote to you briefly,
3.4: according to which you, reading, are able to know my understanding in the mystery of Christ;
3.5: which in other generations was not made known to the sons of men, as it is now revealed to his holy apostles and prophets through the Spirit;
3.6: that the Gentiles are to be fellow-heirs, and the same body, and partakers of the promise of Christ Jesus through the gospel,
3.7: whose minister I became, according to the gift of the grace of God which was given unto me; according to the working of his power.
3.8: To me, the least of all saints, was this grace given, to preach to the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ;
3.9: and to shine forth what is the economy of the mystery which has been hidden from the ages in God who created all things;
3.10: in order that the manifold wisdom of God through the church, may now be made known to the governments and authorities in the heavenlies,
3.11: according to the purpose of the ages which he made in Christ Jesus our Lord.
3.12: In whom we have boldness and access with confidence through the faith of him.
3.13: Therefore I ask that you faint not in my tribulations in your behalf, which is your glory.
3.14: For this cause I bow my knees to the Father,
3.15: of whom the whole family in heavens and upon earth is named,
3.16: in order that he may grant unto you, according to the riches of his glory, that you be strengthened with might by his Spirit in the inner man;
3.17: that Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith;
3.18: being rooted and grounded in divine love, in order that you may be able to comprehend with all saints what is the breadth and length and depth and height,
3.19: and to know the divine love of Christ which transcends knowledge, in order that you may be filled with all the fulness of God.
3.20: And to him who is able to do exceedingly above all things which we ask or think, according to the power working in us,
3.21: to him be glory in the church indeed in Christ Jesus unto all the generations of the age of the ages: Amen.

4.1: Therefore I, the prisoner in the Lord, exhort you to walk worthily of the calling with which you are called,
4.2: with all humility and meekness, with long suffering, forbearing one another in divine love;
4.3: endeavoring to keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace.
4.4: There is one body and one Spirit, as ye indeed are called in one hope of your calling;
4.5: one Lord, one faith, one baptism,
4.6: one God and Father of all, who is above all, and through all, and above you all, and in all.
4.7: And to each one of you grace is given according to the measure of the gift of Christ.
4.8: Therefore he says, Having ascended upon high, he led captivity captive, and gave gifts to the people.
4.9: But what is that which ascended, except that which descended into the lower parts of the earth?
4.10: But the one having descended and the one having ascended above all the heavens, that he might fill all things, is the same.
4.11: And he gave some, apostles; some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers;
4.12: unto the perfection of the saints, in the work of the ministry, in the edification of the body of Christ:
4.13: until we may all come into the unity of the faith, and of the perfect knowledge of the Son of God, into a perfect man, into the measure of the likeness of the fulness of Christ:
4.14: in order that we may be no longer infants, tossed by the waves and carried about by every wind of teaching, in the caprice of the people, in their craftiness, pursuant to their method of delusion;
4.15: but speaking the truth in divine love, let its grow up in him in all things, who is the head, Christ;
4.16: from whom the whole body, being assimilated and knitted together through every joint of the supply, according to the working in each several part, makes increase of the body in the edification of itself in divine love.
4.17: Therefore I say this, and witness in the Lord, that you no longer walk about as the Gentiles also walk about in the vanity of their mind,
4.18: being darkened in their understanding, alienated from the life of God through the ignorance being in themselves, on account of the blindness of their heart;
4.19: who being past feeling have given themselves up to debauchery, unto the working of all impurity with greediness.
4.20: But you did not so learn Christ:
4.21: if indeed ye have heard him, and been taught in him, as the truth is in Jesus:
4.22: that with reference to your former life, you are to lay aside the old man, who is corrupt in the lusts of deception;
4.23: and to be renewed in the spirit of your mind,
4.24: and to put on the new man, who has been created in harmony with God in the righteousness and holiness of the truth.
4.25: Therefore, having laid aside lying, speak the truth each one with his neighbors: because we are members of one another.
4.26: Be ye angry, and sin not: let not the sun go down upon your provocation:
4.27: neither give place to the devil.
4.28: Let the one stealing steal no more: but rather let him labor, working with his own hands doing that which is good, that he may have to give to the one having need.
4.29: Let no corrupt communication go forth out of your mouth, but if anything is good unto edification of need, in order that he may give grace to those who hear.
4.30: And grieve not the Holy Spirit of God, by whom you were sealed unto the day of redemption.
4.31: Let all bitterness, and wrath, and anger, and clamor, and blasphemy, depart from you, with all evil.
4.32: But be ye kind toward one another, merciful, forgiving one another, as indeed God in Christ forgave you.

5.1: Therefore be ye imitators of God, as beloved children;
5.2: and walk about in divine love, as Christ also loved you, and gave himself for you, an offering and a sacrifice to God for an odor of sweet savor.
5.3: But all fornication, and uncleanness, or covetousness, let it not be named among you, as it becomes saints;
5.4: and indecorum, or foolish talking, or indecent jesting, which is not becoming, but rather the giving of thanks:
5.5: for you are knowing this, that no fornicator, or unclean person, or covetous, who is an idolater, has an inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God.
5.6: Let no one deceive you with empty words: for through these the wrath of God comes on the sons of disobedience.
5.7: Therefore be not partakers along with them.
5.8: For at one time ye were darkness, but now ye are light in the Lord: walk about as children of the light,
5.9: (for the fruit of the light is in all goodness and righteousness and truth),
5.10: proving what is acceptable to the Lord;
5.11: and have no fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness, but rather indeed convict them.
5.12: For it is disgraceful even to speak of those things which are done by them in concealment:
5.13: but all things being convicted by the light are made manifest; for everything made manifest is light.
5.14: Therefore he says, Awake, thou sleeper, and arise from the dead, and Christ will shine upon thee.
5.15: Therefore see how you walk about circumspectly, not as unwise, but wise;
5.16: buying in the opportunity, because the days are evil.
5.17: Therefore be not unwise, but understand whatsoever is the will of the Lord.
5.18: Be not drunk with wine, in which there is riot, but be ye filled with the Spirit;
5.19: speaking one to another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord,
5.20: always giving thanks for all things in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ to God, even the Father;
5.21: being submissive to one another in the fear of Christ.
5.22: Wives, be submissive to your own husbands, as to the Lord,
5.23: because the husband is the head of the wife, as Christ is also the head of the church, being himself the saviour of the body.
5.24: But as the church is submissive to Christ, so also let the wives be to their husbands in everything.
5.25: Husbands, love your wives with divine love, as Christ also loved the church with divine love, and gave himself for her;
5.26: in order that he might sanctify her, having purified her by the washing of water through the word,
5.27: in order that he might present to himself the glorious church, having not spot or wrinkle or any of such things; but that she might be holy and blameless.
5.28: So the husbands ought to love their own wives with divine love as their own bodies. The one loving his own wife is loving himself:
5.29: for no one ever yet hated his own flesh; but he nourishes and cherishes it, as Christ also the church;
5.30: because we are members of his body:
5.31: on account of this a man shall leave his father and mother and cleave unto his wife: and they two shall be one flesh.
5.32: This is a great mystery: but I speak in reference to Christ and the church.
5.33: Moreover you also each one thus love his own wife with divine love as himself; and that the wife also reverence the husband.

6.1: Children, obey your parents in the Lord: for this is right.
6.2: Honor your father and mother, which is the first commandment with promise,
6.3: that it may be well with you, and you may live long upon the earth.
6.4: And fathers, provoke not your children to wrath: but bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.
6.5: Ye servants, obey those who are your masters according to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in purity of your heart, as unto Christ;
6.6: not with eyeservice, as menpleasers, but as the servants of Christ doing the will of God from the soul;
6.7: serving with good will as the Lord, and not men:
6.8: knowing that if each one may do good, he will receive this with the Lord, whether bond or free.
6.9: And, ye masters, do the same things to them, forbearing threatening: knowing that their Master and yours is in the heavens, and that there is no respect of persons with him.
6.10: Finally, be filled up with dynamite in the Lord, and in the power of his might.
6.11: Put on the panoply of God, that you may be able to stand against the methods of the devil,
6.12: because there is not to us fighting against blood and flesh, but against the governments, against the authorities, against the world-rulers of this darkness, against the spirits of wickedness in the heavenlies.
6.13: Therefore take the panoply of God, that you may be able to stand in the evil day, and having done all things, to stand.
6.14: Stand therefore, being girded about as to your loins with truth, and being invested with the breastplate of righteousness,
6.15: and being shod as to your feet with the preparation of the gospel of peace;
6.16: in all things taking the shield of faith, with which you shall be able to quench all the fiery darts of the wicked one.
6.17: And receive the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God:
6.18: praying with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit in every place, and watching unto this same thing in all perseverance and prayer for all the saints,
6.19: and for me that the word may be given unto me in opening of my mouth, boldly to make known the mystery of the gospel,
6.20: for which I am an ambassador in chain; in order that in it I may preach boldly, as it behooves me to speak.
6.21: But in order that you may also know the things concerning me, how I am doing, Tychicus, my beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord, will make known to you:
6.22: whom I sent to you unto this same thing, in order that you may know the affairs concerning us, and he may comfort your hearts.
6.23: Peace and divine love to the brethren, with faith, from God our Father and our Lord Jesus Christ.
6.24: Grace be with all who love the Lord Jesus Christ with divine love in purity.

1.1: Paul and Timothy, the servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints who are at Philippi, with the bishops and deacons.
1.2: Grace and peace unto you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: I thank my God for every mention of you,
1.4: always in all my prayer with joy making supplication,
1.5: for your fellowship in the gospel from the first clay until now;
1.6: having confidence as to this same thing, that the one having begun a good work in you will perfect it unto the day of Jesus Christ:
1.7: as it is righteous for me to think in behalf of you all, because I have you in my heart, both in my bonds and in the defence and confirmation of the gospel, that you are all my fellow-partakers of the grace.
1.8: For God is my witness, how I long after you in the affections of Jesus Christ.
1.9: And I pray this, that your divine love may yet more and more abound in perfect knowledge and all understanding;
1.10: in order that you may distinguish those things which differ; that you may be pure and without offence in the day of Christ;
1.11: being filled with the fruit of righteousness, through Jesus Christ, unto the glory and praise of God.
1.12: But I wish you, brethren, to know that the affairs appertaining to me have turned out rather unto the promotion of the gospel.
1.13: So that my bonds in Christ are manifest in all the pretorian army, and to all the rest;
1.14: and many of the brethren in the Lord, being confident through my bonds, are bold to speak the word of God more fluently without fear.
1.15: Some indeed through envy and strife, and some through good will, are preaching Christ:
1.16: the latter from divine love, knowing that I am set for the defence of the gospel:
1.17: the former from self-seeking are proclaiming Christ insincerely, thinking that they will add affliction to my bonds.
1.18: For what is it? moreover that in every place, whether in pretext or in truth, Christ is proclaimed; and I rejoice in this, yes, and I will rejoice.
1.19: For I know that this will turn out to me unto salvation, through your prayer and the supply of the Spirit of Jesus Christ,
1.20: according to my earnest expectation and hope, that I shall be ashamed in nothing, but with all boldness, as always, even now Christ will be magnified in my body, whether by life, or by death.
1.21: For Christ is my life, and death is my gain.
1.22: But if to live in the flesh, this shall be to me the fruit of the work, indeed I know not what I shall ask.
1.23: But I am in a strait between two, having a desire to depart and to be with Christ; for this is far better:
1.24: but to remain in the flesh is safer on account of you.
1.25: And having confidence in this, I know that I shall abide with you all, unto your promotion and the joy of your faith;
1.26: in order that your rejoicing in Christ Jesus may abound in me through my coming again unto you.
1.27: Only live worthily of the gospel of Christ: in order that, whether coming and seeing you or being absent, I hear those things concerning you, that you are standing in one spirit, with one soul contending for the faith of the gospel;
1.28: and not being intimidated in anything by the adversaries: which is to them the manifestation of destruction, but of your salvation, and this is from God;
1.29: because the blessing is conferred on you in behalf of Christ, not only to believe on him, but indeed to suffer for him:
1.30: having the same conflict as you saw in me, and now hearing me.

2.1: If then there is any consolation in Christ, if there is any comfort of divine love, if any fellowship of the Spirit, if any affection and mercies,
2.2: fill my joy, that you may think the same thing, having the same divine love, being like-minded, thinking this one thing;
2.3: that nothing is to be according to self-seeking nor according to vain glory, but in humility esteeming one another better than yourselves;
2.4: looking not each after your own interests, but each after that of others.
2.5: Think the same thing among yourselves, which is also in Christ Jesus:
2.6: who, being in the form of God, thought it not usurpation to be equal with God,
2.7: but he humbled himself, having taken the form of a servant, being in the likeness of men; and having been found in fashion like a man;
2.8: he humbled himself, being obedient even unto death, yea, the death of the cross.
2.9: Therefore God has indeed exalted him, and given him a name above every name;
2.10: that at the name of Jesus every knee must bow, of things in heaven and things upon the earth and things beneath the earth,
2.11: and every tongue shall confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, unto the glory of God the Father.
2.12: So, my beloved brethren, as you have always harkened, not only in my presence, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling;
2.13: for God is the one working in you both to will and to do, of his own good pleasure.
2.14: Do all things without murmurings and disputatious;
2.15: in order that you may be blameless and pure, the children of God, irreproachable, amid a crooked and perverse generation, among whom you shine as lights in the world,
2.16: having the word of life; unto my boasting in the day of Christ, because I did not run in vain, neither did I labor in vain.
2.17: But if indeed I am poured out for a sacrifice and an offering for your faith, I rejoice, and rejoice along with you all;
2.18: but you also rejoice in this same thing, and rejoice along with me.
2.19: But I hope in the Lord Jesus, speedily to send unto you Timothy, in order that I may also be delighted, having learned the things concerning you.
2.20: For I have no one like-minded, who will nobly remember the things concerning you;
2.21: for all are seeking after their own, and not the things of Jesus Christ.
2.22: But you know his integrity, that, as a child a father, he served along with me in the gospel.
2.23: Indeed then I hope to send him, so soon as I may learn the things concerning myself:
2.24: but I trust in the Lord that I myself will come speedily.
2.25: But I thought it necessary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother and fellow-laborer and fellow-soldier, and apostle and the minister of my necessity;
2.26: since he was longing after you all, and grieving, because you heard that he was sick.
2.27: For he was indeed nigh unto death: but God had mercy on him; and not only him, but me also, in order that I may not have sorrow upon sorrow.
2.28: Therefore I the more diligently, in order that, seeing him, you may rejoice again, and I may not be without sorrow.
2.29: Then receive him in the Lord with all joy, and have such in honor:
2.30: because he was nigh unto death on account of the work of Christ, having jeoparded his life, in order that he might fulfill your deficiency of ministry towards me.

3.1: Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord. To write the same things to you indeed is not burdensome to me, but it is safe to you.
3.2: Beware of dogs, beware of the evil workers, beware of the counterfeit circumcision.
3.3: For we are the circumcision, who serve the Spirit of God, and boast in Christ Jesus, also having no confidence in the flesh:
3.4: even though also having confidence in the flesh. If any other one seems to have confidence in the flesh, I the more:
3.5: in circumcision the eighth day, of the race of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, a Hebrew of the Hebrews; as touching the law, a Pharisee;
3.6: in reference to zeal, persecuting the church, according to righteousness which was in the law being blameless.
3.7: Those things which were gained to me, these I counted loss for the sake of Christ.
3.8: Yes truly, I even counted all things loss on account of the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord, for the sake of whom I suffer the loss of all things, and I consider them but excrements, that I may gain Christ,
3.9: and may be found in him, not having my own righteousness, which is of law, but that which is through faith of Christ, the righteousness of God through faith:
3.10: to know him, and the power of his resurrection, and the fellowship of his sufferings, being made conformable unto his death;
3.11: if perchance I may attain unto the resurrection which is out from the dead.
3.12: Not that I already received it, or have already been made perfect: but I persevere, if I may receive that for which I have indeed been received by Christ Jesus.
3.13: Brethren, I do not consider that I have yet received it;
3.14: but there is one thing, indeed forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forward to those which are before, I press toward the goal unto the mark of the high calling of God in Christ Jesus.
3.15: Therefore let us, so many as are perfect, think the same thing: and if you think otherwise in any respect, God will also reveal this to you:
3.16: only, whereunto we have already attained, to walk by the same rule.
3.17: Be ye my imitators, brethren, and mark those thus walking about as you have us an example.
3.18: For many walk about, of whom I frequently spoke to you, and now I speak even weeping, the enemies of the cross of Christ:
3.19: whose end is destruction, whose God is their stomach, and whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things.
3.20: For our citizenship is in the heavens; whence we are indeed looking for our Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ:
3.21: who will transform the body of our humility, similitudinous to the body of his own glory, according to the energy by which he is able indeed to subdue all things to himself.

4.1: So, my beloved and longed for brethren, my joy and my crown, stand fast in the Lord, beloved.
4.2: I exhort, Euodia, and I exhort Syntyche, to think the same thing in the Lord.
4.3: Yea, I also entreat thee, noble yoke-fellow, assist those women, whosoever labored with me in the gospel, both along with Clement, and the rest of my fellow-workers, whose names are in the book of life.
4.4: Rejoice in the Lord always: I say to you again, Rejoice.
4.5: Let your clemency be made known to all men; the Lord is nigh.
4.6: Be solicitous about nothing; but in all prayer and supplication, let your request be made known to God.
4.7: And the peace of God, that passes all understanding, will keep your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
4.8: Finally, brethren, so many things as are true, so many things as are noble, so many things as are righteous, so many things as are pure, so many things as are lovely, so many things as are of good report; if there is any virtue, and if there is any praise, think on these things.
4.9: Whatsoever things you have indeed learned and received and heard and seen in me, do the same: and the God of peace will be with you.
4.10: But I greatly rejoice in the Lord, because indeed you have at length revived to think about me; in whatsoever you indeed were thinking, nevertheless you lacked opportunity.
4.11: Not that I speak concerning deficiency: for I have learned to be content with those things amid which I am.
4.12: I indeed know how to be poor, and I know how to abound: in every thing and in all things I learned both to flourish and to be poor, both to abound and to be destitute.
4.13: I can do all things through him who fills me up with dynamite.
4.14: Moreover you did beautifully, communicating with my tribulation.
4.15: And you indeed know, O Philippians, that in the beginning of the gospel, when I came out from Macedonia, no church communicated with me in the word of giving and receiving, except you alone;
4.16: because also in Thessalonica both once and twice you sent to my need.
4.17: Not that I seek a gift; but I seek fruit abounding to your credit.
4.18: But I have all things, and I abound: I am full, having received from Epaphroditus those things from you, an odor of a sweet savor, a sacrifice acceptable, well-pleasing to God.
4.19: But my God will supply all your need according to his riches in glory in Christ Jesus.
4.20: To God even our Father be the glory unto the ages of the ages. Amen.
4.21: Salute every saint in Christ Jesus. The brethren who are with me salute you.
4.22: All the saints, and especially those from the house of Caesar, salute you.
4.23: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

1.1: Paul, the apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, and brother Timothy,
1.2: to the saints who are in Colossae and the faithful brethren in Christ. Grace to you and peace from God our Father.
1.3: We give thanks to God even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, always praying for you,
1.4: having heard of your faith in Christ Jesus, and the divine love which you have toward all the saints.
1.5: on account of the hope which awaits you in the heavens, which you heard before in the word of the truth of the gospel,
1.6: having come to you, as it is indeed in the whole world bearing fruit and increasing, as also among you, from the day on which you heard and have known the grace of God in truth;
1.7: as you have learned from Epaphras our beloved fellow-servant, who is the faithful minister of Christ your behalf,
1.8: who also having revealed to us your divine love in the Spirit.
1.9: Therefore we, from the day on which we heard, do not cease praying for you, and asking that you may be filled with the perfect knowledge of his will in all wisdom, and spiritual understanding,
1.10: that you may walk worthily of the Lord in all loyalty, in every good work bearing fruit, and increasing in the perfect knowledge of God.
1.11: being impowered with all power, according to the might of his glory, in all patience and longsuffering with joy;
1.12: giving thanks to the Father, who has made us worthy unto a participation of the inheritance of the saints in light;
1.13: who delivered us from the power of darkness, and transplanted us into the kingdom of the Son of his love;
1.14: in whom we have redemption, the remission of sins:
1.15: who is the image of the invisible God, being the first begotten of all creation,
1.16: because in him all things are created, in the heavens and upon the earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or lordships or governments or authorities. All things were created by him, and unto him;
1.17: and he before all things, and all things consist in him:
1.18: and himself is the head of the body, the church: who is the beginning, the first begotten from the dead, in order that in all things himself may be preeminent:
1.19: because in him all fulness is pleased to dwell;
1.20: and through him, to reconcile all things unto himself, having made peace through the blood of his cross: through him, whether things upon the earth, or things in the heavens.
1.21: And you, being at one time aliens and enemies in your minds on account of wicked works, nevertheless he has now reconciled
1.22: in the body of his cross through death, to present you holy and blameless and unreprovable before him,
1.23: if you abide in the faith, having been grounded and firm, and not moved from the hope of the gospel which you have heard, having been preached in all creation which is under heaven; whose minister I Paul became.
1.24: Now I rejoice in sufferings in your behalf, and am filling up the residue of the afflictions of Christ in my flesh in behalf of his body, which is the church;
1.25: whose minister I became, according to the economy of God which was given to me unto you, to fulfill the word of God,
1.26: the mystery which has been hidden from ages and from the generations: but is now made manifest to his saints,
1.27: to whom God willed to make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles, who is Christ in you, the hope of glory:
1.28: whom we preach, admonishing every man and teaching every man in all wisdom, in order that we may present every man perfect in Christ;
1.29: unto which I also labor, agonizing according to his energy, working in me with power.

2.1: For I wish you to know how great a conflict I have in behalf of you, and those in Laodicea, and so many as have not seen my face in the flesh;
2.2: in order that their hearts may be comforted, being knitted together in divine love, and in all the riches of the full assurance of understanding, unto the perfect knowledge of the mystery of God, of Christ,
2.3: in whom are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
2.4: I say this in order that no one may deceive you with a persuasive speech.
2.5: For if I am absent in the flesh, but I am present with you in spirit, rejoicing and seeing your order, and the establishment of your faith toward Christ.
2.6: Therefore as you received Christ Jesus the Lord, walk about in him,
2.7: having been rooted and grounded in him, and confirmed in the faith, as you have been taught, abounding in thanksgiving.
2.8: See that no one shall be deceiving you through philosophy and empty delusion, according to the tradition of men, according to the elements of the world, and not according to Christ,
2.9: because in him dwells all the fulness of the Godhead bodily,
2.10: and you are complete in him, who is the head of all government and authority:
2.11: in whom you are also circumcised with the circumcision made without hands, in putting off the body of depravity, in the circumcision of Christ;
2.12: having been buried with him in baptism, in which you are also raised by the faith of the operation of God, who raised him from the dead:
2.13: and you, being dead in trespasses and in the uncircumcision of your depravity, has he created life in you along with himself, having forgiven us all transgressions,
2.14: having blotted out the handwriting which was against us in ordinances, which was antagonistical to us: and took it out from the midst, having nailed it to the cross;
2.15: having destroyed governments and authorities, he made a public exhibition of them triumphing over them on it.
2.16: Therefore let no one judge you in meat, or in drink, or in the participation of a feast, or of the new moon, or of the sabbath:
2.17: which things are a shadow of the things to come; but the body is of Christ.
2.18: Let no one purposely rob you of your prize by humiliation and worship of the angels, trusting in those things which he has seen, being vainly puffed up by the mind of his depravity,
2.19: and not holding the Head, from which the entire body, by joints and ligaments being supplied and knitted together, increases the increase of God.
2.20: If along with Christ you are dead from the elements of the world, why are you dogmatized as living in the world,
2.22: those things which are all unto destruction by use according to the commandments and teachings of the people?
2.23: Which indeed are having a word of wisdom in will worship, and humiliation, and austerity of the body; not in any value against the indulgence of the flesh.

3.1: If then ye are risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, where Christ is, sitting on the right hand of God;
3.2: think about those things above, and not things upon the earth.
3.3: For ye are dead, and your life is hidden with Christ in God:
3.4: when Christ, your life, may appear, then will you also appear with him in glory.
3.5: Therefore kill your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleanness, passion, evil desire, and covetousness, which is idolatry;
3.6: through which the wrath of God comes.
3.7: In which you indeed at one time did walk about, when you lived in them:
3.8: but you also lay aside all these; anger, wrath, malice, blasphemy, disgraceful talk out of your mouths:
3.9: lie not to one another, having laid aside the old man with his habits,
3.10: and having put on the new man, who is renewed into perfect knowledge according to the image of him who created him:
3.11: where there is not Greek and Jew, circumcision and uncircumcision, barbarian, Scythian, bond, free: but Christ is all things, and in all.
3.12: Therefore, as elect of God, holy and beloved, put on affections of mercy, kindness, humility, meekness, longsuffering;
3.13: forbearing one another and forgiving one another, if any one may have a quarrel against any one; as Christ also forgave you, so indeed do you likewise:
3.14: and in all these things put on divine love, which is the bond of perfection.
3.15: And let the peace of Christ reign in your hearts, in which you are called in one body; and be ye thankful.
3.16: Let the word of God dwell in you richly, teaching and admonishing one another, in all wisdom, in psalms, hymns, spiritual songs, with grace making melody in your hearts to God;
3.17: and every thing whatsoever you may do, in word or in work, do all things in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through him.
3.18: Ye wives, submit to your husbands as is becoming in the Lord.
3.19: Ye husbands, love your wives with divine love, and be not harsh towards them.
3.20: Children, obey your parents in all things, for this is well-pleasing in the Lord.
3.21: Ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath, in order that they may not be discouraged.
3.22: Ye servants, obey your masters according to the flesh in all things; not with eye-service, pleasing men, but of purity of heart, fearing the Lord.
3.23: Whatsoever you may do, work from your soul, as for the Lord, and not for men;
3.24: knowing that you will receive the recompense of the inheritance from the Lord. Serve the Lord Christ;
3.25: for the one doing wrong receives that for which he did the injustice: and there is no respect of persons.

4.1: Masters, award unto the servants that which is right and equal; knowing that you also have a Master in heaven.
4.2: Be constant in prayer, watching in the same with thanksgiving;
4.3: at the same time also praying for us, in order that God may open to us the door of the word, to speak the mystery of Christ, on account of which I indeed am bound;
4.4: in order that I may manifest the same, as it behooves me to speak.
4.5: Walk about in wisdom toward the aliens, buying in the opportunity.
4.6: Let your word be always with grace, seasoned with salt, that you may know how it behooves you to answer each one.
4.7: Tychicus, my beloved brother, and faithful minister and fellow-laborer in the Lord, will make known to you all things which appertain to me:
4.8: whom I sent unto you for this same thing, in order that you may know the things concerning us, and he may comfort your hearts;
4.9: along with our faithful and beloved brother, Onesimus, who is from you; they will truly make known all things to you.
4.10: Aristarchus my fellow-soldier salutes you, and Mark the cousin of Barnabas concerning whom you received commandments; if he may come to you, receive him;
4.11: and Jesus, called Justus, who being of the circumcision: these are my only fellow-laborers in the kingdom of God, who have been made a comfort to me.
4.12: Epaphras, who is from you, the servant of Jesus Christ, always agonizing in your behalf in his prayers, in order that you may stand perfect even having been fully carried away in all the will of God, salutes you.
4.13: For I testify to him, that he always has much solicitude for you, and those who are in Laodicea, and those who are in Hierapolis.
4.14: Luke, the beloved physician, and Demas salute you.
4.15: Salute the brethren who are in Laodicea, and Nymphas, and the church which is in their house.
4.16: And when the letter may be read by you, cause that it may also be read in the church of the Laodiceans; and that you may also read the letter from Laodicea.
4.17: And say to Archippus; Take heed to the ministry which you received in the Lord, that you may fill it.
4.18: Salutation of me Paul with my own hand. Remember my bonds. Grace be with you.

1.1: Paul, and Silvanus, and Timothy, to the church of the Thessalonians in God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. Grace to you and peace.
1.2: We give thanks to God always for you all, making mention in our prayers;
1.3: incessantly remembering your work of faith and labor of love and patience of hope of our Lord Jesus Christ, before God even our Father;
1.4: knowing, brethren beloved of God, your election,
1.5: because our gospel came not unto you in word only, but in power, and in the Holy Ghost, and in much assurance; as you know what sort we were among you for your sakes.
1.6: And you became imitators of us, and the Lord, having received the word in much tribulation, with the joy of the Holy Ghost;
1.7: so that you are an example to all the believers in Macedonia and in Achaia.
1.8: For from you the word of the Lord echoed out, not only in Macedonia and in Achaia, but in every place your faith which is towards God has gone forth; so that we have no need to say any thing:
1.9: for they proclaim concerning what kind of reception we had unto you; and how you turned to God from the idols, to serve the true and the living God,
1.10: and to await his Son out of the heavens, whom he raised from the dead, Jesus the one delivering us from the wrath to come.

2.1: For you know, brethren, our coming unto you, that it was not in vain:
2.2: but having suffered, and been abused, as you know, at Philippi, we were bold in our God to speak to you the gospel of God in much conflict.
2.3: For our exhortation was not from delusion, nor from impurity, nor in guile:
2.4: but as we were approved of God that the gospel should be intrusted unto us, so we speak; not as pleasing men, but God who is proving our hearts,
2.5: For at that time we were not in word of flattery, as you know, nor in a pretext of covetousness, God is our witness;
2.6: nor seeking glory from men, nor from you, nor from others, being able to be burdensome, as the apostles of Christ;
2.7: but we were gentle in the midst of you, as if a nurse may cherish her children;
2.8: being so desirous of you, that we are anxious not only to give the gospel of God, but our own souls, because you are beloved unto us.
2.9: For you remember, brethren, our labor and toil: night and day working, that we should burden no one of you, we preached unto you the gospel of God.
2.10: You are witnesses, and God, how sacredly and righteously and blamelessly we were unto you who believed:
2.11: as you know, exhorting each one of you, as a father of his own children, and comforting you,
2.12: and testifying, that you walk worthily of God, who calls you into his own kingdom and glory.
2.13: And on account of this we also give thanks to God incessantly, because, receiving the word of God from us by hearing, you received it not as the word of men, but, as it truly is, the word of God, who indeed works in you who believe.
2.14: For ye, brethren, became imitators of the churches of God which are in Judea in Jesus Christ: because you suffered the same things from your fellow tribes, as they also from the Jews;
2.15: who even killed the Lord Jesus and the prophets, and persecuted us, and are displeasing to God, and hostile to all men;
2.16: forbidding that we should speak to the Gentiles in order that they may be saved; that they may fill up their sins always: but the wrath is come upon them to the uttermost.
2.17: But, brethren, we having been absent from you for the space of an hour, in presence, not in heart, we were the more exceedingly anxious to see your face with much desire.
