2.18: Because we wish to come to you, I Paul indeed both once and twice; and Satan hindered me.
2.19: For what is our hope, or joy, or crown of rejoicing, except you, in the presence of our Lord Jesus Christ at his coming?
2.20: For you are our glory and joy.

3.1: Therefore no longer containing, we delighted to be left alone at Athens;
3.2: and we sent Timothy, our brother and minister of God in the gospel of Christ, in order to establish you, and exhort you concerning your faith;
3.3: that no one should be shaken in these tribulations. For you know that for this we are appointed.
3.4: For indeed, when we were with you, we foretold you that we are about to suffer tribulation; as indeed took place, and you know it.
3.5: Therefore I indeed, no longer containing, sent that I might know your faith, lest perhaps the tempter tempted you, and our labor may be in vain.
3.6: But Timothy, having already come to us from you, and proclaimed to us the good news of your faith and your divine love, and that you always have a good mention of us, longing to see us, as we do to see you;
3.7: therefore we were comforted, brethren, over you in all our distress and tribulation on account of your faith;
3.8: because we now live, if you stand in the Lord.
3.9: For what thanks are we able to render unto God in your behalf, for all the joy with which we rejoice on account of you before our God;
3.10: night and day praying incessantly that we may see your face, and perfect the deficiencies of your faith?
3.11: But God himself, even our Father, and our Lord Jesus, direct our way unto you:
3.12: and the Lord fill you and cause you to superabound in divine love toward one another, and toward all, even as we also do towards you;
3.13: in order to establish your hearts blameless in holiness in the presence of God even our Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus with all his saints: amen.

4.1: Finally therefore, brethren, we pray you and exhort you in the Lord Jesus, that as you received from us how it behooves you to walk about and to please God, as you do indeed walk about, in order that you may abound more and more.
4.2: For you know what promises we gave unto you through our Lord Jesus.
4.3: For this is the will of God, your sanctification, that you abstain from fornication;
4.4: that each one of you know how to possess his vessel in sanctification and honor,
4.5: not in the passion of lust, as indeed the Gentiles who do not know God;
4.6: that one should overreach and defraud his brother in a business transaction: because the Lord is the avenger concerning these things, as we indeed before told you and witnessed to you.
4.7: For God did not call us to uncleanness, but in sanctification.
4.8: Therefore the one rejecting (sanctification), does not reject man, but God, who indeed gives to you his Holy Spirit.
4.9: But concerning brotherly love you have no need that I write to you: for you yourselves are taught of God to love one another with divine love;
4.10: for you indeed are doing the same thing unto all the brethren in all Macedonia. And we exhort you, brethren, that you abound more and more;
4.11: and that you aspire to be quiet, and to prosecute your own employments, and work with your hands, as we proclaimed unto you;
4.12: in order that you may walk about circumspectly toward the aliens, and you may have need of nothing.
4.13: For we do not wish you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning those who are asleep; in order that you may not sorrow, even as those having no hope.
4.14: For if we believe that Jesus died and is risen, so also will God bring with him those who sleep in Jesus.
4.15: For we speak this to you in the word of the Lord, that we who are alive, who are left unto the coming of the Lord, can not anticipate those who are asleep,
4.16: because the Lord himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and the trump of God: and the dead in Christ shall rise first;
4.17: then we who are alive, who are left, will at the same time along with them be caught up in the clouds, to meet the Lord in the air; and so we will be always with the Lord.
4.18: So comfort one another with these words.

5.1: But concerning the times and seasons, brethren, you have no need that I write to you;
5.2: for you yourselves know well, that the day of the Lord is so coming like a thief in the night.
5.3: When they may say, Peace and safety, then sudden destruction comes on them, as travail upon a woman in gestation; and they can not escape.
5.4: But you, brethren, are not in darkness, that the day may overtake you like a thief:
5.5: for you are all the sons of light, and the sons of day: we are not of night, nor of darkness;
5.6: then therefore let us not sleep like the rest, but watch and be sober.
5.7: For those sleeping, sleep in the night; and those who are drunken, get drunk in the night:
5.8: but let us, who are of the day, be sober, having put on the breastplate of faith and divine love; and the helmet, the hope of salvation:
5.9: because God did not put us forth unto wrath, but unto the obtainment of salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ,
5.10: the one having died for us, in order that, whether we are awake or asleep, we shall at the same time live with him.
5.11: Therefore exhort one another, and edify either the other, as you indeed are doing.
5.12: But we intreat you, brethren, to know those who are laboring among you, and standing before you in the Lord, and admonishing you;
5.13: and that you yourselves esteem them exceedingly in divine love for the sake of their work. Live in peace among yourselves.
5.14: And we, exhort you, brethren, admonish the unruly, comfort the small-souled people, support the weak, be longsuffering toward all.
5.15: See that no one may return evil for evil to any one; but always pursue good toward one another, and toward all.
5.18: in every thing give thanks; for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus towards you.
5.21: but prove all things; and hold fast to the beautiful;
5.23: And the God of peace himself sanctify you wholly; and may your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless, in the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
5.24: Faithful is the one calling you, who indeed will do it.
5.26: Salute all the brethren with a holy kiss.
5.27: I adjure you in the name of the Lord, that this epistle shall be read to all the brethren.
5.28: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.

1.1: Paul, and Silvanus, and Timothy, unto the Church of the Thessalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.2: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and our Lord Jesus Christ.
1.3: We ought always to give thanks to God for you, brethren, as it is worthy, because your faith increases, and the divine love of each one of you all towards one another abounds more and more;
1.4: so that we ourselves rejoice over you in the churches of God, on account of your patience and faith in all your persecutions and tribulations which you endure;
1.5: the manifestation of the righteous judgment of God, that you may be counted worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you indeed suffer:
1.6: if indeed it is a righteous thing with God to recompense tribulation to them who are troubling you,
1.7: and to you who are troubled, rest with us, in the revelation of the Lord Jesus from heaven with the angels of his power
1.8: in the fire of flame, dispensing vengeance to those who know not God, and to those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus:
1.9: who shall suffer vengeance, eternal destruction from the face of the Lord and from the glory of his might,
1.10: when he may come to be glorified among his saints, and among all those who believe, to be wondered at in that day, because our testimony was believed by you.
1.11: Unto which indeed we are praying incessantly for you, in order that our God may count you worthy of the calling, and may fulfill all the good pleasure of his goodness and work of faith, with power;
1.12: in order that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and our Lord Jesus Christ.

2.1: But we beseech you, brethren, concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and our gathering unto him;
2.2: that you be not suddenly shaken from your mind, nor disturbed, whether by a spirit, or through word, or a letter as by us, as that the day of the Lord has come.
2.3: Let no one deceive you in any way: because unless there may first be an apostasy and the man of lawlessness may be revealed, the son of perdition,
2.4: the one opposing and exalting himself above everything that is called God or divinity; so that he sits in the temple of God, showing himself off that he is God.
2.5: Do you not remember that still being with you, I told you these things?
2.6: And now you know that which hinders, that he should be revealed in his time.
2.7: For already the mystery of lawlessness is working: only there is one now hindering, until he may be taken out of the midst;
2.8: then indeed will the lawless one be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus will remove by the spirit of his mouth, and will exterminate by the brightness of his coming;
2.9: whose coming is according to the energy of Satan in all power and signs and wonders of falsehood,
2.10: and in all the deception of unrighteousness to those who perish; because they did not receive the divine love of the truth, that they might be saved.
2.11: And on this account God sends to them the working of delusion, that they should believe a lie:
2.12: in order that they may all be condemned who did not believe the truth, but took pleasure in unrighteousness.
2.13: But we ought to give thanks to God always for you, brethren beloved of the Lord, because God chose you from the beginning unto salvation through sanctification of the Spirit and belief of the truth;
2.14: unto which He also called you through our gospel, unto the possession of the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
2.15: Then therefore, brethren, stand, and hold fast the traditions which you have been taught, whether by word, or by our epistle:
2.16: and our Lord Jesus Christ himself and God our Father, the one having loved us and given eternal consolation and good hope through grace,
2.17: comfort your hearts, and establish you in every good work and word.

3.1: Finally, brethren, pray for us in order that the word of the Lord may run and be glorified, as even unto you:
3.2: and in order that we may be delivered from the ungodly and wicked men; for faith does not belong to all.
3.3: But the Lord is faithful, who will establish you and keep you from the evil one.
3.4: And we have trusted in the Lord in your behalf, that you are doing, and will do whatsoever we command.
3.5: And the Lord direct your hearts into the love of God, and the patience of Christ.
3.6: And we command you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you withdraw from every brother who walks about disorderly, and not according to the teaching they received from us.
3.7: For you yourselves know how it behooves you to imitate us; because we were not disorderly among you;
3.8: neither did we eat bread with any one gratuitously, but with labor and toil, night and day working, that we might not burden any one of you:
3.9: not because we have not the right, but in order that we may give ourselves an example to you, that you may imitate us.
3.10: For indeed when we were with you, we proclaimed this to you, that if any one does not wish to work, let him not eat.
3.11: For we hear that there are certain ones walking about among you disorderly, doing nothing, but they are busybodies:
3.12: but we command such and exhort them in the Lord Jesus Christ, that with quietude working, they must eat their own bread.
3.13: But you, brethren, be not weary doing well.
3.14: But if any one does not obey our word through the epistle, note him; do not keep company with him; in order that he may be ashamed;
3.15: consider him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother.
3.16: The Lord of peace himself grant unto you peace always in every way. The Lord be with you all.
3.17: Salutation of me Paul with my own hand, which is the token in every epistle: so I write.
3.18: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.

1.1: Paul, the apostle of Jesus according to the commandment of God our Saviour, and Jesus Christ our hope;
1.2: to Timothy, my beloved son in the faith. Grace, mercy, peace, from God the Father and Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.3: As I exhorted you to remain in Ephesus, I going into Macedonia, in order that you may command certain ones not to teach heterodoxy,
1.4: nor to give heed to fables and endless genealogies, which present questions, rather than the economy of God which is in faith:
1.5: but the end of the commandment is divine love out of a clean heart and a good conscience and faith free from hypocrisy:
1.6: from which certain ones having deflected have gone out into empty talking,
1.7: wishing to be teachers of the law, not knowing either what they are saying, or concerning what things they do affirm.
1.8: But we know that the law is good, if any one may use it lawfully;
1.9: knowing this, that the law is not made for the righteous, but for the unrighteous and disorderly, for the ungodly and for sinners, for the unholy and the profane, for patricides, matricides and homocides,
1.10: for fornicators, for Sodomites, for kidnapers, for liars, for perjurers, and if any thing else is opposed to healthy teaching;
1.11: according to the gospel of the glory of the blessed God, with which I am intrusted.
1.12: I give thanks to Jesus Christ our Lord, the one having filled me up with dynamite, because he considered me faithful, having put me in the ministry;
1.13: being antecedently a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and an insulter: but I obtained mercy, because I did it in unbelief being ignorant;
1.14: but the grace of our Lord with faith and the divine love which is in Christ Jesus superabounded.
1.15: It is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners; of whom I am chief:
1.16: but on this account I obtained mercy, in order that Jesus Christ might in me the chief show forth all longsuffering, for an example of those about to believe on him unto eternal life.
1.17: But to the King of the ages, the incorruptible, invisible, only God, be honor and glory unto the ages of the ages. Amen.
1.18: This charge I commit unto you, O child Timothy, according to the prophecies that went before on you, that you may war a beautiful warfare in the same;
1.19: having faith and a good conscience; which some having cast away have made shipwreck concerning the faith;
1.20: of whom is Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have delivered to Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme.

2.1: Moreover, first of all things, I exhort you, that prayers, supplications, intercessions, thanksgivings, be made in behalf of all men;
2.2: for kings and all who are in authority; in order that we may lead a peaceable and quiet life in all godliness and honesty.
2.3: This is beautiful and acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour;
2.4: who wishes all men to be saved, and to come to the perfect knowledge of the truth.
2.5: For there is one God, and there is also one mediator of God and men, the man, Christ Jesus,
2.6: the one having given himself a ransom for all, a testimony in due time;
2.7: in which I have been placed a herald and an apostle I speak the truth, I lie not, a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and in truth.
2.8: Therefore I wish that men in every place would all pray, holding up holy hands, without wrath and doubting:
2.9: likewise that the women adorn themselves in comely apparel, with modesty and prudence; not with braided hair, and gold or pearls or costly garments;
2.10: but whatsoever becomes women professing godliness, through good works.
2.11: Let a woman learn in silence in all submission;
2.12: but I do not permit a woman to dictate or usurp authority over her husband, but to be in silence.
2.13: For Adam was first created, then Eve.
2.14: And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgression;
2.15: but she shall be saved through child-bearing, if they may abide in faith and in divine love and in sanctification with prudence.

3.1: It is a faithful saying, If any one desires the episcopacy, he covets a beautiful work.
3.2: Therefore it behooves the bishop to be blameless, the husband of one wife, modest, prudent, orderly, hospitable, competent to teach,
3.3: not given to wine, not a controvertist; but gentle, peaceable, not a money lover;
3.4: ruling his own house beautifully; having children in subordination with all gravity;
3.5: but if any one does not know how to rule his own house, how will he take care of the church of God?
3.6: not a novice, lest being puffed up he may fall into the condemnation of the devil.
3.7: But it also behooves him indeed to have a beautiful testimony from the aliens, in order that he may not fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.
3.8: Likewise let the deacons be grave, not double tongued, not given to much wine, not fond of filthy lucre;
3.9: having the testimony of faith in a pure conscience.
3.10: And let them also first be proven; then let them minister the office of deacon, being irreproachable.
3.11: Likewise let their wives be grave, not tattlers, modest, faithful in all things.
3.12: Let the deacons be the husbands of one wife, ruling their children and their own houses beautifully.
3.13: For those having ministered the office of a deacon beautifully procure to themselves beautiful progress, and much boldness in the faith which is in Christ Jesus.
3.14: I write these things to you, hoping to come to you more speedily;
3.15: but if I tarry, in order that you may know how it behooves you to deport yourself in the house of God, which is the church of the living God, the pillar and ground of the truth.
3.16: And assuredly great is the mystery of godliness; Who is manifested in the flesh, was justified in the spirit, was seen of angels, was preached among the Gentiles, was believed on in the world, was taken up in glory.

4.1: But the Spirit says positively, that in the last times certain ones will depart from the faith, giving heed to seducing spirits and to the teachings of demons,
4.2: speaking lies in hypocrisy, having been cauterized as to their own conscience,
4.3: forbidding to marry, commanding to abstain from meats, which God created for reception with thanksgiving to the faithful and to those perfectly knowing the truth.
4.4: Because every creature of God is good, and nothing rejected, being received with thanksgiving:
4.5: for it is sanctified by the word of God and by prayer.
4.6: Submitting these things to the brethren, you will be a beautiful minister of Jesus Christ, being nourished by the words of faith, and the beautiful teaching which you have followed;
4.7: but reject the unsanctified and silly stories: but exercise yourself unto godliness.
4.8: For bodily exercise is profitable unto little; but godliness is profitable unto all things, having the promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come.
4.9: This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all acceptation.
4.10: For unto this we toil and agonize, because we have hope in the living God, who is the Saviour of all men, especially of the faithful.
4.11: Command and teach these things.
4.12: Let no one look with contempt upon your youth; but be you an example of the faithful, in word, in deportment, in divine love, in faith, in purity.
4.13: Until I come, give attention to reading, to exhortation, to teaching.
4.14: Do not neglect the gift which is in you, which was given unto you through prophecy, with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery.
4.15: Be diligent in these things; give yourself wholly unto them; in order that your progress may be manifest to all.
4.16: Take heed to yourself and the teaching: continue in these things; for doing this you will indeed save yourself and those who hear you.

5.1: Rebuke not an elder, but exhort him as a father; the younger men as brothers:
5.2: the elderly women as mothers; the younger women as sisters, in all purity.
5.3: Honor widows who are truly widows.
5.4: But if any widow has children, or grandchildren, let them first learn to show piety to their own house, and to give benefactions to their ancestors: for this is acceptable in the sight of God.
5.5: She who is truly a widow, and left alone, hopes in God, and abides in prayers and supplication night and day;
5.6: but she who is wanton is dead though living.
5.7: Indeed command these things, in order that they may be blameless.
5.8: But if any one provides not for his own, and especially those of his own house, he has denied the faith, and is worse than an infidel.
5.9: Let a widow not be taken into account under three score years, the wife of one husband,
5.10: being witness in beautiful works; if she has brought up children, if she has entertained strangers, if she has washed the feet of saints, if she has succored those in tribulation, if she has followed in every good work.
5.11: But reject the younger widows: for when they may wax wanton against Christ, they wish to marry;
5.12: having condemnation, because they have rejected their first faith:
5.13: and at the same time they learn to be idle, going about houses; and not only idle, but also loquacious even busybodies, speaking things which they ought not.
5.14: Therefore I wish the younger women to marry, to raise up children, to rule the house, to give no occasion to the adversary for the sake of reproach;
5.15: for already certain ones have turned away after Satan.
5.16: If any faithful woman has widows, let her support them, and let not the church be burdened; in order that she may give her attention to those who are truly widows.
5.17: Let the elders who stand before the people beautifully, be considered worthy of double remuneration, especially those laboring in the word and teaching.
5.18: For the scripture says, Thou shalt not muzzle the ox that treadeth out the corn: and, The laborer is worthy of his hire.
5.19: Bring not an accusation against an elder, except before two or three witnesses.
5.20: Convict those who sin before all, in order that the rest may also have fear.
5.21: I testify before God, and Jesus Christ, and the elect angels, that you must guard these things without prejudice, doing nothing by partiality.
5.22: Lay hands quickly on no one, and be not partaker of other men's sins.
5.23: Keep yourself pure. No longer drink water, but use a little wine for the sake of your stomach and on account of your frequent sickness.
5.24: The sins of some men are manifest beforehand, going before to judgment; and some men they also follow after:
5.25: likewise truly are good works manifested beforehand; and those which are otherwise are not able to be hidden.

6.1: Let the servants so many as are under the yoke, esteem those who are their masters worthy of all honor, in order that the name and doctrine of God may not be blasphemed.
6.2: But let those that have faithful masters not despise them, because they are brethren; but rather let them serve them, because they are the faithful and beloved who are partaking of the benefaction. Command these things and exhort them.
6.3: If any one teaches another doctrine, and does not give heed to the sound words which belonged to our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godliness;
6.4: he has been inflated, knowing nothing, but doting about questions and controversies, from which come envy, strife, blasphemies, evil surmisings,
6.5: wranglings of men having been corrupted as to their mind and turned away from the truth, considering that gain is godliness.
6.6: Godliness with contentment is great gain,
6.7: for because we have brought nothing into the world, we are not able to carry any thing out;
6.8: however having food and raiment we shall be contented with these.
6.9: But those wishing to be rich fall into temptation and a snare and many foolish and hurtful lusts, which drown the people in destruction and perdition.
6.10: For the love of money is a root of all evils: which some seeking after have wandered from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows.
6.11: But you, O man of God, fly from these things; and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, divine love, patience, meekness.
6.12: Fight the good fight of faith, lay hold on eternal life, into which you have been called, and witnessed a beautiful testimony before many witnesses.
6.13: I charge you before God, who creates life in all things, and Jesus Christ, who witnessed a beautiful testimony before Pontius Pilate,
6.14: that you keep the commandment, spotless and pure, unto the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ:
6.15: which the blessed and only Sovereign, the King of the kings, and Lord of the lords, will manifest in his own due times;
6.16: he alone having immortality, inhabiting light unapproachable; whom no one of men has seen, or is able to see: to whom be honor and power eternal. Amen.
6.17: Charge the rich in this world not to think high things, nor to hope in uncertain riches, but in God, who richly supplies us all things for our enjoyment;
6.18: that they do good, be rich in good works, be cheerful givers, ready communicators;
6.19: laying up for themselves a good foundation for the future, that they may lay hold on the life which is life indeed.
6.20: O Timothy, stand guard over that which has been committed to you, avoiding unsanctified, empty talks and oppositions of knowledge falsely so called,
6.21: which some proclaiming have made shipwreck concerning the faith. Grace be with you.

1.1: Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, according to the commandment of life which is in Christ Jesus,
1.2: to Timothy, my beloved child. Grace, mercy, peace from God our Father and Jesus Christ our Lord.
1.3: I give thanks to God, whom I serve from my ancestors with a clean conscience, as I have incessant mention of you in my prayers, night and day
1.4: longing to see you, remembering your tears, in order that I may be filled with joy;
1.5: having received the remembrance of the unhypocritical faith which is in you; which dwelt first in your grandmother Lois, and your mother Eunice; and, I am persuaded that it is in you also.
1.6: On account of which cause I remind you to revive and refire the gift of God which is in you by the laying on of my hands.
1.7: For God has not given us the spirit of cowardice; but of power and divine love and prudence.
1.8: Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor me his prisoner: but suffer affliction for the sake of the gospel according to the power of God;
1.9: the one having saved us, and called us with a holy calling, not according to our works, but according to his own purpose and grace, which was given to us in Christ Jesus before the eternal times,
1.10: but now having been made manifest through the appearing of Jesus Christ our Saviour, the one having indeed destroyed death, and lighted up life and immortality through the gospel,
1.11: unto which I have been placed a herald, and an apostle, and teacher:
1.12: on account of which cause I indeed suffer these things: but I am not ashamed; for I know whom I have believed, and am persuaded that he is able to stand guard over that which is committed unto me unto that day.
1.13: Hold fast the form of sound words which you heard with me, in the faith and divine love which is in Christ Jesus:
1.14: stand guard over the beautiful deposit through the Holy Ghost who dwells in us.
1.15: You know this, that all who are in Asia, of whom are Phygelus and Hermogenes have turned away from me.
1.16: May the Lord grant mercy to the family of Onesiphorus, because frequently he refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my chain,
1.17: and, being in Rome, he diligently sought me, and found me.
1.18: May the Lord grant unto him to find mercy with the Lord in that day. And so many things as he ministered in Ephesus, you know better.

2.1: Therefore, my child, be thou filled up with dynamite in the grace which is in Christ Jesus,
2.2: and whatsoever things thou hast heard with me through many witnesses, commit thou the same to faithful men, who will be able also to teach others.
2.3: Suffer affliction, as a good soldier of Jesus Christ.
2.4: No one operating as a soldier is entangled with the affairs of life; in order that he may please his commander.
2.5: But if indeed any one may fight, he is not crowned unless he may fight lawfully.
2.6: It behooves the toiling farmer first to partake of the fruits.
2.7: Know what I say; for the Lord will give you understanding in all things.
2.8: Remember Jesus Christ, who is risen from the dead, from the seed of David, according to my gospel:
2.9: in whom I suffer affliction as an evil-doer, even unto bonds; but the word of God is not bound.
2.10: On account of this I endure all things for the sake of the elect, in order that they may also have the salvation which is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory.
2.11: It is a faithful saying: For if we die along with him, we will also live with him:
2.12: if we endure, we will truly reign with him: if we shall deny him, he will also deny us:
2.13: if we are unfaithful, he remains faithful; for he is not able to deny himself.
2.14: Remember these things, testifying before God, that they shall not fight with words, profitable unto nothing, for the overturning of those who hear.
2.15: Study to present yourself to God approved, a workman not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth.
2.16: But reject the unsanctified empty talks: for they will proceed unto more of ungodliness,
2.17: and their word like gangrene will have eating. Of whom are Hymenaeus and Phyletus;
2.18: who have made shipwreck concerning the truth, saying that the resurrection has already come, and they overturn the faith of some.
2.20: But in a great house there are not only gold and silver vessels, but also wood and stone, the former truly indeed unto honor, but the latter unto dishonor.
2.21: Therefore if any one may cleanse himself from these, he shall be a vessel unto honor, having been sanctified, well pleasing to the Lord, having been prepared unto every good work.
2.22: But fly from youthful lusts, and pursue righteousness, faith, divine love, peace, with those who call upon the Lord out of a clean heart.
2.23: But reject foolish and undisciplinary questions, knowing that they gender strife.
2.24: But it does not behoove the servant of the Lord to strive, but to be gentle toward all, competent to teach, enduring evil,
2.25: in meekness correcting the adversaries; if peradventure God may grant unto them repentance into the perfect knowledge of the truth,
2.26: and they may escape from the snare of the devil, having been taken captive by him (the Lord's servant) according to his will.

3.1: But know this, that in the last days perilous times shall come.
3.2: For men will be lovers of themselves, moneylovers, arrogant, proud, blasphemous, disobedient to parents, ungrateful, unholy,
3.3: without natural affections, covenant breakers, devilish, intemperate, furious, opposed to good,
3.4: traitors, headstrong, puffed up, lovers of pleasure rather than lovers of God;
3.5: having a form of godliness, but denying the power of the same: and from these turn away.
3.6: For of these are those creeping into houses, and leading captive little, silly women laden with sins, being led by divers lusts,
3.7: always learning, and never able to come into the perfect knowledge of the truth.
3.8: In the manner in which Jannes and Jambres also resisted Moses, so these indeed resist the truth; men who are corrupt as to their mind, reprobate concerning the faith.
3.9: But they shall proceed no further: for their insanity will be manifest to all, as theirs also was.
3.10: Burt you have followed my teaching, leadership, purpose, faith, long suffering, divine love, patience,
3.11: persecutions, sufferings; such as came to me in Antioch, in Iconium, in Lystra; such persecutions as I endured: and the Lord delivered me out of them all.
3.12: But truly all wishing to live godly in Christ Jesus will suffer persecution.
3.13: But wicked men and seducers will wax worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived.
3.14: But abide thou in those things which thou hast learned and in which thou hast been instructed, knowing from whom thou hast learned;
3.15: and that from an infant thou hast known the holy scriptures which are able to make thee wise unto salvation through faith which is in Christ Jesus.
3.16: All scripture is God-breathed and profitable unto teaching, unto conviction, unto correction, unto instruction which is in righteousness:
3.17: in order that the man of God may be perfect, having been thoroughly perfected unto every good work.

4.1: In the presence of God, and Jesus Christ, the one about to judge the living and the dead, I testify to, both his appearing and his kingdom;
4.2: preach the word: be instant in season and out of season; convict, exhort, rebuke, with all longsuffering and teaching.
4.3: For the time will come when they will not endure healthy teaching; but according to their own lusts they will heap to themselves teachers itching as to their hearing;
4.4: and they will indeed turn their hearing from the truth, and be turned unto fables.
4.5: But be thou sober in all things, suffer affliction, do the work of an evangelist, make full proof of thy ministry.
4.6: For I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand.
4.7: I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith:
4.8: finally there is a crown of righteousness laid up for me, which the Lord, the righteous judge, will give me in that day: not only to me, but to all those who with divine love, do love his appearing.
4.9: Hasten to come to me quickly.
4.10: For Demas has left me, having loved the present age, and is gone into Thessalonica; Crescents into Galatia, Titus into Dalmatia.
4.11: Luke alone is with me. Having taken Mark, bring him with you: for he is useful unto me for the ministry.
4.12: But I sent Tychicus into Ephesus.
4.13: Coming, bring the cloak, which I left in Troas with Carpus, and the books, especially the parchments.
4.14: Alexander the coppersmith showed to me much evil: the Lord will reward him according to his works.
4.15: Whom you also watch for he resisted our words exceedingly.
4.16: In my first defence no one stood by me, but all left me: may it not be charged against them:
4.17: but the Lord stood by me, and impowered me; in order that the preaching through me might be fulfilled, and all the Gentiles hear: and I was delivered out of the mouth of the lion.
4.18: And the Lord will deliver me from every evil work, and save me into his heavenly kingdom: to whom be glory unto the ages of the ages. Amen.
4.19: Salute Prisca and Aquila, and the house of Onesiphorus.
4.20: Erastus remained in Corinth: and I left Trophimus in Miletum sick.
4.21: Hasten to come before winter. Eubulus and Pudens and Linus and Claudia and all the brothers salute you.
4.22: The Lord be with your spirit. Grace be with you.

1.1: Paul, the servant of God, and apostle of Jesus Christ, according to the faith of the elect of God, and the perfect knowledge of the truth which is according to godliness,
1.2: in the hope of eternal life, which God who cannot lie, promised before the eternal times,
1.3: and manifested in his own seasons his word by preaching, with which I am intrusted, according to the commandment of God our Saviour;
1.4: to Titus, my beloved son according to the common faith. Grace and peace from God the Father and Jesus Christ our Saviour.
1.5: Therefore I left you in Crete, in order that you may set in order remaining things, and establish elders in every city, as I commanded you;
1.6: if any one is irreproachable, the husband of one wife, having faithful children, not in accusation of riot or incorrigible.
1.7: For it behooves the bishop to be blameless, as the steward of God; not audacious, not irascible, not given to wine, not a controvertist, not fond of filthy lucre;
1.8: but hospitable, loving the good, prudent, righteous, holy, temperate;
1.9: holding that which is according to the teaching of the faithful word, in order that he may be able both to exhort with healthy teaching, and to convict the opposers.
1.10: For many are incorrigible, speaking vain things and egotistical, especially those from the circumcision,
1.11: whose mouths it is necessary to stop; who overturn whole families, teaching those things which it does not behoove, for the sake of disgraceful gain.
1.13: This testimony is true: on account of which cause convict them sharply, in order that they may be sound in the faith,
1.14: not giving heed to Jewish fables, and commandments of men turning away from the truth.
1.15: To the pure all things are pure: but to the corrupted and unbelieving there is nothing pure; yea, their mind and their conscience are polluted.
1.16: They profess to know God, but deny him by their works, being abominable, and unbelieving, and reprobate unto every good work.

2.1: But speak you those things which become healthy teaching.
2.2: That the elderly men be sober, grave, prudent, sound in faith, in divine love, in patience:
2.3: likewise that the elderly women be reverent in demeanor, not tattlers, not given to much wine, teachers of that which is good;
2.4: in order that they instruct the young women to love their husbands, to love their children,
2.5: to be prudent, chaste, domestic, good, submissive to their own husbands, in order that the word of God may not be blasphemed.
2.6: Likewise exhort the young men to be prudent:
2.7: concerning all things exhibiting yourself an example of good works; in teaching; purity, gravity,
2.8: the sound word, irrefutable, in order that the adversary may be ashamed, having nothing evil to say concerning us.
2.9: That servants submit to their own masters, that they be obedient in all things; not speaking back;
2.10: not purloining, but exhibiting all good faith, that they may adorn the teaching of God our Saviour in all things.
2.11: For the grace of God, that brings salvation to all men, has appeared,
2.12: teaching us, that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we must live prudently and righteously and holily in this present age;
2.13: looking for the blessed hope even the appearing of the glory of our great God and our Saviour Christ Jesus;
2.14: who gave himself for us, that he might redeem us from all iniquity, and purify to himself a peculiar people, zealous of good works.
2.15: Speak these things and exhort and convict with all authority; let no one despise thee.

3.1: Remind them to submit to the governments, authorities, to obey the rule over them, to be ready unto every good work,
3.2: to speak evil of no one, that they should be peaceable, gentle, showing all meekness to all men.
3.3: For when we also were without understanding, being disobedient, deceived, serving divers lusts and pleasures, living in sin and envy, hateful, hating one another;
3.4: but when the goodness and philanthropy of God our Saviour appeared,
3.5: not from works which are in righteousness, which we did, but according to his own mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and the renewal of the Holy Ghost,
3.6: whom he poured out on us richly, through Jesus Christ our Saviour;
3.7: in order that, being justified by his faith, we may be made heirs according to the hope of eternal life.
3.8: The word is faithful, and I wish you to be established concerning these things, in order that those having believed in God may think to excel in good works. These things are beautiful and useful to the people:
3.9: but reject foolish questions, and genealogies, and strife, and controversies about law; for they are unprofitable and vain.
3.10: Reject a heretical man after the first and second admonition;
3.11: knowing that such an one is turned away, and is sinning, being self-condemned.
3.12: When I shall send Artemas or Tychicus to you, hasten to come to me at Nicopolis: for I have determined to spend the winter there.
3.13: Send on Zenas the lawyer and Apollos speedily, in order that nothing may be lacking to them.
3.14: And let our people indeed learn to excel in good works for necessary uses, in order that they may not be unfruitful.
3.15: All who are with me salute you. Salute those who love us with the love of friendship in the faith. Grace be with you all.

1.1: Paul, the prisoner of Jesus Christ, and brother Timothy, to Philemon the beloved also our fellow-laborer,
1.2: and to sister Apphia, and Archippus our fellow-soldier, and the church in your house.
1.3: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
1.4: I give thanks to my God always, making mention of you in my prayers,
1.5: hearing about your divine love, and the faith which you have toward the Lord Jesus, and all the saints;
1.6: in order that the fellowship of your faith may be efficient in the perfect knowledge of every good thing which is in you toward Christ.
1.7: For I had much joy and consolation over your divine love, because the affections of the saints have been refreshed by you, O brother.
1.8: Therefore, having much boldness in Christ to command you to that which is appropriate,
1.9: on account of the divine love, I the more exhort you, being such as Paul the aged, and now also the prisoner of Jesus Christ.
1.10: I exhort you concerning my son, whom I begat in my bonds, Onesimus,
1.11: him at one time unprofitable to you, but now profitable both to you and to me: whom I have sent back to you,
1.12: him, that is my own heart.
1.13: Whom I did wish to have with me, in order that he might minister unto me in your stead in the bonds of the gospel:
1.14: but without your consent I did not wish to do anything; in order that your good might not be by constraint, but by the free will:
1.15: for on this account he suddenly departed from you for an hour, that you might have him back forever;
1.16: no longer as a slave, but more than a slave, a brother beloved, especially to me, and much more to you, both in the flesh and in the Lord:
1.17: if then you have me a comrade, receive him as myself.
1.18: If he has wronged you as to anything, or owes you anything, charge this to me.
1.19: I Paul have written with my own hand, I will pay it: not that I may say to you that you even owe yourself to me.
1.20: Yea, brother, let me rejoice over you in the Lord: refresh my heart in Christ.
1.21: Having confidence in your obedience I have written to you, knowing that you will do even more than those things which I say.
1.22: And at the same time also prepare for me a lodging: for I hope that through your prayers I will be consigned unto you.
1.23: Epaphras, my fellow-soldier in Christ Jesus;
1.24: Mark, Aristarchus, Demas, Luke, my fellow-workers, salute you.
1.25: The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit.

1.1: On many occasions and in many ways in the olden time, God having spoken to the fathers through the prophets, at the last of these days has spoken to us through his Son,
1.2: whom he put forth the heir of all things, and through whom he created the ages;
1.3: who being the brightness of his glory, and the character of his person, and holding up all things by the word of his power, having made purgation of the sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high;
1.4: being so much greater than the angels, that he has inherited a name so much more excellent than they.
1.5: For to which one of the angels at any time did he say, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee? and again, I will be unto him a Father, and he shall be unto me a Son?
1.6: And again when he may lead in the first begotten into the world, he says, Indeed let all the angels of God worship him.
1.7: And to the angels he says, he maketh his angels spirits, and his ministers a flame of fire: but to the Son he says,
1.8: Thy throne, O God, is unto the age of the age; and the scepter of righteousness is the scepter of thy kingdom.
1.9: Thou hast loved righteousness, and hated iniquity; therefore God, thy God, has anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy comrades.
1.10: And thou, at the beginning, O Lord, didst lay the foundations of the earth, and the heavens are the works of thy hands.
1.11: These shall perish; but thou dost remain: truly all these shall wax old like a garment;
1.12: and thou shalt roll them up like a mantle, and they shall be changed: but thou art the same, and thy years shall not fail thee.
1.13: And to which one of the angels has he at any time said, Sit thou on my right hand, until I may make thine enemies the footstool of thy feet?
1.14: Are not all these ministering spirits, having been sent forth unto ministration for the sake of those who are about to inherit salvation?

2.1: Therefore it behooves us the more earnestly to give heed to the things which we have heard, lest at some time we may leak out.
2.2: For if the word having been spoken by angels was stedfast, and every disobedience and transgression received a just recompense of reward;
2.3: how shall we escape, having neglected so great a salvation? which having received the beginning to be spoken by the Lord, was confirmed unto us by those who heard it;
2.4: God at the same time witnessing, by signs and indeed by wonders, and various dynamites, and gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to his will.
2.5: For he did not submit the world to come, concerning which we speak, to angels.
2.6: But somewhere one testified, saying, What is man, that thou art mindful of him? Or the Son of man, that thou visitest him?
2.7: Thou didst humiliate him somewhat comparatively with the angels; thou didst crown him with glory and honor;
2.8: thou didst subordinate all things beneath his feet. For in subordinating all things beneath him, he left nothing which is not subordinated beneath him.
2.9: But we see Jesus humiliated somewhat in comparison with the angels, having been crowned with glory and honor on account of the suffering of death, in order that by the grace of God he might taste death for every one.
2.10: For it became him, on account of whom are all things, and through whom are all things, in leading many sons to glory, to make the captain of their salvation perfect through suffering.
2.11: For both the one sanctifying and they who are sanctified are all of one: on account of which cause he is not ashamed to call them brethren,
2.12: saying, I will proclaim thy name to thy brethren, in the midst of the church will sing praises to thee.
2.13: And again, I will put my trust in him: and again; Behold, I and the children which God has given unto me.
2.14: Then since the children have inherited blood and flesh, he likewise also received the same, in order that through death he might set at nought him who has the power of death, that is, the devil;
2.15: and might reconcile them whosoever were subject to bondage all their life through the fear of death.
2.16: For not yet does he take upon himself the nature of angels, but he takes upon himself the seed of Abraham.
2.17: Therefore he ought in all things to be made like unto his brethren, in order that he might be a merciful and faithful High Priest in things appertaining to God, to the end that he may atone for the sins of the people.
2.18: For in that he himself suffered being tempted, he is able to succor those who are tempted.

3.1: Therefore, holy brethren, partakers of the heavenly calling, consider Jesus, the Apostle and High Priest of our profession;
3.2: being faithful to him who appointed him, as indeed Moses in all his house.
3.3: For he is esteemed worthy of more honor than Moses, inasmuch as the One having built it, has more honor than the house.
3.4: For every house is built by some one; and the one having built all things is God.
3.5: And Moses was indeed faithful in all his house as a servant, unto the testimony of those things which shall be spoken;
3.6: but Christ was as a son, over his own house; whose house we are, if we hold fast the boldness and rejoicing of hope firm unto the end.
3.7: Therefore as the Holy Spirit says, This day if you hear his voice,
3.8: harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the wilderness,
3.9: whom our fathers tempted in proving me, and saw my works forty years.
3.10: Therefore I was provoked with this generation, and I said, They do always err in their heart: and they have not known my way,
3.11: as I swore in my wrath, They shall not enter into my rest.
3.12: See, brethren, lest at some time there shall be in some one of you an evil heart of unbelief, in turning away from the living God:
3.13: but exhort one another each day, while it is called to-day; in order that no one of you may be hardened with the deceitfulness of sin:
3.14: for we have been made partakers of Christ, if indeed we may hold fast the beginning of confidence firm unto the end.
3.15: In that it is said, This day if you hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation:
3.16: for who were those, having heard, who were hardened? yea, were they not all those having come out of Egypt under Moses?
3.17: And with whom was he provoked forty years? was it not with those that sinned, whose carcases fell in the wilderness?
3.18: And to whom did he swear that they should not enter into his rest, but to those who believed not?
3.19: And we see that they were not able to enter in on account of their unbelief.

4.1: Then let us fear, lest at some time, the promise to enter into his rest having been left, some of you may appear to have come short.
4.2: For we truly have had the gospel preached unto us, as they did also: but the word of hearing did not profit them, not being mixed with faith to those hearing.
4.3: For we who have believed, do enter into rest: as he has said, As I swore in my wrath, They shall not enter into my rest: the works truly having been from the foundations of the world.
4.4: For he somewhere has spoken thus in reference to the seventh day, And God rested on the seventh day from all his works.
4.5: And in this again he has said, They shall not enter into my rest.
4.6: Then since it remains that some do enter into it, and those formerly having had the gospel preached unto them did not enter in on account of unbelief,
4.7: again he appoints a certain day, saying in David, as has previously been said, This day, after so long a time; If you may hear his voice this day, harden not your hearts.
4.8: For if Joshua had given them rest, he would not speak concerning another day after these things.
4.9: Therefore there is a sabbatism left for the people of God.
4.10: For the one having entered into his rest has ceased from his works, as God did from his own.
4.11: Therefore let us hasten to enter into that rest, lest some one may fall by the same example of unbelief.
4.12: For the word of God is living, and powerful, and sharper than any two-edged sword, and piercing unto the dividing of soul and spirit, of both joints and marrow, and a quick discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart.
4.13: And no creature is hidden in his presence: but all things are naked and have been laid open to the eyes of him to whom the word is unto us.
4.14: Therefore having a great high priest, having entered into the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast the testimony.
4.15: For we have not a high priest who is not able to be touched with our infirmities; but one having been tempted as to all things like unto us, apart from sin.
4.16: Therefore let us draw nigh with confidence to a throne of grace, that we may receive mercy, and find grace in every opportune need.

5.1: For every high priest, being received from men, presides over men in the things appertaining to God, in order that he may offer gifts and sacrifices for sins:
5.2: being able to sympathize with the ignorant and erring, since himself is also compassed about with infirmity;
5.3: and on this account he has need, as for the people, so also for himself, to offer sacrifices for sins.
5.4: And no one takes this honor to himself, but the one called of God, as indeed Aaron was.
5.5: Likewise Christ also did not glorify himself to become a high priest, but the one having spoken to him, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee:
5.6: as also he says in another place, Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.
5.7: Who in the days of his flesh, having with strong crying and tears offered up both prayers and supplications unto him who is able to save him from death, and having been heard on account of his piety,
5.8: indeed being a Son, he learned obedience from those things which he suffered;
5.9: and having been made perfect, he became the author of eternal salvation to all those who obey him;
5.10: having been ordained of God a high priest after the order of Melchizedek.
5.11: Concerning whom there is much word to us, and difficult to speak, since you are dull of hearing.
5.12: For indeed you, who ought to be teachers so far as time is concerned, have need that some one again teach you what are the rudiments of the beginning of the oracles of God; and you have need of milk, not solid food.
5.13: For every one partaking of milk is unskilful in the word of righteousness; for he is a babe;
5.14: but solid food belongs to the perfect, those having their senses disciplined by use unto the discernment both of the good and the evil.

6.1: Therefore having left the word of the beginning of Christ, let us be carried to perfection; not again laying the foundation of repentance from dead works, and of faith toward God,
6.2: of the teaching of baptisms, and of the laying on of hands, and of the resurrection of the dead, and of eternal judgment.
6.3: And we will do this, if God may permit.
6.4: For it is impossible that those having been once enlightened, and tasted the heavenly gift, and have been made partakers of the Holy Ghost,
6.5: and having tasted the beautiful word of God, and the dynamites of the coming age,
6.6: indeed having fallen away, to renew them again unto repentance; having crucified to themselves again the Son of God, and put him to an open shame.
6.7: For the earth drinking the rain coming often upon her, and bringing forth the herb nutritious to those by whom it is also cultivated, receives blessings from God:
6.8: but that which produces thorns and thistles, is reprobate, and nigh unto the curse; whose end is unto burning.
6.9: But, beloved, we are persuaded better things concerning you, and things appertaining to salvation, if indeed we do thus speak.
6.10: For God is not unrighteous to forget your work and the divine love which you manifested in his name, having ministered to the saints, and ministering.
6.11: But we desire each one of you to exhibit the same diligence unto the full assurance of hope unto the end:
6.12: in order that you may not be dull, but imitators of those who through faith and longsufferings do inherit the promises.
6.13: For God having promised Abraham, since he had no greater one by whom to swear, swore by himself,
6.14: saying, If indeed blessing I will bless thee, and multiplying I will multiply thee:
6.15: and thus having waited long, he received the promise.
6.16: For men swear by the greater: and an oath of confirmation is to them an end to all controversy:
6.17: but God, in this wishing more abundantly to show forth to the heirs of the promise the immutability of his counsel, confirmed it by an oath:
6.18: that through two immutable things in which it was impossible that God should lie, we who have fled may have a strong consolation to lay hold of the hope set before us,
6.19: which we have as an anchor of the soul, both sure and steadfast and entering into that which is in the veil,
6.20: whither Jesus the forerunner has entered in our behalf, having been made a high priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.

7.1: For this Melchizedek, the king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, the one having met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him,
7.2: to whom Abraham divided the tenth from all first, being interpreted, King of righteousness, and then King of Salem, which is, King of peace;
7.3: without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but being made like unto the Son of God, he abides a priest continually.
7.4: You see how great this man was, to whom the patriarch Abraham even gave the tenth part of the chief spoils.
7.5: And those indeed of the sons of Levi receiving the priesthood have a commandment to tithe the people according to the law, that is, their brethren, even though having come out from the loins of Abraham:
7.6: but he who did not derive his lineage from them has tithed Abraham, and blessed him having the promises.
7.7: For without contradiction the less is blessed by the better.
7.8: And here indeed men dying, receive tithes; however there, he is witnessed to that he lives.
7.9: And, so to speak a word, Levi, the one receiving tithes, has also been tithed through Abraham.
7.10: For he was still in the loins of his father, when Melchizedek met him.
7.11: Then indeed if perfection was through the Levitical priesthood, for unto it the people have been tithed, what need is there still that another priest shall rise after the order of Melchizedek, and not be called after the order of Aaron?
7.12: For the priesthood being changed, of necessity there is a change of the law.
7.13: For he unto whom these things were spoken belongs to another tribe, from which no one ministers at the altar:
7.14: for it is evident that our Lord sprang from Judah; in reference to which tribe Moses spoke nothing concerning priests.
7.15: And it is still more abundantly evident, if after the similitude of Melchizedek another priest rises,
7.16: who was not made after the law of a carnal commandment, but after the power of an endless life.
7.17: For it is testified, Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchizedek.
7.18: For there is a disannulling of the preceding commandment, on account of its weakness and inadequacy
7.19: for the law made nothing perfect, but the bringing in of a better hope, by which we draw nigh unto God.
7.20: And in as much as it is without an oath, for the priests were made without an oath;
7.21: but He with an oath through the one saying to him, The Lord hath sworn, and will not regret it; thou art a priest forever;
7.22: insomuch that Jesus has also been made the mediator of a better covenant.
7.23: And indeed many have been made priests, because they were prohibited by death from continuing:
7.24: but he, because he abides forever, has an unchangeable priesthood:
7.25: wherefore he is also able to save to the uttermost those coming unto God through him, ever living to intercede for them.
7.26: For such a high priest was indeed appropriate unto us, holy, free from sin, undefiled, having been separated from the sinners, and being higher than the heavens;
7.27: who had not daily need, as the high priests, first to offer up sacrifices for their own sins, then those of the people: for he did this, having offered up himself once.
7.28: For the law institutes men high priests, having infirmity; but the word of the oath, which is after the law, the Son, having been made perfect forever.

8.1: But in addition to the things which having been spoken this is the principal thing: We have such a high priest, who sat on the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven,
8.2: The minister of the holy things, and of the true tabernacle, which God pitched, and not man.
8.3: For every high priest is appointed to offer both gifts and sacrifices: whence it is necessary to have something even that which he may offer.
8.4: If then indeed he was on the earth, he would not be a priest, there being those offering gifts according to law,
8.5: whosoever serve the pattern and shadow of heavenly things, as Moses about to complete the tabernacle was commanded: for, he says, See that you shall make all things after the pattern which was shown to you in the mount:
8.6: but now he has obtained a more excellent ministry, insomuch that he is also the mediator of a better covenant, which has been founded on better promises.
8.7: For if that first covenant had been faultless, a place would not have been sought for the second.
8.8: For finding fault with them, he says, Behold the days are coming, says the Lord, and I will perfect upon the house of Israel and upon the house of Judah, a new covenant:
8.9: not according to the covenant which I made with their fathers, in the day that I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt; because they abode not in my covenant, and I regarded them not, says the Lord.
8.10: Because this is my covenant which I will establish with the house of Israel after these days, says the Lord; having given my laws in their mind, I will also write them on their heart; and I will be to them a God, and they shall be unto me a people.
8.11: And they shall no longer teach each one his neighbor, each one his brother, saying, Know ye the Lord: because all shall know me, from their small even unto the great.
8.12: Because I will be merciful unto their iniquities, and I will remember their sins no more.
8.13: In that he calls it new, he has made the first one old; but that which is old and antiquated is nigh unto vanishing.

9.1: Then indeed the first tabernacle also, had ordinances of service, and a sanctuary for this world.
9.2: For the first tabernacle was made; in which there were candlesticks, and the table, and shew-bread; which is called, Holy.
9.3: And after the second veil, was the tabernacle called Holy of holies;
9.4: having the golden altar, and the ark of the covenant overladen on all sides with gold, in which was the golden pot having the manna, and the rod of Aaron which budded, and the tables of the covenant;
9.5: and above this was the cherubim of glory overshadowing the mercy seat; concerning which things it is not pertinent to speak specifically.
9.6: And these having been thus adjusted, the priests come continually into the first tabernacle, performing the services:
9.7: and into the second comes the high priest alone once a year, not without blood, which he offers for himself, and the errors of the people;
9.8: the Holy Spirit showing this, the way of the holies has not yet been made manifest, the first tabernacle yet standing:
9.9: which is a figure unto the present time, in which gifts and sacrifices are offered, not being able to make the worshiper perfect, as to his conscience;
9.10: consisting only in meats and drinks, and divers baptisms, ordinances of the flesh, abiding until the time of restitution.
9.11: But Christ being a high priest of good things to come, through a greater and a more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is, not of this world;
9.12: neither through the blood of goats and bullocks, but through his own blood, came once into the holies, having found eternal redemption.
9.13: For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the ashes of a heifer sprinkling those who have been defiled, sanctifies unto the purification of the flesh;
9.14: how much more shall the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered up himself without spot to God, purify our conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
9.15: And on this account he is mediator of the new covenant, since there being death, unto the redemption of the transgressions unto the first covenant, those having been called may receive the promise of eternal inheritance.
9.16: For where there is a covenant, it is necessary to bear the death of the covenanter;
9.17: for a covenant is valid in case of the dead: since it has no force while the covenanter lives.
9.18: Neither was the first covenant therefore dedicated without blood.
9.19: For every commandment having been spoken by Moses to all the people according to law, having taken the blood of bullocks and goats, with water, and scarlet wool, and hyssop, he sprinkled both the book itself and all the people,
9.20: saying, This is the blood of the covenant which God established unto you.
9.21: And he likewise also sprinkled the tabernacle, and all the vessels of the ministry, with blood.
9.22: And according to the law, almost all things are purified by blood; and without the shedding of blood there is no remission.
9.23: Therefore it is necessary that the pattern of the things in these heavens be purified; and the heavenly things themselves with greater sacrifices than these.
9.24: For Christ did not come into the sanctuaries made with hands, the pattern of the true; but into heaven itself, now to be made manifest unto the face of God in our behalf:
9.25: neither in order that he may frequently offer up himself, as the high priest goes into the holies once a year with the blood of another;
9.26: since it behooved him frequently to suffer from the foundation of the world: but now in the end of the ages he has been made manifest unto the removal of sin through the sacrifice of himself.
9.27: And inasmuch as it is appointed unto men once to die, and after this is the judgment:
9.28: so also Christ, having once been offered up to bear away the sins of many, will appear the second time apart from sin unto salvation to those expecting him.

10.1: For the law having the shadow of good things to come, not the real image of the things, annually with the same sacrifices which they offer continually, is by no means able to make perfect those coming to it:
10.2: since in that case would they not have ceased being offered, because the worshipers having once been purified would have had no more conscience of sins?
10.3: But in the same sacrifices there is a remembrance of sins annually;
10.4: for it is impossible that the blood of bulls and goats should take away sins.
10.5: Therefore, coming into the world, he says; Sacrifice an offering thou willest not, but thou hast perfected for me a body:
10.6: whole burnt offerings and offerings for sins thou wast not pleased with:
10.7: then I said, Lo, I come in the volume of the Book it has been written of me to do thy will, O God.
10.8: Saying above, that Sacrifices and offerings and whole burnt offerings and offerings for sin thou didst not will, neither wast well pleased with; whatsoever are offered according to law;
10.9: then he has said, Lo, I come to do thy will. He takes away the first, that he may establish the second;
10.10: by which will we have been sanctified through the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once for all.
10.11: And every high priest indeed stands daily ministering, and frequently offering the same sacrifices, which are never able to take away sins:
10.12: and he, having offered up one sacrifice for sins, forever sat down on the right hand of God;
10.13: finally waiting until his enemies may be made the foot-stool of his feet.
10.14: For by one offering he has forever perfected the sanctified.
10.15: And the Holy Ghost truly does witness to us: for afterward he said,
10.16: This is the covenant that I will make unto them after these days, says the Lord; having given my laws on their hearts, and I will also write them in their mind;
10.17: and I will remember their sins and iniquities no more.
10.18: But where there is removal of these, there is no more offering for sin.
10.19: Then, brethren, having boldness unto the entering in of the holies through the blood of Jesus,
10.20: by which he has opened unto us a new and living way, through the veil, that is, of his flesh,
10.21: and having a great high priest over the house of God;
10.22: let us draw nigh with a true heart in a full assurance of faith, having been sprinkled as to our hearts from an evil conscience,
10.23: and washed as to our body with purifying water: let us hold fast the testimony of hope steadfast; for the one having promised is faithful;
10.24: and let us recognize one another in the provocation of divine love and good works:
10.25: not forsaking the assembling of ourselves together as is the custom to some; but exhorting: and this the more, as you see the days drawing nigh.
10.26: For we sinning willingly after we have received the perfect knowledge of the truth, there is left no more sacrifice for sins,
10.27: but a certain fearful anticipation of judgment and violence of fire, about to devour the adversaries.
10.28: The one having rejected the law of Moses dies without mercy before two or three witnesses:
10.29: of how much more terrible punishment, do you think, the one having trodden under foot the Son of God, and counted the blood of the covenant, by which he was sanctified, common, and insulted the Spirit of grace; be counted worthy!
10.30: For we know him who said, Vengeance belongs to me, I will repay; and again, The Lord will judge his people.
10.31: It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
10.32: But remember the former days, in which, you being illuminated by the Spirit, endured a great fight of afflictions;
10.33: both indeed in reproaches and tribulations being exposed as a theater, and having become the companions of those being thus exercised.
10.34: For you suffered along with the prisoners, and received with joy the spoliation of your goods, knowing that you have a better and abiding possession.
10.35: Therefore cast not away your confidence, which has great reward.
10.36: For you have need of patience, in order that, having done the will of God, you will inherit the promise.
10.37: For yet a little while, the one coming will come, and will not tarry.
10.38: My righteous man shall live by faith: and if he may draw back, my soul has no pleasure in him.
10.39: But we are not of the drawing back unto perdition; but of faith unto the salvation of the soul.

11.1: But faith is the confidence of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.
11.2: For by it the elders receive the witness of the Spirit.
11.3: By faith we understand that the worlds were created by the word of God, and that which was seen was not made from things which are manifest.
11.4: By faith Abel offered up to God a more acceptable sacrifice than Cain, through which he received the witness that he was righteous, God witnessing to his gifts: and through it he having died is still speaking.
11.5: By faith Enoch was translated that he should not see death; and he was not found because God translated him. For before he was translated he had the witness of the Spirit, that he pleased God:
11.6: but without faith it is impossible to please him: for it behooves the one coming unto God to believe that he is, and he is a rewarder unto them who seek him out.
11.7: By faith Noah, being warned concerning things not yet seen, being moved with fear, prepared an ark for the salvation of his family; by which he condemned the world, and became heir to the righteousness which is according to faith.
11.8: By faith Abraham, being called to go out into a place which he was about to receive for an inheritance, obeyed; and went out, not knowing whither he goes.
11.9: By faith he sojourned in the land of promise, as a strange country, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, fellow-heirs of the same promise:
11.10: for he anticipated a city having foundations, whose builder and maker is God.
11.11: And by faith Sarah herself received power unto the conception of seed, even past the time of age, since she considered him faithful who had promised.
11.12: Therefore indeed they were born of one, and those things of one having died, as the stars of heaven for multitude, and as the sands which are by the sea, which are innumerable.
11.13: These all died in the faith, not having received the promises, but seeing them afar off, and embracing them, and confessing that they are strangers and pilgrims on the earth.
11.14: For those speaking such things declare that they are seeking after a country of their own.
11.15: If indeed they remember that country from which they came out, they would have had an opportunity to return;
11.16: but now they seek a better country, that is, a heavenly. Therefore God is not ashamed to be called their God: for he has prepared for them a city.
11.17: By faith Abraham, being tested, offered up Isaac: and the one having received the promises offered up his only begotten son,
11.18: in reference to whom it was said, In Isaac shall thy seed be called:
11.19: considering that God is able to raise him from the dead; whence he also received him in a figure.
11.20: By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come.
11.21: By faith Jacob, when dying, blessed each one of the sons of Joseph, and worshiped, on the hilt of his staff.
11.22: By faith Joseph, dying, made mention concerning the exodus of the children of Israel; and commanded concerning his own bones.
11.23: By faith Moses, having been born, was hidden three months by his parents, because they saw that he was a beautiful child; and did not fear the commandment of the king.
11.24: By faith Moses, having become an adult, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter;
11.25: choosing rather to suffer affliction with the people of God, than to enjoy the pleasure of sin for a season;
11.26: esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt: for he was looking unto the recompense of reward.
11.27: By faith he left Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king: for he went out, as seeing the invisible one.
11.28: By faith he instituted the passover, and the sprinkling of blood, in order that the one destroying the first-born might not touch them.
11.29: By faith they pass through the Red sea as through dry land: the undertaking of which the Egyptians having entered upon were drowned.
11.30: By faith the walls of Jericho fell, having been encompassed about seven days,
11.31: By faith Rahab the harlot perished not with the unbelievers, having received the spies with peace.
11.32: And what do I yet say? time will fail me relating concerning Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, and David, and Samuel, and the prophets:
11.33: who through faith subdued kingdoms, wrought righteousness,
11.34: obtained promises, escaped the edge of the sword, from weakness became filled up with dynamite, became mighty in war, put to flight the armies of the aliens:
11.35: women receive their dead from a resurrection: some were tortured, not accepting deliverance; in order that they might receive a better resurrection:
11.36: and others received the trial of scourgings and mockings, and still of bonds and imprisonment:
11.37: they were stoned, they were tempted, they were burnt, they died by the edge of the sword; they went about in sheepskins, in goatskins; being destitute, troubled, persecuted,
11.38: of whom the world was not worthy; wandering in deserts, and in mountains, and caves and dens of the earth.
11.39: And all these, having received the witness of the spirit through faith, did not obtain the promise:
11.40: God having reserved something better for us, that they might not be made perfect apart from us.

12.1: Therefore let us indeed, having around us so great a cloud of witnesses, having laid aside every weight, and the sin that doth so easily beset us, run with patience the race which is set before us,
12.2: looking unto Jesus the beginner and perfecter of our faith; who for the joy that was placed before him, endured the cross, looking with contempt at the shame, and has sat down on the right hand of the throne of God.
12.3: For consider him who has endured so great a contradiction of sinners against himself, in order that you may not become weary, fainting in your souls.
12.4: For you have not yet resisted unto blood, fighting against sin;
12.5: and you have forgotten the exhortation which reasoneth with you as with sons, My son regard not lightly the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art proven of him:
12.6: for whom the Lord loves he chastises, and scourges every son whom he receives.
12.7: Endure unto chastisement; God deals with you as with sons; for what son is there whom the father does not chastise?
12.8: And if you are without chastisement, of which all have been partakers, then are you bastards, and not sons.
12.9: Then indeed, we had fathers of our flesh who chastised us, and we endured: how much more then shall we submit to the Father of spirits, and live?
12.10: For they indeed for a few days were accustomed to chastise us according to that which seemed right to them; but he made unto our profit, in order that we might partake his holiness.
12.11: Indeed no chastisement for the present seems to be truly joyful, but sorrowful: but afterward it yields the peaceable fruit of righteousness to them who have been disciplined by it.
12.12: Therefore hold up the hands which hang down, and the paralyzed knees,
12.13: and make straight paths for your feet, in order that whatsoever is lame may not be turned out of the way, but rather may it be healed.
12.14: Follow after peace with all men, and the sanctification, without which no one shall see the Lord:
12.15: looking diligently lest any one may fail from the grace of God; lest any root of bitterness springing up may trouble you, and through it many may be defiled;
12.16: lest any one may be a fornicator, or a profane person, as was Esau, who for one morsel sold his birthright.
12.17: For you know that, wishing to inherit the blessing, he was rejected: for he found no place of repentance even though having sought it diligently with tears.
12.18: For you have not come to the mountain that can be touched, and that is burnt with fire, and unto blackness and darkness, and tempest,
12.19: and to the sound of the trumpet, and the voice of words; which those having heard requested that the word should not be spoken unto them:
12.20: for they could not endure that which was spoken, If a wild beast should touch the mountain, it shall be pierced through with a dart:
12.21: and the sight was so fearful, Moses said, I exceedingly fear and tremble:
12.22: but you have come to mount Zion, and to the heavenly Jerusalem, to the city of the living God, and to myriads of angels,
12.23: to the whole company, and to the church of the first-born, who have been written in the heavens, and to God the Judge of all, and to the spirits of justified people who have been made perfect,
12.24: and to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, speaking something better than the blood of Abel.
12.25: See that you do not reject the one speaking: for if they escape not having rejected the one delivering them the divine oracles on earth, how much more shall we not escape, who turn away from the one speaking from the heavens:
12.26: whose voice then shook the earth; but now he has promised, saying, I will still once shake not only the earth, but also heaven.
12.27: But he would yet once show the removal of the things shaken, as having been created, in order that the things unshaken may remain.
12.28: Therefore receiving an unshaken kingdom, let us have grace, through which we may worship God acceptably with reverence and fear:
12.29: for our God is a consuming fire.

13.2: Forget not hospitality: for by it some having entertained angels were incognizant.
13.3: Remember those bound, as having been bound along with them; those suffering persecutions, as you yourselves being also in the body.
13.4: Marriage is honorable among all, and the couch undefiled: for God will judge fornicators and adulterers.
